DEBATE.TITLE: OPENING OF FUTURE SESSIONS OF THE PARLIAMENT

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that I have received a letter from His Excellency the Governor-General acknowledging the resolution agreed to by the House on 24 March 1988 relating to the arrangements for the opening of future sessions of Parliament.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Sinclair-Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. Can you explain the nature of that communication? Is the Governor-General accepting advice from this House without it having been approved by the Senate? If I may perhaps extend my remarks, my understanding was that that resolution had been forwarded to the Senate. Until such stage that it has been accepted by the Senate, it has not actually been accepted by the Parliament. I would therefore ask on what basis has advice from one House been forwarded to the representative of the Queen, instead of advice from the Parliament as would normally be the case?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter from the Governor-General just thanks the House for the letter of 24 March conveying the text of a resolution agreed to by the House of Representatives about arrangements for the opening of future sessions of Parliament. It is simply an acknowledgment of the fact that it was sent from this House to the Governor-General. It also has to go through the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Sinclair-Madam Speaker, with indulgence: my understanding is that the Parliament, not this House, advises the Governor-General. You will recall that there was a specific addition to the resolution requesting that the resolution be sent to the other chamber. It would seem extraordinary to me that the advice should be forwarded-and I accept that it has been-from just one House. I point out that, in normal circumstances, advice to the Governor-General should be advice from the Parliament. As you know so well, normally a resolution would go from this place to the other place, we would get advice back from the other place and we would then proceed to advise the Governor-General. I suggest that in this instance protocol has been breached. I think the Governor-General might well be alerted to that.

Mr Beazley-Madam Speaker, with your indulgence, on the point of order, I would suspect that this is a somewhat different resolution from that which would normally proceed in the way which has been suggested. It is about the opening arrangements for the Houses of Parliament on which both Houses may have different but equally valid views. We obviously have a requirement to consult the Senate on that matter, but not exclusively the Senate. I do not think there would be anything inappropriate in the Speaker or the Clerk-the Speaker in this case-writing to the Governor-General and informing him of the House's views.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was our view that we should request the Senate to pass the same motion. But I do not think that precludes this House from taking its own action.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS (MAINTENANCE INCOME TEST) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 March, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Connolly had moved by way of amendment:

That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: `whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House deplores the fact that the economic and social policies pursued by the Hawke Government since March 1983 have directly contributed to the continuing high level of marriage break-ups by:
(1) increasing the number of Australian families living below the poverty line and bearing the brunt of unemployment, including an additional 165 000 children;
(2) pursuing policies which have resulted in single income families on average weekly earnings with 2 children facing a decline of $42 a week in their standard of living in real terms;

(3) abolishing negative gearing between July 1985 and September 1987 which resulted in a decline in rental accommodation, and a steep rise in rental costs which has contributed to 160 000 Australians waiting for public housing, while thousands of families and individuals live in refuges, emergency accommodation or on the streets;
(4) failing to give recognition to the increased burdens of families with dependants other than the approximately 23% eligible for assistance under the Family Assistance Scheme; and
(5) contributing to a marked decline in the standard of living of veterans, war widows, ex-service personnel and serving personnel'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements (Maintenance Income Test) Amendment Bill and to oppose the amendment moved by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). I remind the House that the Bill is complementary to the Child Support Act 1988. Together, they constitute the major elements of the child support scheme, which is one of this Government's most significant social policy reforms. The Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements (Maintenance Income Test) Amendment Bill will effect reform in the manner in which maintenance, which is ordered under the Family Law Act and coordinated under the Child Support Act, is treated by the social security and veterans' benefits systems. This legislation is an essential part of the Government's program to enter the 1990s with guaranteed financial security for over 400,000 Australian children living in poverty as a result of the trauma associated with marriage breakdown.

SPEECH.PARA: Although many Australian parents assume responsibilities for child support subsequent to marriage breakdown, Australia is entering the 1990s with a trend in which only 30 per cent of non-custodial parents pay regular maintenance for their children. The fact that 70 per cent of non-custodial parents do not pay maintenance is a tragedy which this Government seeks to redress under the new child support scheme of which this Bill is an integral component. The Government recognises that the shirking of parental responsibility for non-custodial child support and the existence of child poverty are largely the result of deficiencies in the existing child maintenance system. Legislation must be enacted to ensure that the Australian taxpayer is not required to bear the economic burden of inadequate levels of court orders, ineffective coverage of the eligible population, difficulties in the enforcement of court orders and a lack of integration of the child maintenance system with the social security system as a whole.

The Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements (Maintenance Income Test) Amendment Bill provides a mechanism by which maintenance payable by non-custodial parents under the Child Support Act will be coordinated with public support entitlements and family allowance payments for distribution to beneficiaries through the Department of Social Security. Upon the introduction of this Bill, the following maintenance reforms will be implemented: capital or lump sum maintenance as specified in orders or agreements made after the start of the scheme will be imputed as income of pensioners and beneficiaries; in-kind maintenance and payments made to third parties in lieu of maintenance will also be imputed; a separate maintenance income test will be introduced; there will be special treatment of maintenance by way of housing provision; and special savings provisions will preserve the pre-scheme total income of existing pensioners and beneficiaries who are custodial parents.

The introduction of this Bill, in association with the Child Support Act and amendments to the Family Law Act, will have particular application in the Northern Territory. Statistics reveal that in the Northern Territory 11.5 per cent of families are single parent families with one or more dependent children, compared with the national average of 7.9 per cent. Those figures, and the transient nature of the Northern Territory, lead one to deduce that single parent families seek refuge in the Northern Territory and that community and family support services in my electorate are called on to alleviate the burdens of maintenance evasion in the southern cities and States. This Bill will do much to alleviate the economic need of single parents to abandon their established home environment in other States and will minimise the distance factor in the pursuance of maintenance payments. It should be recognised that what this Government will be able to achieve through this and the complementary legislation to which I have referred is to encourage a significant shift in community and legal values in the settlement of maintenance orders and the responsibilities of non-custodial parents towards their children.

Criticisms have been levelled against aspects of the legislation, which seeks only to ensure that non-custodial parents assume their responsibilities under the new child support scheme. Those criticisms reveal a disgusting attitude, in my view, which condones child deprivation which is all too apparent under the existing maintenance system. The Government is facing up to its responsibilities to the children of this nation. While I note that the Opposition supports the Bill, through amendments moved by the honourable member for Bradfield it has made a number of assertions in relation to the objectives of this Government in the area of social reform. I point out that the performance of this Government in the area is in stark contrast to the record of the Opposition and the baseless assertions of the honourable member for Bradfield.

The facts are that under the previous Government the real disposable incomes of low income families declined by 5.5 per cent for a beneficiary couple with four children and by 4.2 per cent for a sole parent pensioner with two children. As a result, the number of children in poverty more than doubled under the previous Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what Gerry Hand says.

—I will repeat that for the benefit of the honourable member opposite. The number of children in poverty more than doubled under the previous Government. The fatuous claims made by the Opposition in this area need to be revealed for what they are. At the same time, the additional pensioner benefit for children fell by about 32 per cent in real terms between 1975-76 and when this Government first came to power in 1983. That is the record of the Opposition when it was the Government of this country. The value of this payment has now increased by about 59 per cent in real terms since this Government came to power, or by 102 per cent for children aged 13, 14 or 15. That is this Government's record and it contrasts with the ridiculous claims made by the Opposition and with its record in government.

SPEECH.PARA: While the Government has concentrated on improving assistance for low income families, other families have benefited from the three rounds of income tax cuts made since March 1983. For example, a single taxpayer with no dependants and earning $200 a week will have gone from paying $34 a week in March 1983 to $25 a week in July 1987. A taxpayer earning $400 a week will have gone from paying $98 a week to $83 a week.

Since coming to office this Government has created more than one million jobs at more than twice the rate of the Western industrialised world and at four times the rate of the Fraser-Howard Government. So much for the claims of the honourable member for Bradfield and the Opposition. This Government, unlike the previous Government when Mr Howard was Treasurer, has thus far brought down unemployment to 7.4 per cent-and we are expecting further falls. This Government has introduced a family package of tax free cash assistance which directs $22 per week per child, and more for teenagers between the ages of 13 and 15, to almost 600,000 working families with 1.2 million children. This new family package has been introduced at a cost of some $500m a year. For a family earning $320 a week, with three children, the new tax free payment of $66 a week is equivalent to a wage rise of $93 a week.

This Government has brought inflation and interest rates under control. We are well on the way to getting inflation down to 6 per cent by mid-year and mortgage rates are now 2 per cent lower than they were at this time last year. We have raised the age pension by 8.4 per cent in real terms, in contrast to the sorry record of the Opposition when it was in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so.

—When Mr Howard was Treasurer, as unpalatable as it may be to the honourable member for O'Connor, the real value of the pension was cut by 4.1 per cent. Those opposite bleat and bleat about this Government's record. The public knows what the Opposition's record is. The public knows about the hideous performance of the Opposition while in government, when it had control of the treasury bench. Under this Government the pension has now virtually reached the important Australian Labor Party target of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. Those opposite could not come close to that figure.

SPEECH.PARA: Age pensions are indexed twice a year, at a cost of $1 billion. This Government has addressed the poverty trap problem by allowing pensioners to earn more income without their pensions being reduced. This Government has introduced the home and community care program to improve the choices available to elderly Australians in need of care and doubled the funds available for care of the aged and disabled in their homes. This Government has assisted 270,000 young families through our first home owners scheme.

I ask honourable members to contrast that record with the politics of hatred that marks the Opposition. The Opposition is concerned with setting Australian against Australian. The Opposition would abolish the assets test so that millionaires could get the pension. The Opposition would pay for the pensions of millionaires by cutting pensions for all sole parents whose children are over the age of 10 years. That was the promise of the Opposition parties at the last election. At the last election the Opposition talked about funding cuts that targeted child care centres and labour market programs and public housing. That is the concern of the Opposition for the public and social security of this nation.

Who can forget John Howard cloistered with his rich mates in the Melbourne Club, caucusing with John Elliott and coming up with the consumption tax? The honourable member for O'Connor knows all about the consumption tax. He did not want it but now he has to wear it. We all know what the impact of a consumption tax would be on the poor in Australia. I will quote what the honourable member for Bradfield has said in this regard. He is the person who has been trying to shoot down this Government's policies with regard to social security and social justice. It was a pitiful attempt during his contribution to this debate in moving the Opposition's amendments. The honourable member for Bradfield said of consumption tax:

Two things come into place. Firstly, those who do pay income tax would pay less income tax but the quantum of tax may not change very much. The second element is that those who pay little or no income tax must be thoroughly protected otherwise they will be the ones who will have to carry most of the cost, and obviously that is not satisfactory.
I shall repeat that last sentence:

The second element is that those who pay little or no income tax must be thoroughly protected otherwise they will be the ones who will have to carry most of the cost, and obviously that is not satisfactory.

Indeed, it is not satisfactory. What is the Opposition proposing in the area of consumption tax? Let us look at the electorate that I represent-the Northern Territory. The unemployment rate in the Northern Territory is some 12 per cent, the highest in Australia. The honourable member for Bradfield knows what it is like in the isolated communities of the Northern Territory. The honourable member is not present at the moment but he would recall visiting outlying Aboriginal communities where the total population is dependent upon social welfare payments. He will recall the cost of living in those areas. As I recall, he made statements about the shop at Kintore. He said he was concerned about the exorbitant prices charged in that shop, which the Aboriginal people at Kintore had to pay for goods and services. The honourable member for Bradfield would recognise, as other honourable members do, that the cost of living in the Northern Territory's capital city, Darwin, and to a lesser extent Alice Springs, is the highest of any major city in Australia. The honourable member should understand, therefore, that the cost of living in remote communities is even higher.

It is people living in these areas who would have to bear the burden of the Opposition's consumption tax. What would the Opposition do to help them? What would the Opposition do to alleviate the problems that confront Aboriginal people living in remote communities? What would the Opposition do to assist those who live in the northern suburbs of Darwin who have the backsides out of their pants? What would the Opposition do to assist these people? It has no intention of doing anything. We now know from where the Opposition intended to raise its $2.5 billion, which is the gap between what it promised during the campaign for the last Federal election and what it said it would raise in tax revenue. It was going to raise that amount from a consumption tax. It had absolutely no intention of doing anything for those who live in poverty in Australia.

The Opposition's record speaks for itself. When the Opposition was in government it undermined the social security system of this country. It increased the deprivation of those who live in poverty in this country. When the Opposition went to the polls last year, it promised to deprive such people even more, yet its members stand in this House and say that they wish to introduce a consumption tax. Last year, in July, in the lead-up to the election the Opposition promised to undermine the incomes of those people who comprise the poorest sections of the community. This consumption tax would redistribute income away from the poor and direct it to the rich once again. The Opposition's record speaks for itself. There is nothing it can say that will convince the Australian community otherwise.

We all know that the National Party of Australia understands the realities of remote Australia. We all know what Senator Stone said in another place and elsewhere throughout the country. On 3 December 1987, Senator John Stone is reported in the Sydney Morning Herald as saying:
It-
a broad-based consumption tax-
hasn't a ghost of a chance-it is bad economics and bad politics.

He understands that it is bad politics; he understands that it is bad economics, as antediluvian as some of his economic theories may be. He understands that it is the people living in remote areas of Australia who would suffer. To their credit, the members of the National Party understand. But, they sit silent on that side of the House because they form part of the coalition. The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) said:
It is not a National Party tax policy these days, or a Liberal Party tax policy, it is a Coalition tax policy.

I ask members of the National Party to tell us whom they represent. Do they represent those people in the remote areas of Australia who bear the higher cost of living in the country, or do they represent the interests of those people on the front bench of the Liberal Party who come from the North Shore of Sydney and the south side of the Yarra? That is what I would like to know. I have a fairly good idea of whom they represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are a long way from the bush.

—They certainly are; they have no concern for those people. The honourable member for O'Connor is from a bush electorate. He understands the problems of a consumption tax but he will have to wear it because his Party has decided that it wants a consumption tax. What will he tell his electors? He will say, `I'm sorry, pals, you'll just have to wear it. Don't worry about it; we'll undermine the social security system. We'll impose a consumption tax, but you'll be sweet because we'll be the Government'. Let me tell the honourable member for O'Connor that the shadow Minister for finance has got it right. It is bad politics, it is bad economics, and if that is the coalition's policy it will never get into government-thankfully.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by pointing to this Government's record in the area of social justice. I refer to the social wage, something which the Opposition does not understand and has great difficulty coming to terms with. The Economic Planning Advisory Council report of April 1987 analysed trends in social wage expenditure and its distributional impact. For the benefit of those opposite, the report states:
The social wage is defined to include outlays on health, education, social security and welfare, and housing and community amenities.
Real per capita expenditure on the social wage (total public sector) increased 6.5 per cent between 1982-83 and 1984-85.

How does this compare with the deplorable record of those opposite when they were in government? It compares with an increase of 1.6 per cent a year between 1978-79 and 1982-83 and a decline of 2.3 per cent a year between 1975-76 and 1978-79. So much for the bleatings from the honourable member for Bradfield. He has no idea what social justice means.

The Opposition has no comprehension of what are the needs of the poorer sections of our community. It has no intention of living up to its responsibilities if ever it is in government-God forbid that that will ever happen-and looking after those with the most need in our community. It has no concern for the people in my electorate, that is for sure, who would suffer horrendously if a consumption tax were introduced. If we imposed a 10 per cent consumption tax, what would happen, for example, to the standard of living of those people whom the honourable member for Bradfield said he is concerned about? As I said, the Opposition had no intention of increasing pensions had it come to power. What would happen? If it did not increase pensions, it would have no way of compensating those people who are the most deprived in our community. What would happen to those people who live in Kintore if there were a 10 per cent increase on food and other items as a result of a consumption tax? They would go out the door.

The health and community standards of the Aboriginal people in rural areas of the Northern Territory, which were of concern to the honourable member for Bradfield, would decline even further. We would see a shameless attack on the standard of living and the health care of those people who live in remote communities. Not only would those people suffer from this hideous consumption tax proposal, but those people in Australia who are on low incomes, those who rely on the social security system for support, would also suffer. These are the people that the Opposition is attacking by its proposal to introduce a consumption tax.

Let us face it: while the honourable member for O'Connor may disagree with the approach of his colleagues on the other side of the House, he knows that he has to fall into line behind the new leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Elliott. He knows that he has to fall in line because Mr Elliott and his cowboys who live in the Melbourne Club want to ensure that their ilk get the benefits of government, that they are able to distribute income towards themselves and away from the poorer sections of the community. Instead of supporting those most in need, he and Mr Howard want to get together and gang up on the honourable member for O'Connor, the shadow Minister for finance and those people who have rural electorates, and get the goodies for themselves. It is a shameful attack on the people of Australia. It is a shame that the honourable member for O'Connor has to sit at the table and accept the nonsense that is fed to him by the front bench of his Party. I suggest that, before the honourable member for Bradfield bleats in the way he did when he moved the amendments to this legislation, he should look at the record of his Party when it was in government. He ought to look at the promises it made to the electorate in July of last year and see what their impact would have been. He has no idea of what social justice means and neither has the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the honourable member for the Northern Territory that in future debates he should refer to the Leader of the Opposition as the Leader of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the outset, and in stating my support for the amendment moved by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), I should reiterate what previous speakers on this side have indicated: that the Opposition supports the general aims of this Bill and the package of legislation of which it is an integral part. Anyone who was listening to the remarks of the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) might be surprised to learn that. It seems that he had so little to say in support of the legislation that he spent his time attacking, in a disjointed, animated and somewhat inaccurate way, the supposed position of the Opposition parties. I guess that is a measure of his understanding of the legislation. It is certainly an indication of his appreciation of Opposition party policy.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the honourable member that the electors of Groom only a week ago had something to say about the relative importance of a consumption tax, particularly as it was not part of Opposition policy. The Labor Party candidate ran that line pretty hard. We will see the signs of this happening over the next several months. Members on the Government side will be getting up and attacking the Liberal Party or the coalition parties about a consumption tax that is not part of our policy. We saw them do so on the issue of privatisation some time ago. They attacked us left, right and centre, and made it an issue in the general election in South Australia. Not long afterwards, when it suited their purposes, they adopted the Opposition parties' privatisation policy and concepts.

The honourable member for the Northern Territory, to pick out one amusing little example, told us about the tax which was payable before the change of government in 1983 by an income earner on $200 per week. He said-and I have no reason to doubt him, although I have not checked it-that it stood at $35 in those days, whereas now it has been reduced to perhaps $29 or some such figure. The tax certainly has reduced on an income of $200. What the honourable member failed to mention is that under this Government's high inflation policies a salary of $200 is probably now worth $250, before tax, in the income earner's pocket, and that he is paying $50-odd tax on it. One can forget the relevance of an income of $200 five years ago; it is what the income earner has to pay in tax now that is relevant. That is the deception that is being practised on Australian taxpayers, because tax collections are up. They are up because of bracket creep, and it is a deliberate policy. So much for the honourable member for the Northern Territory. He did not say a great deal more on which I would care to comment.

Broadly, it is a valued principle that people should accept the financial costs of their own decisions to bring up children. Government should never have a leading role in influencing those decisions, even when marriage breakdown and ensuing separation and maintenance are not an issue. Clearly, it is preferable for separated parents to be able to provide for all children of their union, without the intervention of government. In that preferred circumstance, not only would the children be better off, but the parents could preserve their independence and integrity, which no government should deprive them of unless for good and proper cause. That being said, I fear some differences between the Government and Opposition emerge.

One cannot help thinking that, given the track record of the Government, the motivation for this legislation is not so much to reinforce individual responsibility, but is more to improve the budgetary outlook and the budgetary problems that the Government has created for itself. In other words, it seems likely that money rather than the well-being of children is the prime motivator. This perspective is reinforced by the apparently inflated estimates of savings which are indicated in the financial impact statement. Given the number of people involved, the savings of $120m in 1988-89 and $192.8m in 1989-90 seem to be very high. Perhaps the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) could tell us why savings are predicted to grow so rapidly in years subsequent to 1988-89.

It seems likely that inflation will account for the gradual end to transitional provisions which provide a floor in incomes at the level which exists prior to the adoption of this legislation. Surely inflation will not account for the huge growth in savings in subsequent years as indicated in the financial impact statement. As if to add fuel to the fire of my concern, the Government has made it clear that this legislation is a Budget Bill. While we cannot be certain that it will be so, the estimates provided to this House must be based on the best assessment of available information and not on the most favourable figures for the Budget or Budget projections.

In the past the existence of the social security system has very much acted as a disincentive for people to provide child support through maintenance. That is because it would have been literally impossible for many well-meaning parents to provide the same level of support as social security and other pension benefits. It was a terrible irony that a guise of irresponsibility might be required of parents to ensure that the Government looked after their children.

In the House several weeks ago the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) cogently demonstrated the dreadful effects of poverty traps on the welfare of Australian families. In particular, he referred to the hastily brought together family income supplement. That measure was simply one of the most notable attempts of the Government to buy votes at the most recent general election. The timely demise of Labor in New South Wales after a similar exercise in political cynicism suggests that the Government created that particular poverty trap for little political benefit. That view is more and more reinforced by recent by-election results around the country.

The fact remains that most Australians do not want a burgeoning welfare system and all the problems for individuals and families that go with it. It is trite to say it, but the solution to poverty is prosperity. At the same time it must be recognised that people value their independence, often to the extent that they would prefer to refuse money from the Government. That is still the case, I am glad to say, although much less so than in years past.

Nevertheless, a virtue of this Bill is that it would avoid the ever present risk of poverty traps. It allows some continued incentive for a recipient of a pension or benefit to seek increased income through maintenance. This additional income from private rather than from public moneys will offer savings to the Government as well as benefits to the parents supporting a child or children. The down side is that each dollar of additional maintenance income will reduce the payment of social security and related benefits by 50c. That will apply once the permissible earnings of $15 per week plus $5 per additional child are exceeded. These provisions are worthy attempts to deal with the problem of poverty traps which might make the receipt of maintenance from a former spouse undesirable.

Parts of the Bill consider maintenance income separately from income derived from work or other sources with a similar objective. The other side of poverty traps, which provide a definite disincentive for people to gain any sort of income beyond that provided by the social security system, is the desirability of work as well as of income producing investments. That presents a dual problem that this Government has really created for itself in any attempt it might make to reform the social security system and tackle the acknowledged problems of poverty. On the one hand there is the risk of making dependence on the Government so attractive that people seek rather than avoid such dependence; on the other hand, the Government pays for that social security system through taxation. High marginal rates of confiscatory taxation make the work option look less attractive. As well, the capital gains tax is into the attempt to make money by other entrepreneurial means.

It is because of this conundrum that any attempt to eliminate poverty through the social security system is likely to fail. In a very real sense, there is a danger that success in giving comfortable public provision will lead to the creation and extension of more poverty. These issues are examined by Charles Murray in his important work entitled Losing Ground. The conclusions of these and his arguments are equally applicable to legislation which we now have before the House.

Ultimately, the aims of the child support scheme will not be achieved just by this legislation. The support of children depends on wider factors, such as the economic prosperity of the country and the desirability of raising a family in the existing environment. Maintenance entitlements covered in this legislation are triggered only when marriages break down. This will happen for many reasons, and it is not the job of members of this Parliament to preach to people about probable causes. In the context of this debate, however, what we can do is ensure that we do not pass legislation which will unduly disadvantage those people who choose to marry and have children.

That brings me to the point that fundamental to the living standards of families in Australia is economic policy. Contrary to the rhetoric of honourable members opposite, economic policy is one of the great areas of failure of the Hawke-Keating Government. The Government's policies have maintained a level of inflation at least treble that of our major trading partners for most of its term of office. This high inflation policy is particularly felt by those doing the weekly shopping and seeing their disposable income dwindle. Anyone contemplating the rapidly receding chance of buying a new car on the sort of income most people now receive is feeling the pinch of government policies. People considering an overseas holiday for themselves or their families can see, in the rapidly expanding prices, the effects of this Government's policies. Anyone trying to earn a bit more money in a second job or by improving the capital value of his property can see the effect of this Government's policies as high marginal rates of income tax and capital gains tax confiscate more of the results of his work.

All of these consequences of this Labor Government affect the well-being of individuals and families. They have had and will have a detrimental effect on the happiness and well-being of many Australians. The family holiday, which gives people a real chance to relax and get away from it all, has become an increasingly burdensome drain on the pockets of Australian wage earners and small business owners.

No-one should pretend that general economic conditions are not the biggest influence on the social security system and that those economic circumstances do not affect the conditions in which children live. It follows that the payment of maintenance is best facilitated by the person paying for the support of the children having the adequate means of doing so. The savings provided for in this Bill can be made only if the person who will pay maintenance is not unemployed or dependent in some other way on the social security system. Honourable members opposite will, I hope, acknowledge that, despite the bluster of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), Australia still has an unacceptably high rate of unemployment. Five years of Labor Government have made little impact on the seemingly intractable problem of unemployment.

The Government talks a lot about its mastery of macro-economic policy. Having to get the macro-economic variables in order is the Trea-surer's excuse for every economic failure he has foisted upon this country. Furthermore, it is the Government's excuse for the present problems of Australian industry. However, this talk of macro-economics demonstrates an appalling lack of regard for micro-economics. The Government likes to ignore the details of economic argument because they are so unpalatable. That is a great threat to the good intentions of this Bill, which sets up a structure that is, in many respects, better than that system it will replace.

All of this will come to nothing if people do not have the means to pay maintenance. A significant part of the Bill will involve the assessment of maintenance of income in kind. This is clearly a necessary measure to avoid people circumventing the intentions of the Bill. However, the Government should keep it in mind that this will lead to the most difficult administrative task in implementing the principles of the Bill. The judgment of the value in kind contributions to the support of children will not always be straightforward-I doubt that it will ever be straightforward. Therefore, it will be a difficult task for staff of the Department of Social Security and a source of frustration for some beneficiaries. I acknowledge that these are probably unavoidable difficulties, and I can only urge the Minister for Social Security and his Department to be mindful of them.

This points to an element of the current package of child support legislation which is more important to the Opposition than it seems to be to the Government. In drafting its child support scheme, the Government has committed considerable resources in staff and money to its implementation. We will have an essentially bureaucratic system of maintenance payments which does not make provision for private individuals to accept their responsibility through private arrangements. Whilst the well-being of children must be the first priority of maintenance, this must be done, in my opinion, as efficiently as possible with minimal intervention by government when it is not necessary to a solution.

I remind the Government that the child support scheme will stand or fall on the economic performance of Australia during the remainder of this Government's term in office. The best option of child support is actively to foster the family as the building block of our society. In the absence of disincentives, the family unit used to be able to meet most of its own welfare needs. Sadly, this ability has been reduced over the past 20 or 30 years for a number of reasons which would take too long to canvass here today.
I would like to conclude with the worthwhile remarks of my former colleague John Hyde in an article published last year in the Weekend Australian. He said:

In addition, the State threatens the viability of the family itself, partly through marital legislation and partly through tax and welfare features that make family life an unattractive proposition or that encourage people not to meet their familial responsibilities.

We run the risk, in our well-intended legislative efforts, of going further down the road that Hyde warned us about. Whilst I do not have any easy answers, I do think that the problems are not being adequately thought through on all occasions. We deal with one problem at a time far too often, and although I would not ascribe that failing to the Minister necessarily it seems to be a failing of his government generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to rise in this debate to support the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements (Maintenance Income Test) Amendment Bill. This Bill is the third and final part of the legislative package to implement the Government's thorough review of the child support scheme. There are another two pieces of legislation-the Family Law Amendment Act 1987, which provides for assessment of child support in the court system, and the Child Support Bill 1988, which provides for the collection of child support.

SPEECH.PARA: The need for this important reform arises from the recognition of two important facts: first, over half of the 800,000 Australian children living in poverty are in single parent families; and, secondly, more than 70 per cent of non-custodial parents do not pay regular maintenance for their children. Clearly, children are the main casualties of marriage breakdown. Research done by the social policy and research department of the Brotherhood of St Lawrence, and by the Government through the social security review, has highlighted this alarming situation. In 1981-82 the incidence of poverty was higher for the children of sole parent households and for single parents themselves than for any other household type; 46 per cent of all sole parent households were below the poverty line; 70 per cent of sole parent households with three children were below the poverty line; and 91 per cent of sole parent families with four or more children were in poverty.

Between 1972-73 and 1981-82 the incidence of poverty in female headed single parent families increased from 38 per cent to 50 per cent and for male headed families from 16 per cent to 19 per cent. Between 1976-77 and 1985-86 the real disposable income of a sole parent pensioner with two children dropped by 2 per cent, and of a sole parent pensioner with four children by 5.6 per cent. Clearly, several factors contributed to this situation. First, the participation in the labour force by single parents dropped from 45 per cent in 1974 to 40 per cent in 1984. Secondly, there was a decline in the real value of the non-indexed components of government income support. For example, as Bettina Cass has shown, the real value of the family allowance declined by 29 per cent between 1976-77 and 1985-86. Thirdly, there was a failure by non-custodial parents to meet their financial responsibility with regard to their children.

The Government's commitment to ensuring that measures are taken so that no children need live in poverty demands that the child support system be reformed. Parents who have the capacity to pay will no longer be able to abdicate their responsibility to provide financial support for their children-a responsibility that until now has fallen to the social security system. As the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) has said, the scheme will make the legal right of children to be supported by both their parents a real right. It was disappointing to hear the honour-able member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) imply that the motivations for this package were merely budgetary. I think the underlying principle in this package deserves bipartisan support.

The Government's reformed child support scheme will, first, increase the number of families receiving maintenance; secondly, it will increase the level of maintenance; thirdly, and importantly, it will ensure that the maintenance is received on a regular basis. Effective maintenance collection has never been achieved in Australia-a statement confirmed by the estimate that 70 per cent of non-custodial parents do not pay regular maintenance. The establishment of a child support register which records all maintenance liabilities and effects automatic deductions from wages and salaries is the only way to ensure that children receive the support to which they are entitled. This is a collection system that does not depend on voluntary payment.

There has been some suggestion that automatic withholding should be imposed only when default in payment occurs. After careful consi-deration, the Government has rejected the suggestion. As the Minister has previously pointed out, the experience overseas is that in a vast majority of cases, default occurs within the first two years after an order for payment is made. If we are considering any stigma that attaches to automatic withholding, surely such stigma is greater if this requirement is applied only after default.

The incidence of marriage breakdown and single parent families is on the rise in this country. In the mid-1970s sole parent households constituted 9 per cent of all families whereas they constituted 14 per cent in 1984. The Government has an obligation to ensure that adequate maintenance is paid regularly by non-custodial parents with a capacity to pay. The Government will introduce a system of formula assessment to complement the present reforms in assessing the capacity to pay and what constitutes adequate maintenance. As the Minister has acknowledged, effective collection is only part of the problem.

This legislation deals more specifically with and amends maintenance income tests which are dealt with in the two major pieces of legislation which I mentioned at the commencement of my speech. The Bill implements a separate pension and benefit income test on maintenance income; it implements the imputation of capital lump sum maintenance and the imputation of in-kind maintenance as maintenance income; and it implements special protection provisions to avoid hardship being caused under the provisions mentioned above.

I think it is important to look at some of the problems which this legislation addresses. In-kind maintenance takes many forms. For example, it may include food provided, household items supplied, the payment of medical insurance, education and car expenses, and the like. I would have to acknowledge and agree with the point made by the honourable member for Curtin, who preceded me in this debate, that there is a real need to prevent people using these types of in-kind maintenance to circumvent the system. It is important to note that, unfortunately, not all of the families that we are talking about have the ability to effect in-kind maintenance payments. It would be unfair if those who are able to effect payment only by cash were not treated the same as the more wealthy in the community who are able to effect in-kind maintenance payments.

It is important that we look at the way in which we treat capital transfers either in respect of the transfer of substantial lump sum capital or in the context of the distribution of property following a divorce. There is a real need to indicate clearly in those capital transfers what is maintenance income and what is involved in respect of other forms of distribution.

The two shadow Ministers made very disappointing contributions when this Bill was previously debated in this House. The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), in his capacity as the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, unfortunately tried to embark upon a form of fear campaign that has characterised much of the debate over veterans entitlements legislation in the past. If we really look at this legislation we will see that the overall effect on veterans entitlements legislation is minor. The honourable member does himself a disservice by claiming that this piece of legislation will in some way heighten the confusion and fear out in the veterans community. I think it is clearly acknowledged by many members of the veterans' community that there is very little argument against this Government's record in this field.

It is appropriate that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) is at the table. Last week I attended a function in Victoria which celebrated the seventieth year of the Department of Veterans' Affairs or, as it was known for most of that time, the Repatriation Department. This function commemorated 70 years of service of this Department which commenced operations in King Street. By way of digression, on that occasion the Minister reflected on what a difficult task it must have been in those days-70 years ago-for those who were asked to oversee the implementation of the then legislation when they had nothing to fall back on. There were no precedents; they were starting from scratch.

When we look at some of the reforms which have taken place, such as this legislation, which is part of the overall reform of the child support scheme, again we reflect on how difficult it is even now, when we have some 40-odd years of history of a social security system in this country, to start not quite from scratch but to commence a system which tries to address a lot of inequities and inadequacies. The work and consultation that have preceded the putting together of this package have been very important. That importance is reflected by the fact that, in the main, the scheme has received bipartisan support. People should not use it to score points as it is a very real concern to those who find themselves belonging to single parent families or being a single parent.

It is a bit difficult to talk about the real impact of changes to procedures. The honourable member for Curtin, perhaps at a more partisan point in his contribution, described loosely the family allowance scheme (FAS) as being an exercise in buying votes. I ask the honourable gentleman whether he decries the redistributive effects that give many families a real chance. I note that he spoke of one aspect of family life being important; that is, the ability to take family holidays and the like. It is unfortunate that, for many recipients of the FAS, what we are really talking about are not luxuries that family holidays represent but bare necessities-necessities such as a new pair of slippers or a dressing gown for a child. Their ability to clothe children properly poses a very real problem. It is not just something in people's imagination. Many families in Australia require what people might term basic necessities. We need to assist them so they can get such items.

It would be remiss not to mention the fact that when the Minister for Social Security presented this piece of legislation to Caucus for its consideration it was an historic occasion because he included a social justice impact statement. That was very important because it not only gave us an opportunity to look at the financial implications but also allowed us to address the problems and to establish a strategic way of thinking of how we should implement different policy. The Minister is to be congratulated on providing the statement that accompanied this legislation.

It is well known that the Government is embarking on a more strategic insight into the way in which it delivers some of its policies. We are looking at the four main arms of the social justice strategy-that is, equity, equality, access and participation. This legislation attains those requirements in a number of ways. Regarding equity, the Bill will achieve a fairer distribution of social security expenditure by the income testing of all forms of maintenance. We must consider the dual part of the legislation. Social security entitlements will now be assessed according to the level rather than the form of maintenance received, which, as I said earlier, was unfair. In the past, only those in receipt of cash payments were subject to income test requirements. Now there will be a broader definition of what maintenance really is and we will be able look at the various ways in which maintenance can be received.

I look forward to the further developments of the child support scheme. The Australian community needs to acknowledge that there is a real need to address the problems of the many thousands of young Australians who are members of single parent families. It is remiss that on some occasions, loosely and rather quickly, some might dismiss single parent families as being single parent families not from necessity or circumstances beyond the control of the parent. The figures decry any notion in the wider community that there are those who become single parents because in some way it gives them the key to the door to some form of easy life. That is a rather obnoxious way of thinking. I do not think there is any evidence that that is the case. It is an unfortunate reality that many single parent families are the result of failed marriages and failed relationships. I think that we should not only ensure that we put into place measures such as those contained in this legislation that try to address the problems of those families but also put our minds to addressing preventive measures that ensure that we do not see a further increase in the number of single parent families. We should be looking at proper marriage education or, more importantly, a proper family relationship educative processes that ensure that many who go into relationships which are doomed to failure can at least have some access to programs that will assist them to be able to reassess whether those relationships are worthwhile. We must do that and start addressing that as a problem or we will be only plugging gaps with the sorts of measures that are before us today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) was quite in error when he took the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) to task for the statements that the honourable member for Curtin had made criticising the Government on this measure in terms of cost saving. He said he was disappointed that the honourable member for Curtin chose to talk about the Government's motivation in terms of cost saving. Whilst I would acknowledge the sincerity of the honourable member for Scullin in today's debate in his concern for families, I am sorry that he does not appear to be better aware of actions that his Government has taken in the last two years which have immeasurably increased the hardship of those attempting to rear children in one-parent families. He pointed out, quite rightly, a number of family assistance packages, but I am afraid that he fell into the trap, which is all too common amongst Government members of taking the Government's rhetoric at face value and not paying enough attention to the reality of a number of the policies that the Government has introduced. Later in my speech I will mention a couple of the initiatives that the Hawke Government has taken that have adversely affected single parent families over the last couple of years, but first of all I turn to the Government's rhetoric. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) stated in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: For too long poverty has been the traumatic result of marriage breakdown for children in sole-parent families. This Government is committed to ensuring that by 1990 no child need live in poverty. The child support scheme is a central part of our program to achieve that objective.

Today we are debating a Bill which is part of the child support scheme. The Opposition welcomes the thrust of the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements (Maintenance Income Test) Bill in so far as it will make maintenance collection a function of government in an attempt to ensure that more families will receive maintenance from non-custodial parents. The Opposition, however, is critical that it has taken the Government so long to act. This criticism has been made in several debates over the last three or four years. The Fraser Government in 1982 commissioned a report into the collection of child maintenance. That report was delivered to the Hawke Government early in its tenure in 1983. In other words, the report was not completed by the time the Fraser Government went out of power. The Hawke Government, for political reasons, decided not to proceed on the recommendations of that report. So it is now five years later that we are taking serious steps on the issue-steps that could have been taken five years ago.

All children have two parents, except where one parent has died, and this Bill does not apply in that case. The problem we face is that of the parent who walks away from the financial responsibilities to children and, I might say, to the custodial parent. I do not believe that the responsibilities of the non-custodial parent end just with the children. A number of the parents are not facing either of those responsibilities. If it is necessary that custodial parents cannot derive income of their own-as I said, perhaps because their children are young or disabled-non-custodial parents have an ongoing responsibility to custodial parents. That is probably a subject for another day.

I also want to make the comment-a comment I have made in previous speeches on the subject-that it was never the intention of this Parliament that the Family Law Act be interpreted in the way it was by the Family Court of Australia regarding access to social security benefits for those who become custodial parents after divorce. The relevant section of the Family Law Act which has enabled this situation to arise was not inserted to give automatic access to welfare payments. I suggest that any people interested in the subject look at the Senate debates on amendments to that section. They will find that the intention of the Parliament was to make the matter of maintenance fairer for the person paying maintenance. It was not meant to allow people to walk away from the responsibility of maintenance. However, the Family Law Court subsequently interpreted that section of the Family Law Act in that manner. We have now amended the Family Law Act to reduce the Court's ability to rely on the payment of social security where a non-custodial parent can pay maintenance.

It is unlikely that the sentiments the Minister expressed in the section of the speech I have just quoted will have much effect. He was saying that this is part of the central program to reduce child poverty. There are three groups of recipients of supporting parent's benefits. Firstly, there are those whose co-parent does not have the means to contribute to maintenance of the ex-spouse and the non-custodial parent's children-and the Bill specifically excludes those people from paying maintenance. I refer to people who are social security recipients. Secondly, there are people whose co-parents have the means but walk away from their responsibilities. The changes we are debating today essentially apply to that category of supporting parent's benefits recipients. Thirdly, there are those people who can afford to make financial contributions but who enter into private arrangements with the custodial parent. This is the category of people to whom the honourable member for Scullin was referring-the so-called middle class rip-off of the social security system.

I point out that the third group is unlikely to be in poverty. That is the group where the non-custodial parent, usually the father, enters into arrangements to pay school fees, retail store accounts and so on, but this has not been classified as maintenance. Therefore, the custodial parent is shown as having no income from the non-custodial parent and has been able to claim the supporting parent's benefit. In this case, the supporting parent's benefit has been an addition to family income. However, the people who have entered into that type of arrangement are not likely to be the ones whose children live in poverty, at least partly thanks to these very arrangements. So the second group I have referred to, where the non-custodial parent could afford to pay maintenance to the custodial parent for their children, but who make little or no contribution, is the group we should be most concerned about.

The position of sole parents in this country has been well documented for years. That documentation clearly shows that the problem of poverty in sole parent families is essentially a female problem. I have some figures, unfortunately not particularly recent but the most recent ones available, that graphically illustrate the comparative position of a sole parent. I refer for a moment to those people who are not receiving the supporting parent's benefit. Thirty-nine per cent of female sole parents are in paid employment, so 61 per cent of female sole parents are not in paid employment and presumably contribute the bulk of women on supporting parent's benefit. That 39 per cent of female sole parents is contrasted with the figure of 84 per cent of male sole parents who are in paid employment. That makes it quite clear that the male sole parent is in a superior position to earn income compared with the female sole parent.

The problem demonstrated by those figures is compounded by the fact that the female sole parent who is in paid employment will earn, on average, only 76 per cent of the level of income of a male sole parent. So with all the difficulties that come with being a sole parent, even for those who can remain in paid employment, the financial difficulties are sharper for the female sole parent. This was underlined to some extent-I believe inadvertently-by the Minister in his second reading speech when he made the statement:
It is expected that additional non-maintenance income-
that is, income earned by the custodial parent-
will generally be in the form of casual or part time earnings.

So the financial situation that custodial parents, particularly female custodial parents, have been locked into for a decade will not change in structure very much through this Bill, on the Minister's admission. The real issue of child poverty in single parent families centres on access to work, maybe also to education and training, by those people who are custodial parents. Many parents, male and female, who are capable of employment, will decide for a number of reasons not to go into employment, at least initially. For example, where the children are very young the custodial parent may well judge it more appropriate to remain at home caring for them. Under these circumstances those people tend to adopt the same characteristics as the long term unemployed. They have these characteristics to a more extreme degree because they are likely to be out of the work force even longer than the long term unemployed. Long term dependence on the supporting parent's benefit erodes people's job skills and makes whatever job skills they may have had-which, in the case of women, in times gone by were likely to be minimal-even more obsolete. These two factors reduce their employability. Further, their long absence from the work force makes them very unattractive to employers.

In response to that, the Government claims that it has been spending money-as it has-on reskilling people who are dependent on the supporting parent's benefit and on widows pensions. The Government however has introduced parallel policies which have been particularly cruel and which have added to the difficulties of the supporting parent. In the 1986 Budget the Government introduced a requirement relevant to the supporting parents beneficiaries and widows pensioners. I raise this matter because of the comments of the honourable member for Scullin and others in this debate about the Government's intentions and understanding of the problems it now addresses. I quote from a statement that appeared in 1986 Budget Paper No. 1:

The Government has decided to improve the administration of supporting parent's benefit and widow's pensions by more regular reporting, to ensure continuing eligibility, and counselling which will assist the recipients to find work and thus reduce outlays. From October 1986 recipients will be required to report to the Department of Social Security on their circumstances each month during their first three months on benefit and quarterly thereafter.

In debate on that Budget I questioned the Minister for Social Security as to whether that was in fact the Government's intention. If it was the Government's intention to provide the support of counselling to find ways to have people enter the work force so that they were no longer dependent on social security, the expense would have been fairly high. Nevertheless, this initiative, presented in positive rhetoric, was shown in the Budget Papers as a cost saving measure. In fact, that counselling has never taken place.

That initiative was only ever meant to check up on whether people were still eligible to receive their benefit. I noticed some ministerial advisers starting to write vigorously when I said that counselling has never taken place. I suggest that they check the Hansard transcript of evidence given recently by representatives of the Department of Social Security of this matter to a committee of the House of Representatives. This initiative had a policing function. I suggest also that the advisers check the transcript of evidence given by Department of Employment, Education and Training representatives. If there was to be a counselling function for those on supporting parent's benefit-not those about to be taken off the benefit-the Commonwealth Employment Service would have been involved. That statement in the Budget Papers of 1986 was news two weeks ago to the Department of Employment, Education and Training.

In that same Budget, the Government reduced educational allowances for social security beneficiaries. Whereas previously such people were eligible for the tertiary education assistance scheme, now Austudy, that eligibility was removed in 1986 so that access by social security beneficiaries to education and training was further hindered by a financial obstacle. In 1986, social security beneficiaries who wished to pursue education found themselves $23 a week worse off as a result of that decision of the Government-another cost saving measure.

I have said that that statement in Budget Paper No. 1 of 1986 standing in the Government's name was untrue. The Minister for Social Security may not have been responsible for its being there. It has transpired that the counselling proposal was nothing but empty rhetoric and was never meant to be anything else. When I questioned the cost of this additional counselling in debate on this matter, the Minister said that compared with the savings involved, the cost was minor. At no stage did the Minister indicate to this Parliament that the counselling function would not be undertaken, nor did he indicate that instructions were not given to the Commonwealth Employment Service that it would shortly have to counsel large numbers of social security recipients about their rights of access to job training schemes, because, of course, that counselling was never set in place. In that sense, the Minister connived with the untruth of the Budget Paper, even though he may not have been directly responsible for that untruth.

Of course, more recently, as a result of the May statement of 1987, all recipients of a supporting parent's benefit or widow's pension lose that benefit when their youngest child attains 16 years of age, regardless of whether that child is still in full time education, and regardless of whether the recipient is attempting to educate other children, for instance, at a tertiary level. That action is taken after only six months notice. In this regard, the Government has shown an extraordinary lack of understanding of the real needs of people attempting to rear children single handedly. The real issue of child poverty in this country-those categories of supporting parent's benefit recipients who will not receive additional support from the non-custodial parent or who will receive very little support-centres on the availability of child care and the refusal of the Government to consider support for alternative types of child care to that which is presently being funded; the almost non-existence of after school care for the children of those who would want to enter the work force and earn full-time wages; and the obstacles to access to education and training, a number of those obstacles having been raised by this Government. This Bill will force some parents to face some of their financial obligations. It will relieve the Government of some public expenditure. It will have little effect on child poverty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), who has just resumed her seat, admitted that some of the facts and figures she brought to the debate are old and out of date. I suggest that much of her contribution was out of date. She completed her contribution by referring to child care. She said that the Government had done nothing about child care. I remind the honourable member that the last budgetary allocation for child care by her Government, the Liberal-National Party Government, amounted to some $45m, when there were some 40,000 child care places in this nation. This year, this Government will spend $229m and will create 110,000 child care places, providing day care, all care, and after school care. It is quite amazing that the honourable member should make the criticisms that she made knowing full well that her facts and figures were not only out of date but in most instances, wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: No government has an easy task in attempting to address the many community problems that affect people. Most governments are faced with everyday demands from business and the community to address economic problems and to ensure that issues such as trade are constantly on the agenda. Governments are aware of the demands of local governments and people generally about issues such as roads. Governments tend to spend their time on such matters. But this Government, the Hawke Labor Government, has given a different emphasis, which has been targeted at people. It has been this Government that has brought down reports pointing out that during the past year there were some 800,000 children living in poverty. It has been this Government that has been acting directly, by direct funding to families, and indirectly to address that problem and to redress the difficulties.

This Government introduced Medicare. The Opposition wants to scuttle Medicare. This Government introduced the first home owner's scheme. The Opposition, the Liberal and National parties, want to scuttle that scheme. This Government brought about the fee relief for child care, increased the number of child-care places, and introduced the new system of Austudy. This Government increased the tax free threshold and changed completely, and restructured, the tax system so that it impacts less on low income earners. This Government has given a new commitment to solving problems associated with children in poverty.

There is no magic wand. It comes back to commitment and to money. It comes back also to a need to understand that governments cannot play the big brother; they cannot introduce policies and hope that in some magical way all parents will adhere to those policies. Certainly, the Government can put in place measures that will give greater purchasing power to families. The Government can overcome poverty traps. But it comes back finally to those who are responsible for children in this country acting for those children. I find it disgusting, when there are thousands of young children living in poverty, that approximately 70 per cent of non-custodial parents make no contribution whatsoever to the maintenance of their children. Hundreds of thousands of families in this country suffer because non-custodial parents-regrettably usually of the male species, the man, the husband, the father-make no contribution whatsoever towards the maintenance of their children. This is not new; it is not something that has happened in 1988. It has been going on for years and years.

What did the honourable member for Moncrieff ever do in the Senate or in this place to solve the problem? What did the Liberal-National Party coalition she represents ever do to try to solve the problem? They were not game. We cannot win on this issue. The moment we start trying to make people pay their way we come up with the rough cases. We almost need the wisdom of Solomon to address some of these difficulties. I can give case after case of the sorts of problems that exist. For example, there is the problem where the husband, the father, is not only committed to paying maintenance, but also has forgone the house-he has left the house and given it up-and finds that the wife, in many cases the ex-wife, has a relationship with someone else and is getting some sort of sustenance or maintenance in a cash or kind form and she is also getting maintenance from the father and benefits from the system. That is the sort of problem we face. There are cases where men on considerable wages, who live in prosperity, just walk away from their families. I take the point from the honourable member for Moncrieff and I agree with her that it is the women and children who suffer because that man simply does not take up that responsibility. But what did her Government ever do? Nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you ever do?

—This is the Government that has moved. This is the Government that introduced the Child Support Act. This is the Government that addressed the problem through the family law system. This is the Government that is ensuring that fairness and justice prevail, that people first of all have a responsibility to try to get assistance from other quarters before they come to the welfare system and say, `Give me, give me, give me'. This is the Government that is now introducing legislation that says we will take into consideration maintenance in kind. We know that for years there has been a presentation of poverty when in fact there have also been major capital transfers, there has been the availability of a house, there has been payment of educational allowances and there has been payment of medical insurance. In some cases these things are hidden. I do not deny anyone the right to receive that sort of assistance because it gives them a better quality of life, but it takes a government with guts to say, `Let's do something about it and make sure that the recipients, first and foremost, carry out their responsibility to try to get their maintenance and sustenance from those who ought to pay'.

SPEECH.PARA: What did the Opposition do when in government? Nothing. Opposition members can criticise us now, but for years they knew that the problems were there and they did not bother to act. It has been this Government that has ensured that a system is put in place that will officially collect maintenance from the non-custodial parent based on the ability to pay. This is the Government that has decided that it will ensure that those who have children accept an ongoing responsibility to those children, given the capacity to carry out that responsibility. This is the Government that has said that it understands that family breakups will continue but that they shall not always be a burden on the welfare system and therefore on the taxpayers unless it is clearly shown that the custodial parent cannot pay or for whatever reason-and there can be many reasons-it is impossible to collect that maintenance. But we are going to try. This has been happening in this legislature now for some months as this Government bites the bullet to try to rectify a gross problem, a problem that has affected 800,000 children across this nation, hundreds of thousands of families and hundreds of thousands of women. There is case after case, but for every case where clearly the husband is in the wrong one can throw up a case where the wife has done the wrong thing too. As I said, we need the wisdom of Solomon sometimes to rectify these problems, but we are trying.

While I accept the role of the Opposition to criticise, I believe that criticism should be constructive. That criticism should also have a theme within it that says credit should be given where credit is due. It amazes me that people such as the honourable member for Moncrieff get up and bash away, saying that nothing has been done, when in fact so much has been done. Let her say whether she stands by the Opposition's policy of getting rid of Medicare. That Medicare system is bringing a new quality of life to the health care of something like two million Australians, the millions of Australians she says she wants to help. Yet her own Party wants to get rid of Medicare. Let her say how she, as an individual member of Parliament, would address those problems.

It is not just a matter of giving cash. It is not just a matter of giving help in kind. It is a matter of ensuring that those people have specific problems overcome, be they educational, be they health, be they recreational. They are the areas that concern me. I personally believe that so much of the poverty in our nation has been covered up. We do not see it. Many people do not see it because of the wonderful work that is performed by groups such as the St Vincent de Paul Society, the Salvation Army, the churches and the charitable groups. They are bandaiding the problem and we do not see the blood. We ought to open our eyes and see how bad it is. Whilst we can see the quality or lack of quality of a house that some people live in, we do not stop to think enough about the other disadvantages they may be facing, the deprivation that is occurring at a frightening level in the areas of culture, sport and recreation, and in education. People in poverty do not have access to participation in all types of sport and recreation. They are the things that I believe bring down the person, and they are holding down hundreds of thousands of young people in this country. This Government is endeavouring to solve the problem. Whilst I accept the role of any opposition to argue and criticise, it is time that this Opposition came forward with some constructive ideas. I sometimes just give up on the Liberal and National parties here because they come up with nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do not get downhearted.

—The honourable member interjects. In the last election I had the highest increase in support in the nation. The response was fantastic when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) came to my electorate over the weekend. We expected 1,000 people to attend the opening of the Aboriginal Cultural Centre and 4,000 turned up. So I suggest that the honourable member should close her trap and listen. This is the Government that is acting for the people of Australia. This is the Government which has, by way of legislation and by way of its policies, moved to overcome the poverty that exists for so many. It is time the Opposition joined in supporting us in these measures instead of criticising and opposing them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements (Maintenance Income Test) Amendment Bill. It is a progressive step towards finding the solution to the problems facing what is fast becoming the most needy section of the Australian community, the children of broken marriages, or as we now seem to call them, the children of single parent families.
