It is a good thing for the parliamentary process to have the Cabinet Minister, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), admit that there is a serious drop in the living standards of the children in sole parent families throughout the country, and for him to bring in further legislation in a serious and what I believe to be a sincere attempt by him to overcome what has been an area of moral indignation and social comment by all sides of the Parliament. Yet action by either the present or the former Government has not been such as to halt the growth of this expanding social welfare problem. I take this opportunity to say that I support the child support agency which was established under an Act of that name. I am hoping that that experiment, along with the experiment of this Bill, proves successful in collecting maintenance from those liable to pay it without social, financial or psychological damage to single parents or their families.

SPEECH.PARA: During this debate-and the last speaker, the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), was a clear example of this-there has been too much toing and froing by both sides as to who is to blame. I do not include the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) who I thought made a magnificent contribution to the Bill and reflected her long time involvement in this area of concern. She has played a major role within the Liberal Party and in the formulation of our policies. I take the time of the House to repeat what the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) said when he quoted from Opposition policy:
We will amend the Family Law Act to restore the primary obligation of parents to maintain their children, while confirming that support will continue to be provided for families in need.

One does not need to be a great grammarian or scholar to understand that simple statement, which was put forward very forcefully. It should be remembered that the honourable member for Moncrieff, who preceded me, and the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), who will follow me, had a great part to play in coming forward with this policy-a policy which, it should be pointed out, was taken over by the Government subsequent to our announcement of it. I do not wish to make political comment on this except to say, along with our shadow Minister, that we should get away from the nonsense that concern and care for this problem resides on one side of the House. That is absolute and arrant nonsense. I hope that members of the public who are listening to it are aware of this.

The cold hard fact of the debate and the Bill is that the problem itself has not been fully recognised by the community or the social welfare organisations. In my opinion, their efforts have been put into the problems facing the breaking up of marriages and of relationships. It has taken a long time for the social welfare community and the political world to appreciate fully that the real victims are the children of broken marriages. It is only in the past couple of years that we have begun to see a wider awareness of how serious the problem has been.

Before I talk of my own district, on which subject my own party room is absolutely sick to death of hearing me talk, I should mention that I have not heard in this debate about what has been happening with this problem of children of broken marriages and the awesome acceleration of that problem within our community. Just when those of us who have been concerned about it for a number of years think we can see a solution, something goes haywire, because suddenly twice as many people are involved. Suddenly, the growth of social lawlessness amongst children, subteenage and younger, in areas of concentration of single family units, leads us to think that one of the real problems we have to face this time is not just money, cash, in-kind or whatever. But we have to have that. Our whole social welfare community has to understand that we have major public psychological problems to consider and confront. I have been made aware of this area, not because I have a specific interest in it, but because for many years now my electorate in Sydney has been one of the areas where there has been a major concentration of single parents. This is brought about because Cronulla is the only beach suburb within the Sydney metropolitan area on a train line. So single parents have brought their families to the area, thinking it is an ideal spot. For some years I was able to tell my colleagues in my own Party that we had one of the highest supporting parent benefit recipient concentrations in the whole of Australia. This has been changing dramatically and the number has dropped dramatically.

I should like to be able to tell the House that that has occurred because there has been a reduction in the number of single parents. But that is not true. The primary schools in my area, both public and non-public, still have an awesome percentage of children who come from such families. The problem cuts right across socioeconomic barriers. Yet Cronulla, this middle Australia suburb, with one of the most beautiful beaches and being one of the prettiest areas in Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —In New South Wales.

—In Australia-has one of the most serious problems of lawlessness amongst subteenage children. When gangs of children aged between nine and 12 years are bashing up adults and persons of their own age group, it becomes a very serious social problem for a district. This is no underprivileged area of Australia; this is middle Australia. The honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) referred to it. But, along with the honourable member for Moncrieff, I believe he missed some of the problems of middle Australia. I should like at this stage, within the context of this Bill, to say that we really have to start thinking of the problem not just of child maintenance, which is the subject of this Bill, but also of child supervision.
—After school care.

—After school supervision, after school facilities. The problems around Australia between 3.30 and 6 p.m. are immense. They are not acknowledged because they are not seen, because the parents are working. These children who are unsupervised have no guidance or leadership to bring them along the right road. People of my generation do not understand that, because that was not the case when we were young, some decades ago. Authorities, governments, oppositions and people in public positions cannot ignore this problem any more, because, if these children are allowed to go through life without leadership, without guidance, without some control or supervision, then the Australian community will suffer well into the future. Let us start thinking of the twenty-first century, starting with lawlessness amongst our young community.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Deputy Speaker, like you, I realise that one should not go beyond the confines of the Bill before the House. Although some who contributed to the debate have, I will not. While the matter of school child supervision must be closely related to child maintenance, one must also accept the fact that it is not a Federal responsibility, on the face of it. The use of school playgrounds and school facilities is a matter I am pleased to see the new Government of New South Wales addressing itself to. I think I am right in saying that. The use of those facilities is a matter that must be closely related with the Bill before the House. I would like to say that if we do not do that, it will be to our cost. It has been a shame that in this debate there have been instances of honourable members yelling across the chamber and accusing others of not having an interest and not having `done anything'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—We had this accusation from the honourable member who spoke just before me, amongst others. But I do not wish to get caught up at this stage in a political brawl. I believe the Minister has to be congratulated for several things. One is for bringing forward the Child Support Act, the Family Law Amendment Act, and this amendment to child maintenance legislation. I feel sure that he, too, knows that these pieces of legislation are not the final answer. All of us who are concerned know that they are not the final answer, but in my opinion they make substantial progress towards solving a massive problem. The honourable member for Capricornia, when talking about-quite frankly, I forget what he was talking about; maybe I am getting too old.
—Eminently forgettable.

—The honourable member for Bradfield has said that it was eminently forgettable. However, the honourable member for Capricornia was talking in broader terms about who had a concern for the problems. Let me assure him that on this side of the House we are close to our constituents. We are close to the problems that face us. I suggest to him that he may follow that track.

SPEECH.PARA: I get back to the Minister. I congratulate him on the Bill he has brought in. I congratulate him on his sincerity. I also congratulate him on what he has done because he has done something that I cannot recall having seen for a long time in this place. He has made his own ministerial staff available to Opposition committee members and other interested members on this side of the House to discuss and explain precise details of the Bill. I hope this is a practice that will continue. I hope that some honourable members opposite who have tended to scream about this subject may attend similar committee meetings within their own party structure because the problem before us today is not a Labor problem, it is not a Liberal problem, it is not a National Party problem; it is a problem that faces all of us in this House if we have a sincere concern for the welfare of our own community.

The honourable member for Moncrieff, who has, as I have said a couple of times already, a very wide experience in this matter, has shown that on the face of it things are just not what they appear to be. Any of us who have been connected with the social welfare scheme for the last 20 years, 30 years or, in the case of some of us, even longer know that this is the case. There are not going to be any glib solutions. Glib speeches will not suddenly wipe a problem away. Articles by me in the local papers in Cronulla and the Sutherland area expressing horror and concern do not get the children who are causing trouble off the streets. The fact that they have better maintenance, that they are better clothed and better fed, and that their mothers are less worried about them is no solution to what they are doing in those two or three hours late every afternoon. I have been disappointed that this matter has not been dealt with in this Bill which refers to child maintenance.

I wish the Minister well in his endeavours for I am sure that he will not regard this as a final answer. I almost said a `final solution' but I realise that that has broader connotations. Therefore, I say that I do not believe that the Opposition can stand condemned in any way for not showing an interest or a sincere concern. I support the legislation but I also support what the honourable member for Bradfield has brought forward as an amendment. It is not pious. It is not pompous. It states facts which I hope will be addressed by both sides of this House in the continuing debate which will not finish with the conclusion of this debate today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The prime objective of the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements (Maintenance Income Test) Amendment Bill now before the House is to change the means test as it applies to the determination of the amount of supporting parents' benefits and widows' pensions payable to supporting parents. It proposes this change because of some earlier legislation passed with a purpose, hopefully, of increasing the responsibility assumed by non-custodial parents for the maintenance of their children. I have said in this House before, and I say it again, that the public policy objective of a tax system designed to levy taxes on the ground of capacity to pay, like the public policy objective of a social security system designed to assist families, should give adequate tax relief and/or adequate cash family allowances to families who support children. That adequacy should be tested on the ground of what is the cost to a family of maintaining children.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a lot of talk about it being the responsibility of parents to maintain their children. That is true. But it does not face the central issue, which is: How do we view children? Are children part of our community and the future of the nation or do we treat them like we treat all consumer goods and regard them as a total cost to the parent? If we do, let us look at what that total cost involves. A man called Loveridge in a study conducted by the Institute of Family Studies prepared some very interesting information. He estimated-I am using figures updated to December 1987-that it would cost a low income family $1,178 a year to maintain a child two years or under; a child two years to five years would cost $1,500 a year; five to eight years, $1,853 a year; eight to 11 years, $1,967; and a teenage child, $2,929 a year. They are the figures for a low income family with a very spartan form of existence. For higher income families the figures were significantly greater. Therefore, the cost of maintaining a child in 1987 dollars up to the time of the child's nineteenth birthday for a low income family would be $38,290. Loveridge's estimation of the cost for a middle income family was $59,740.

We have to ask ourselves whether that cost is to be assumed by the parent and whether the parent is to be required to make a choice between bringing up a child and thus incurring that expenditure and having that money available for a trip overseas, a cottage at the coast or a luxury motor car. In my view, to face Australian families with that choice is absurd. Our tax and social security system should provide full and adequate tax deductions and cash rebates in the form of family allowances that take account of the full cost of maintaining a child. However, the present system does not do that. We have totally inadequate family allowances-family allowances that this Government has failed to index. Whilst the Government has claimed it has reduced the deficit, it is reducing the deficit at the expense of Australian families and the children in those families. The Government is saving something like $1 billion a year because it is being so mean and so short-sighted about the importance of providing adequate family allowances for all Australian children.

It is true that in separated families there has been a total failure on the part of non-custodial parents to discharge fully the responsibility that they should be taking. In my view the means test that is proposed in this Bill should be designed in a way to ensure that separated parents take as much responsibility for their children as do the parents of intact families. Of course, that would not be necessary if we had a sensible tax and social security system that provided fully by way of tax relief or cash allowances for the cost of maintaining children because then maintenance above an adequate minimum standard for all children could be a matter left to the parents or, when there was a dispute, determined by the courts, with public policy being formulated on the basis of governments knowing that every child had an adequate support through the tax or social security family allowance system. That is not the case because when a family separates we quite rightly say that it would be totally impossible for a supporting parent to support children on the very meagre, mean family allowances currently paid to all Australian families other than those with the very highest of incomes.

If it is to be the responsibility of parents in intact families to pay out of their after tax income the cost of maintaining their children, educating them and giving them a good start in life, the non-custodial parents in separated families should be required to shoulder their responsibility at least to the same degree. If the existing means test were maintained, families who increased their maintenance payments, as those payments should be increased, would not relieve the taxpayer unless the maintenance paid was at a very high level. We have to recognise that, under the present means test, as it applies to the supporting parent's benefit, there is no reduction of the allowances in respect of children until the maintenance, assuming that there is no other income available to the supporting parent, is in excess of $46 a week for one child or $52 a week for two children. Under the existing income test, the allowances that are provided to a supporting parent for children-the mother's /guardian's allowance and the child supplement-would not cut out altogether unless the maintenance payable were at the rate of $114 a week for one child and $164 a week for two children.

The objective of the proposed means test, of the maintenance collection agency and of the change in requirements under the Family Law Act should be twofold: firstly, to help lift out of poverty children who are now in poverty and, secondly, to relieve families who are taking responsibility for the maintenance of their children of the tax burden that they are now carrying to provide maintenance for other people's children.

Clearly, the present means test applicable to the supporting parent's benefit would be totally inadequate to bring about any significant reduction in Government expenditure, so the Government has introduced a new income test. It has been sensitively designed to preserve work incentives by having a separate maintenance income test, distinct from the income test that will relate to other income derived by any supporting parent. The Government has reduced the threshold at which the pension starts phasing out from $46 a week for the first child and $52 a week for two children to $15 a week for the first child and $20 a week for two children. Let us look at that measure. The additional allowances payable in respect of children and the mother's guardian's allowance will not cut out where there is one child aged under 13 years until the maintenance payment by the non-custodial parent is $83 a week; and, for two children, until the combined maintenance payment is $132 a week.

I hope that when the Government introduces its formula for the collection of maintenance it will be based on non-custodial parents who are in the full time work force discharging their responsibility to their children to the same extent as parents in intact families and their children not being a charge on the public purse. I hope, therefore, that the non-custodial parent in the full time work force, with one child, will be required under the formula to pay maintenance of not less than $83 a week. That will do two things. It will relieve the public purse of the costs of maintaining those children. Furthermore, it will massively assist the families of those children in lifting the children out of poverty.

Unless that happens, the Government will not make the projected savings. As I understand the figures, a large expense is incurred on the supporting parent's benefit. The total amount is of the order of $1.8 billion a year but, of that, $1.3 billion or $1.4 billion is the cost of providing the supporting parent with a pension equivalent to the age pension, the widow's pension or the unemployment benefit. All that happens is that the supporting parent becomes entitled to the unemployment benefit without being subject to a work test. The reason she is not subjected to a work test is that she has children in her care. The former supporting spouse, the former husband, is relieved of the responsibility of supporting his wife. He loses the $1,030 spouse rebate, but he does not have to feed or clothe his wife or, under the present arrangements, with the inadequate maintenance collection system we have had up to now, provide much for his children. He has the same income that he had when he had his wife and child or children in the same household, with the exception of that $1,030.

That $1.4 billion will still go to the supporting mother as a child carer's allowance or mother's allowance, which is payable to a separated family but not to an intact family, to whom we give only $1,030. So the amount that this scheme would potentially save is about $500m. That would relate to the supplements that are paid in respect of children of supporting parents. I question the Minister's figures. I have been very pleased to have spoken with his staff and to have had some explanation of them, but I just do not believe that the public purse will make the projected savings unless there is a formula that achieves the objectives that I have outlined.

I want to draw to the attention of the House the comparison of a family on approximately average weekly earnings with two children. I approximate average weekly earnings at the moment to about $25,000 a year. That family, with two children, living together in a happy family home, would be liable to pay tax of $6,001, reduced by the $1,030 spouse rebate and increased by the Medicare levy of $313, increasing the family disposable income and in effect reducing the net overall tax liability by $664, being the universal family allowance payable to the majority of families. So that family would have a disposable income of $20,380. Let us say that the family separates and the non-custodial parent pays no maintenance. The non-custodial parent is the one who is earning $25,000 a year, so he pays tax of $6,001 and the Medicare levy of $313. He has a disposable income of $18,686. What happens to his wife, the mother of his children, and to his children? They receive the basic supporting parent's benefit of $6,053, guardian's allowance of $626, a child supplement of $2,294 and the ordinary family allowance of $664. That gives a total disposable income available to the mother and her two children of $9,637. The total disposable income of that group, albeit that they are not living together, is $28,323 as compared with the disposable income available to the intact family of $20,380. So the separated family is $7,943 a year better off.

My concern is that public policy is not treating families with children in a fair and equitable fashion. It is not giving sufficient allowances for children to the intact family. Let us look at the break-up of that $7,943. Of that $6,053 is the single parent benefit. The spouse has left home or been kicked out; she would get a job but she is not able to do so. Because she is not cohabiting with someone else she is eligible for unemployment benefit. Her husband loses the spouse rebate, $830 of which is applicable to the adult spouse. Therefore $5,223 of that additional cost could be regarded as the benefit payable to the adult separated spouse. That is $523 more than the allowance we make to a husband who supports a dependent spouse or a wife who supports a dependent husband. One reform which would restore some equity would be to allow to any spouse who supports another spouse a tax rebate of the same amount that that person would get if he or she went onto the unemployment benefit.

In the few minutes that remain to me I turn to the benefits that go to the children. The separated family gets a guardian's allowance of $626 and the child supplement of $2,294, an additional $2,920, which is reduced, perhaps, by $200 of the spouse rebate. Therefore a family is $2,720 better off in respect of the well-being of the children if it is separated. I believe that the intact family should receive assistance at least equal to that $2,720. I believe that it is imperative that some action be taken to ensure that this occurs. I also refer to the situation that occurs as maintenance payments are increased. In the case of a family on $25,000 a year, if the maintenance payments were at the level at which the benefits to the children cut out, the dependent mother's total income would be in excess of $13,500, whereas the father's income would be $11,000. This compares with the situation where there is no maintenance paid and the separated spouse receives an income of only $9,637. So the effect of requiring maintenance orders is to improve the standard of living of parents in--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable members have noted, the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements (Maintenance Income Test) Amendment Bill is the third and final piece of legislation for the implementation of stage 1 of the child support scheme. The child support scheme is accepted by all political parties as a major step forward in providing secure income to sole parents and ensuring a fair and equitable system of maintenance assessment and collection. I want to acknowledge, particularly while the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) is in the House, the support of the Opposition for the scheme. In Australia we have had a reasonably long tradition of a practical and realistic approach to family law reform which has been brought about in a non-partisan way. Particularly since the current Opposition spokesperson for social security, the honourable member for Bradfield, took over responsibility for the Opposition's approach on child support the tradition has continued in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: Each of the three pieces of legislation has been somewhat complex. I understand the difficulty that oppositions have with such legislation and I appreciate the very considerable time that the honourable member for Bradfield and his staff have given to grappling with this legislation and, I suppose, in a biased way arriving at a fair and balanced assessment of it. I thank very much all honourable members opposite for the work that has been done and I particularly appreciate the contributions by them, both in this debate and in preceding debates. One thing that has characterised the debate on this legislation-apart from its somewhat less than partisan quality-has been the genuineness of the contributions made by so many individual members, both in this House and in the other place. In this area of reform there is a sense in which every individual feels that he or she has, perhaps, a somewhat extra interest in or more knowledge of what is being debated because of his or her own experience. The genuineness of the contributions is very much appreciated.

The Opposition amendment to the second reading is a tactic which has become a pattern with social security legislation. Opposition members do not oppose the legislation but move amendments to the second reading which are completely irrelevant to the Bill before the House. In this case the Opposition's amendment is even worse than its previous examples of this tactic in that it is tendentious and, in places, simply wrong. I want to turn to the facts in relation to children in poverty, not only for the purposes of this debate but also for the purposes of a broader public debate. I refer particularly to clause 1 of the amendment, which talks about the increasing number of Australian families living below the poverty line and bearing the brunt of unemployment, including an additional 165,000 children. It would be simple enough to say that there are now 50,000 fewer children of unemployment beneficiaries than there were in 1983. I think it is important to look more systematically at the facts of the situation, particularly going back to the period of the previous Government.

In 1976, before the Howard-Fraser Government had commenced hacking into the living standards of the poor of this country, there were 372,000 children of pensioners and beneficiaries. At that time payments for each child were 15 per cent of the married rate pension. Over the seven years of conservative rule the number grew by 50,000 children every year from 1976 to 1982. I ask all honourable members to recognise the horror of that reality-that during those six or seven years of conservative rule 50,000 children of pensioner and beneficiary families were being added to that figure every year. In 1982-83 that conservative coalition Government destroyed the labour market resulting in a massive 150,000 children being added to the numbers of pensioner and beneficiary families. So over the seven years of the Opposition's period in office 410,000 children were added to the social security system. Their families were forced onto dependency on pension or benefit.

While those numbers were escalating, the then Government slashed income support available for those children. In 1977 payments for children were 15.2 per cent of the married rate pension. By 1983 this figure had fallen to 11.1 per cent of the married rate pension and over that period the real value of the married rate pension had also fallen. Keeping in mind the reality of both the massive increase in numbers and the decline in the real value of additional payments for children, what is the Government's record in comparison? We inherited a situation where in 1983 781,800 children were dependent on social security. We have reduced that number. In February this year 779,100 children were dependent on pension or benefit. We have, of course, cut the number of children in pensioner and beneficiary families, although I concede by nowhere near the numbers that we would like to see. So although the level has remained roughly the same during the period that we have been in government there has been a decline in the last few month's. We have had to deal with those massive numbers and the costs that are involved in sustaining a social security budget of which such high proportions go into the support of pensioner and beneficiary families.

Child payments in respect of the married rate pension have increased from 11.1 per cent in 1983 to 12 per cent in 1984, 12.6 per cent in 1985, 13 per cent in 1986 and 14.1 per cent in 1987 for children under 13 years of age and to 17.2 per cent for children aged 13, 14 and 15. So, in each year that we have been in government we have made some improvement in the level of payment despite the massive numbers of children in pensioner or beneficiary families. No matter how difficult the circumstances have been-we have had some extraordinarily difficult Budgets-we have maintained this priority.

Of course, as honourable members will be aware, the Government has made a commitment to achieve, for the first time in the history of family assistance in this country, the benchmarks of 15 and 20 per cent of the married pension rate and then effectively to index those payments so as to maintain their real value. When we hear discussion about child poverty within this country, I think it is surprising that it is not conceded more often how radical a change it is in relation to any child payment to achieve a benchmark or a standard against which that payment should be made and then a commitment to maintain its real value. We have not had that from any government since child endowment was introduced in the 1940s. So it is a very substantial change and commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not index the family allowance.

—Family allowances were a reform arising out of tax changes made during our period of government. The rebate for children was cashed out by the Fraser Government. In one sense, it was a transfer across to the other side of the ledger. It ought to have been obvious in the seven years of conservative government rule that the level of assistance would diminish each year unless there was a commitment to indexation. The previous Government had seven years to face up to that problem. Indeed, the Opposition had the opportunity in the context of the election campaign in the middle of last year to do so, when it made a very substantial commitment in relation to family assistance. But there was no commitment to the indexation of the real level of the family assistance that was promised. That is simply one criticism. Notwithstanding the fact that the honourable member for Bradfield has criticised the Government for failing to address adequately the problem of child poverty, sole parents would have received no assistance out of that package unless they were in the work force. Even in that massive package, there was not a cent for the vast majority of sole parents who were out of the work force. I think it is really quite incredible that the Opposition should have come up with a package along those lines.

SPEECH.PARA: I am suggesting that the Opposition's amendment is fundamentally based on untruths. It is based on a misrepresentation of non-facts. There is no factual basis to the statement that the number of children in pensioner and beneficiary families has increased during the period we have been in government. Quite the contrary, there has been a small decline in the number of children in pensioner and beneficiary families. But, in the case of unemployment beneficiaries, there has been a substantial decrease in the number of children in families in which there is no adult employed.

I think it is important to restate some of the principal elements of the Government's policies and achievements in respect of sole parents. This is an area to which we, as a government, have given considerable attention and priority. I think it could be said that sole parents need three broad areas of assistance. Firstly, they need adequate income to support themselves and their children when they do not have work. In answer to some comments that were made recently by the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), I think it is important for the public and for the honourable member to recognise that most sole supporting parents receive a benefit for a very short time. The average length of time that a sole supporting parent receives a pension is less than three years. I wish we could get that across in public discussion. I think we should make some bipartisan effort to get across the fact that people tend to be on the supporting parent's benefit for a period of crisis and, on average, for not much longer. I know that there are exceptions to that. But there is a mythology in the community about sole parents which makes it extraordinarily difficult for governments to provide, for example, the adequacy that is necessary during a period of crisis. Sole supporting parents need adequate income to support themselves and their children when they do not have work.

Secondly, sole parents need to have access to services to enable them to work. Most sole parents in the community are at the peak of their working lives. I think it is important to say that there is common ground between the Government and the Opposition for believing that the solution to, certainly, long term poverty for sole parents, or for parents who have been in poverty for long periods, is a more effective transition to work. Thirdly, there is a need for assistance to those sole parents who have not been employed for a long period and who need confidence and skills to obtain employment.

In my view the record of this Government in all three areas is a proud and significant one. We have increased payments to younger children from $10 a week to $22 a week and to $28 a week for children aged 13, 14 and 15. Of course, the Government has increased Austudy payments for 16- and 17-year-olds from I think less than $20 a week to more than $50 a week. We have increased the mother's/guardian's allowance from $6 a week to $12 a week-a 100 per cent increase. This allowance has been extended to all sole parent pensioners and beneficiaries. The so-called poverty traps changes of last year have been of major assistance to sole parents. The amount that they can earn each week before they start losing their pension was significantly raised. The amount that a sole parent with three children could earn was increased from $48 a week to $76 a week-a 58 per cent increase.

The earnings credited introduced in the last Budget means that sole parents who are just starting work or who do casual work will be able to keep much of their pension. We have dramatically expanded the availability of child care places and have targeted those places so that sole parents are major users of the child care program. We have made sole parents a priority group for the Commonwealth Employment Service and labour market programs. Sole parents are becoming major users of a range of labour market transition programs.

When one compares the Government's approach with the Opposition's position, the differences are indeed stark. The Opposition would decimate labour market programs, destroy the child-care program, shed its public housing responsibilities and cancel the pensions of every sole parent whose youngest child is over 10. This Government is about helping sole parents to live a decent life and to participate in the mainstream of community activities. The Opposition is about taking away their pensions and leaving them alone, with no pension, without access to child-care, without secure housing and without the chance to get back into a job after years of looking after children. With the Australian Labor Party, sole parents have a chance of living a decent life as part of the Australian community. With the conservatives, here and in the States, the future for sole parents is very bleak.

Let us consider the Opposition's apparent concern for the increasing number of sole-parent pensioners. As at June 1976 there were 137,900 sole-parent pensioners. After seven years of conservative rule, on 30 June 1983 there were 242,100 sole-parent pensioners. So over the seven years of government by the conservatives the number of sole-parent pensioners increased, on average, by 14,900 each year. Let us compare that with this Government's record. On 30 June 1983 there were 242,100 sole-parent pensioners. On 30 June 1987 there were 266,900 sole-parent pensioners. In that four years the average increase has been 11,200, compared with 14,900 under the conservatives. The very good news is that in the year from June 1986 to June 1987 the number of sole-parent pensioners fell. Just as we did with the unemployment benefit, firstly, we slowed the growth in numbers that occurred under the conservatives and now we are actually bringing them down. For the first time in history, in 1986-87 the number of sole-parent pensioners fell. I will repeat that: for the first time in history, in 1986-87 the number of sole-parent pensioners fell. That was not because of any change to age of the qualifying child. That decision had not been implemented on 30 June 1987. The reduction was because of the jobs which this Government has created, the strong support to ordinary Australian families provided by the Government, and our effective administration of the social security system.

The honourable member for Bradfield, in a piece of sophistry rarely equalled in this House, complained that in the years 1980 to 1986 the proportion of unemployed people with children increased from 37 per cent to 46 per cent. He added that most of those years were years of Labor government. What he did not say was why this occurred. It occurred because of the savaging of the Australian labour market by the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in 1982. The honourable member for Bradfield and the House should never forget that terrible year-our only year of negative growth since the Second World War, a year when 300,000 were thrown out of jobs and onto the scrap heap of the conservatives failed economic policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a record drought.
—A record drought. The facts are there. The social security system was literally breaking down under the weight of the numbers going onto the unemployment benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take only a moment of the House. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), in his comments when closing the second reading debate, referred to the growth of numbers of sole parents under the Fraser Government. It should be noted for the record that there was a significant growth. That took place as a result of the passage of the Family Law Act which was introduced during the period of the Whitlam Government. These simple facts ought to be remembered. It was not government policy then deliberately to increase the number of sole parents, but one of the obvious outcomes of the passage of the family law legislation was that divorces became easier to obtain. Consequently, there had to be a growth in the numbers of single parents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I do not want to delay the House either but I must say that I concede that in some respects what I would describe as extreme inequity in the relative positions of non-custodial and custodial parents was an unanticipated and unintended consequence of changes to family law. What this Bill is about, along with the other pieces of legislation, is dealing with that massive inequity which has resulted in tremendous poverty amongst sole parents and particularly in the growth of a very large number of children who, by any stretch of the imagination, could be described as being in poverty. It is those realities and inequities and that scandal of child poverty that the Government is seeking to address.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

In his absence, the Minister for Trade Negotiations, Mr Duffy, will be the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.
