He will return on 19 April. The Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, will perform Mr Morris's duties in his absence, with the Minister for Employment and Education Services, Mr Duncan, representing him in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, as a matter of courtesy, I inform the House also that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, will be absent from Question Time today on Government business. Questions normally addressed to Mr Willis should be directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Holding.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister and I refer him to the explicit promise given in his 1987 election policy speech:

QUESTION.PARA: By 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty.
Does the Prime Minister still stand by that promise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. I made it quite clear in the very considerable media work I did straight after the release of the policy speech that what I was conveying was the fact that as a result of the decision of the Government no Australian child need live in poverty by 1990. I made the obvious fact clear that no Australian government and no Australian Prime Minister could ensure a situation that, the money having been provided as a result of the most significant decision ever taken by any government in the history of this country to deal with this problem-and I shall come in a moment to the dimensions of what the Government has done-an individual parent with responsibility would not misuse that money. If this poor, pathetic collection on the Opposition side of the House gather some comfort from that fact, it is indeed a measure of the depths to which they have descended.

ANSWER.PARA: I proceed to give the Leader of the Opposition and the House a reminder of the dimension of what has been done by the Government in this regard. It is this: A parent will receive at that level of low income units an amount of $22 a week tax free. The import of that may be adjudged by this simple statistic: If one takes a low income family unit of that type with a $320 a week income with three children, the $66 that family will receive tax free is equivalent to a wage increase of $93 a week. That is an indication of the dimension of the initiative undertaken by this Government, an initiative that will be improved upon between now and 1990. I repeat, therefore, that as a result of this historic and quite unparalleled initiative, which is infinitely beyond anything that would have ever occurred to the imaginations of Opposition members during the great period that they were in office-throughout which period the basic problem accumulated, by the massive growth in unemployment that flowed as a result of the coalition's policies-the fact is that by 1990 no Australian child need live in poverty.

I say also that it would be my hope, and I trust a hope shared by the Leader of the Opposition, that the sense of responsibility on all parents who will be in receipt of this very generous allowance, that no child need live in poverty by 1990 will be mirrored by the fact that overwhelmingly that will be the case because those in receipt of this money will expend it properly.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FITZGERALD COMMITTEE TO ADVISE ON AUSTRALIA'S IMMIGRATION POLICIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Will the Minister inform the House whether he has received any documents, and if so what documents, from the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies? Will he further inform the House of the present state of that report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Early last week I received from Dr FitzGerald, the Chairman of the Committee, a draft working copy of the report. At that time Dr FitzGerald made it clear that the final report would consist of three basic documents: the report itself and a list of recommendations, and two appendices. Those appendices would consist of reports commissioned by the Committee about areas relevant to a consideration of the immigration program and administration, some of which have been released already, and a model Bill which is designed to assist discussion concerning aspects of policy recommendations and which, although subject to rewriting, have previously been released in two workshops. Dr FitzGerald is currently out of Australia. He has indicated that he hopes to be in a position to provide me with all documentation relevant to the report within a fortnight of his return. I would hope to be in a position to table the report towards the end of May.

ANSWER.PARA: I should also like to take this opportunity to point out that it is clear from the working draft that the Committee has examined a wide range of issues. The significance of the report will be that it will provide a focus for an informed and rational debate on a range of issues that go to the formulation of an effective immigration policy. In this context I might add also that I think the Press release issued today from the office of the Leader of the Opposition, suggesting that the final report will not accurately reflect the submissions and consultations with the Committee, is to be regretted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—Because it can in no way be seen as a reflection of the work done by the Committee. It is regrettable that the Leader of the Opposition should choose to make such a statement on the basis of an inaccurate Press report. I suggest that had he consulted with his shadow Minister, he would have been much more accurately advised.
—He does not have to remain silent until you table the report.

—I realise that shadow Ministers are under some constraints; they have all got gags on them. The comment made by the Leader of the Opposition is not only irresponsible, but if it reflects on anyone, it reflects on himself, because he was basically more concerned to try to make a political point than to discharge what ought to be his responsibility on behalf of the Opposition-to see that there is in fact a mature, informed and responsible position formulated by the Opposition on this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: There seems also to be a view, expressed in various sections of the media, that the recommendations of the Committee will automatically form the basis of Government policy. Of course, that is not the case. It is the responsibility of the Government to formulate policy. This report will have no more and no less status than other reports that are designed to assist in the formulation of policy after proper evaluation by the Parliament and the community on the issues that they address.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to his previous answer to the question asked by my colleague the Leader of the Opposition. In view of the Prime Minister's rejection of the clear wording of the undertaking he gave to the Australian people in his policy speech, and I quote--
—Are Government members saying that the Prime Minister did not say it? I shall quote his words:
—Never mind, little boy. I should think that that just about behoves you. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: By 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty.

I do not know whether the little boy across the table wants to grow up but he pretends now that he did not use the words in his policy speech. Did he deliberately mislead the Australian people? Is this an indication of his sloppiness? I will wait for the Treasurer to advise him. I know it is necessary as he does not have enough wit or wisdom to advise himself. Is this an indication of mere sloppiness in his use of the English language, a sloppiness that is now illustrative and reflective of his own behaviour in his Ministry? If not, why did he make that clear commitment to the Australian people which he now says could never be kept?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the National Party, if I may put it this way, has been somewhat groomed for this question. We can understand his concern, as we can understand the concern of the honourable member for O'Connor, who has had a gag temporarily put around his mouth. What has the honourable member for O'Connor said to this Rambo of a leader? The Leader has said to him, `You can do what you like here in this House, Wilson. You can get in the gutter as much as you like here, but don't you dare talk about policy matters'. Why did he say that? The honourable member for O'Connor had said, `Look, John, I hold a safe seat, but the thing that worries me is Ian Sinclair's Party. It is quite clear on the question of a consumption tax. If you don't come to your senses on this, young John, we might be giving a seat back to the National Party'. Obviously, the Leader of the National Party is very unsettled at the moment after the Groom by-election. He is very unsettled because he has an unguided missile in the Senate who covets his position as Leader of the National Party. So in these circumstances it is not surprising that we are going to get a barrage of nonsense from the Leader of the National Party.

ANSWER.PARA: The question is absurd. Its level is a reflection of the very agitated state of mind of the Leader of the National Party. I refer him to the answer I gave to the Leader of the Opposition. I repeat: it is quite clear that as a result of the decision we have taken there will be no need for any Australian child to live in poverty in 1990. If the Leader of the National Party believes in a situation in which a power is given to a government or a Prime Minister to intervene so directly in the lives of every individual in this country that it will determine how those individuals spend the money made available to them, he may be able to make some sort of an issue. I have no doubt that on this issue the Australian people will treat the Leader of the National Party with contempt, a contempt that is deserved, and that on this issue of substance they will congratulate and give credit to this Government for the substance of its decision. That decision is unique. It is unparalleled in this country. I repeat: as a result of that decision, no Australian child need live in poverty in 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Community Services and Health seen a report in today's Melbourne Age that the honourable member for O'Connor is proposing a $3 billion cut in Federal grants to the States for hospital and health services? Can the Minister advise the House of the reasons for the Government's payment of health grants to the States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker--

—I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. I draw attention to your own request to Speaker Snedden on Ministers talking about Opposition policy when they know nothing about it. I believe the question is out of order.
—The question was not addressed to Opposition policy.

—It is true that it is difficult to know anything about the Opposition's health policies because they change from day to day. The first thing we might tell the honourable member for O'Connor, the first thing he needs to know, is that of the $3 billion that, according to today's Press, will be withdrawn from the public hospital systems in the States, approximately half is paid to the States for the care of pensioners in the public hospital system. There was no explanation of that. The remaining half is paid to keep down the cost to private patients in public hospitals and also to support disadvantaged patients.

ANSWER.PARA: In the fantasy world in which the honourable member for O'Connor lives, apparently nobody will suffer from this. The Commonwealth will save $3 billion; it will not cost the States anything, we are told, but, of course, it is going to cost ordinary Australians because they are going to have to find that $3 billion. It will not be found, in the Medicare way, in an income-related way. It will be found by flat rate insurance, which is much tougher on the less well off than on the better off. That does not finish the element of unfairness in the proposals because we are also told that there will be risk rated insurance. The Opposition will get rid of the community rating principle and people will pay according to their risk. This Government has always supported community rating because we believe it spreads the burden of health costs fairly across the community.

Let us take a couple of examples of risk rated insurance. Because women in their child-bearing years use medical and hospital services three to four times more than do younger women and somewhat older women, families would have to pay that massive increase to cover the risks of childbirth, so that proposal will impose on a family very much higher costs at a most vulnerable time. Again, it will clearly affect the old because a man of 64 makes three to four times the use of medical and hospital services a 20-year-old does. It will be a very heavy extra cost for elderly people.

The Leader of the Opposition has running around the country a series of loose-lipped shadow Ministers making policy on the run. Let me give the House one further example of the loose-lipped nature of the honourable member for O'Connor. The honourable member for O'Connor told the Liberal Party council meeting the other day that people would have private insurance cards which, unlike the existing Medicare card, would not label them as poor. I have a Medicare card here. I have looked at it and I can see no labelling whatsoever which indicates that anyone is poor. This loose-lipped member for O'Connor--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. It does not label him poor. He gets the best doctor and the best room, just like Paul Keating.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.
—He got his missus in the best room. He doesn't have to worry about it. He gets special treatment.
—Order! Is the honourable member for O'Connor aware that I warned him? I call the Minister.

—The loose-lipped member for O'Connor alleges that this card labels holders as poor. There is nothing on the card that does that. In fact, every Australian family in this country holds a Medicare card. The great advantage of Medicare is that as a universal system the card and its operation do not label people as poor; but under the proposal of the honourable member, in order to protect the poor and the pensioners from the very high charges to be imposed, they will have a card which identifies them as poor. We might call it the Tuckey poverty card. I suggest to the Leader of the Opposition that not only should he discipline the honourable member for O'Connor in relation to his loose lipped remarks about consumption tax, but he should also let him work out a health policy, rather than produce a series of loose lipped reactions around the country.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that 2.6 million Australians are living below the poverty line, and that 20 per cent of them are children? Is it also a fact that, even if the existing commitment to raise the family allowance supplement is met, there will still be some 400,000 children living below the poverty line in 1990? I ask whether this is the reason why the Prime Minister, after addressing the Child Poverty Conference in Melbourne last Saturday said, `How can I say at any time that no child will live in poverty?'.
—The answer to the honourable member's question as to why I said that has been given twice in this House today.

—Has the Minister for Defence seen a statement by the shadow Minister for defence that nuclear-powered ships should be considered for the Royal Australian Navy? Has the Government plans to introduce nuclear-powered warships to the Royal Australian Navy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen a Press release to that effect. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: Nuclear powered ships for the Royal Australian Navy is an option which must be examined. This will be the principal purpose of my visit to the United Kingdom and the United States in June of this year.

I should have thought that any Opposition spokesman on defence or foreign affairs who had available to him at taxpayers' expense an overseas trip might have done something about looking, for example, at the regional relationships we are establishing in the defence area, for which we have been quite unjustifiably criticised by the Opposition. If the Opposition spokesman is going to the United States, he might take advantage of talking about the many serious issues that we discuss with the United States when we as Ministers for Defence and Foreign Affairs visit the United States. To produce a Press release to suggest that his principal priority in visiting there is to examine an option for nuclear powered warships for us is an indication of the irrelevancy into which the Opposition has descended.

The shadow Minister might find out a few things if he does go to the United States. He will find out the very reasons why we do not have nuclear-powered warships in our own armed services. The nuclear-powered warships of the United States that the shadow Minister will see will be aircraft carriers of some 90,000 tonnes. Is it the intention of the Opposition to go for an aircraft carrier of 90,000 tonnes? Well, that would cost $A5 billion before one put an aircraft on it. So that will be an interesting option for him to consider, or will it be the Virginia class guided missile cruiser? That should be an interesting one for him to take a look at. He would be looking at about $A2 billion for a Virginia class cruiser. One thing he will find out if he talks to the people in the United States about the Virginia class cruiser is that that country is in fact moving away from nuclear powered options in that regard and is now constructing gas turbine cruisers to carry its new Aegis system, as witnessed by the Bunker Hill, which visited Australia recently. That is one ship that he could visit here and discuss without spending taxpayers' dollars to find out why the United States does not go down the road of nuclear powered ships.

The fact that the shadow Minister is capable of saying that this is his priority in terms of his overseas visit is an indication of the extent to which the Opposition has no control over its front bench when it comes to the discussion of issues that cost funds. If the Opposition is talking about introducing into the Royal Australian Navy ships of the class that require for a single ship $2 billion to $5 billion worth of expenditure before one even hangs something useful on them, that is an indication perhaps of why it is considering a consumption tax. Such a tax will not be known as John Howard's food tax; it will have to be known as John Howard's battleship tax, if the shadow defence Minister is to have his way.

Right across the board, whether it be the honourable member for O'Connor in regard to health policy, or whether it be the shadow spokesman for defence, the policy making of the Liberal Party is a complete and utter mess. It was once said, wittily, in this place that we had Tiberius on the telephone; what we now have is Claudius in a lift, stuttering his way up and down in Liberal Party meetings in Melbourne, trying to bring his front bench under control. It has to be said that he no longer has a front bench problem simply with regard to the consumption tax; he has a front bench problem in every single policy area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is it a fact that as of the beginning of March this year the Health Insurance Commission instructed all of its offices and staff that no information relating to the affairs of any person can be released to any other person, and that as a result members of parliament making simple requests, such as when a constituent may receive a cheque, are being advised that the information cannot be provided? I ask the Minister: As this new policy is in direct contradiction to the advice provided to the Minister by the Health Insurance Commission on 7 January 1988, has the Health Insurance Commission advised him of its changed interpretation of the obligation of confidentiality contained in section 130 of the Health insurance Commission Act; and, if so, does the Minister still claim to be innocent of any breach of the Health Insurance Commission Act?

—The only point I wish to make in relation to the question raised is that, because of the abuse at one stage of the hotline procedures which the Health Insurance Commission had put in place in relation to requests from doctors so as to facilitate the operation of the Medicare scheme-and there was some evidence that that was abused- we have introduced in relation to that hotline system methods of checking that the demands are legitimate so that no forms of abuse can take place. That is probably what the honourable member is referring to. If there are any more extensive guidelines, I will look at them. But we were concerned by that particular abuse of a system which was designed to benefit and help doctors, and we wanted to ensure that only legitimate and bona fide requests came through that system.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the Minister inform the House of the Government's position on the Japanese coal settlements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know what our position is, but it is pretty obvious that the Opposition does not. I read in the newspapers this morning that there is going to be another Opposition party. It will be a bit of a rush to see who goes to join Joh as Deputy, Senator Stone or the Leader of the National Party, given that they are such a good old team. It would appear that they are divided on this issue, as they are on tax. Before Easter I put out a Press statement on coal. I was very interested to learn that the Leader of the National Party and Dr Storey, a Liberal Party adviser, both put out statements backing the stand that the Government was taking. The Leader of the National Party is now reported as saying he did not put out a Press statement advocating intervention and a floor price approach. He is further reported as saying in the media that the Government should have got the producers together. That is the way he is criticising the Government now.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us look at some of this. This Press release that was not supposed to be put out states:
. . . the reported contract price of $2.90 a tonne was far too low.

The price is $46.90, not $2.90-and this mistake is repeated twice. This is in the Press release he is now reported as saying he did not put out. It came out on Saturday, 3 April, from Bendemeer, in the Sinclair country seat. If he did not put it out, I guess the farmhand put it out on overtime, on Saturday-he is a very clever farmhand, and he deserves more money. He got it to Canberra, got it boxed down here, and got it included in the Opposition Leader's documentary summary for the week. That is not bad for a farmhand up there at Bendemeer. This is the one that the Leader of the National Party is supposed not to have put out.

The second matter is that we have got to get the producers together and we have to intervene. The policy speech of the Leader of the National Party states that Commonwealth mineral export controls will go. That was their policy during the last election. I guess it is still their policy, although one cannot be sure. The Liberal Party policy at the same time was for the abolition of coal export controls. I do not know whether the Leader of the National Party of Australia is sticking to the claim that he put out this Press release or whether it was his farmhand who did so. However, it seems rather curious because he is now reported as saying that we have got to get the coal industry together although it is his Party's policy that there should be absolutely no coal export controls whatsoever. I am certain that Senator Parer would have that view as well. I simply do not know where the Opposition is on this whole question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now answer the question.
—Would the honourable member like to hear more about the Nationals, because they are really funny?
—You can talk about me any day you like; I don't mind.

—I suggest that the Leader of the National Party make up his mind as to whether he put out this Press release or not. We have made our position very clear. We are deferring consideration of the settlements because basically all the settlements are not in. There are coal contracts for 14 million tonnes of hard coal, 14 million tonnes of semi-soft coking coal and three million tonnes of soft coal. We want the whole picture before us before we take any decision about this matter. Both the Prime Minister and I have made the Government's general views known on the whole situation. It is now said that basically Australia has a commodity based currency. Commodity prices certainly are affected very quickly. Of course, what the Opposition has never been prepared to understand throughout the last few years is that because we are getting the lowest price in real terms for our commodities since the Depression this has had an enormous impact on our currency. That is what caused the very large devaluation.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of some economic theories, when one has a devaluation or a depreciation of the currency one gets some great advantage in terms of the prices received for commodities. However, when we look at some of the prices we are receiving it is quite obvious that we have not got the benefits of the devaluation we have had. I guess that one way of demonstrating that is that in November 1982 we were getting about 17,000 yen for a tonne of coal. Today we are getting something less than 6,000 yen for a tonne of coal. I have been saying that it is not just currency adjustments of course but a question of what the world market is, what the profitability of the Japanese steel mills is and also what the competitive pressure is. Quite frankly the Japanese steel mills play very hard and tough. The Japanese people, in other commercial dealings, do not hesitate to discriminate against Australia, whether it be in beef, sugar or other areas. I think it is quite appropriate for us to say something. I could further enhance that by pointing out that Zenchu, the big Japanese cooperative, has put out a most offensive video on food imports and the beef situation.

On the matter of coal, the Japanese steel mills beat their breasts and talk about commercial deals while on the other side of Tokyo Australia is being told that it will have to accept less money for the embassy site after a commercial tender process has been entered into. I am sure that my colleague the Minister for Administrative Services could have something to say about that. I believe that we need to stand up for our coal industry, say things firmly and deal with people firmly. We are not getting involved in commercial processes but that does not mean that we do not have an attitude. I do not believe that Japan will respect Australia if we adopt a craven attitude. We are quite firm. The Opposition is totally confused and does even know what it put out.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of the previous very tentative and tremulous answer from the Minister for Community Services and Health I refer a question to the Attorney-General. I refer him to the Australian Federal Police inquiry into the release of confidential information by the Minister for Community Services and Health and the honourable member for Canning. Is the Attorney-General aware that the Federal Police completed its inquiries and forwarded its report to the Director of Public Prosecutions more than three weeks ago on 24 March 1988? Considering the seriousness of this matter, can the Attorney-General advise when the Director of Public Prosecutions proposes to make his recommendations; and, if not, will he advise the Parliament later this day?

—I am aware of what the honourable gentleman says. I was not aware that the report had been furnished at the time he said. I will be seeing the Director of Public Prosecutions at about 3.30 today, so I will let the honourable member know by 3.45 p.m.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: FORMER EMPLOYEE

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security and refer him to the bizarre claims by a former employee of the Department of Social Security, Peter Sawyer, relating to such things as an insidious national surveillance plot, the imminent demise of the world as we know it and other allegations that have unfortunately caused trauma and fear for many people, particularly the elderly. I ask: Has Mr Sawyer ever produced any evidence to back up his claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that the honourable member for Capricornia does not have it on his own in having to deal with Mr Sawyer. I am sure that the answer I will give to his question will be of interest to many honourable members on both sides of the House. Of course, I am aware of Mr Sawyer's activities. He has recently broadened the base of his scare campaigns from activities related to social security to just about every topic that comes his way. If I may say so, Mr Sawyer is something of a snake oil salesman. He travels about the country offering up his version of the ills of Australia, peddling claims of political conspiracy, world government, takeover plots, hidden bunkers, the demise of hard currency, with nothing but his own soapbox to support these bizarre notions. He began his campaign by claiming that the Department of Social Security computer facilities at Deakin in Canberra were being used as some sort of base for a de facto national identity system to be used as part of a grand government takeover plot. I have previously outlined to the House the rather boring and mundane everyday purpose of the Deakin Computer Centre and have provided detailed information about the purpose and implementation of the Department's important Stratplan project.

ANSWER.PARA: Several groups of members and senators have recently toured the Deakin Centre. To my knowledge none has been able to come up with anything to support Mr Sawyer's allegations of sinister goings-on and bumps in the night. Even the honourable member for O'Connor conceded after his tour that he found nothing necessarily sinister in the building, its contents or the people who work there. That, of course, has not deterred Mr Sawyer, despite the fact that he has continually urged people to look over the centre in order that they find out the truth for themselves.

He has recently turned his fanciful mind to the overwhelming issue of automatic teller machines, asserting that the video cameras installed on some of these devices are part of the Deakin Centre plot to provide a video scan identity of almost every Australian. He no doubt subscribes to the Kit Kat conspiracy theory related to automatic telling machines-that these machines are operated by kindly little old women who sit inside them and respond to the demands of customers with either money or a chocolate bar, as the situation demands. Mr Sawyer, I am sure, is already conducting his own in-depth investigation into the complex issue of chocolate bars and automatic teller machines; but information from the Canberra Permanent Building Society indicates that these cameras have been installed on its machines in an effort to reduce the high incidence of vandalism. The cameras do not photograph every customer and have absolutely no connection with the Deakin Centre.

It is about time that those who give credence to Mr Sawyer begin by demanding a few answers of him as he has been demanding them of others. Just where is the hard evidence of his hysterical claims, apart from those in his own mind? Where is the evidence that Australia, as he asserts, is on the verge of a takeover by revolutionary forces, with established social orders and systems about to be broken down by totalitarian forces?

I think that all members of parliament have shared some concern about the activities of this person who does so much to spread this information. A resident of the country town of Narromine, west of Dubbo, told a newspaper:

It is all getting out of hand. Ordinary country people who have many legitimate concerns are being whipped up into a frenzy of anxiety by some crackpot who is spreading misinformation, sheer fantasy and hysterical nonsense.

The activities of Mr Sawyer have been of great concern to people on both sides of the House. From my investigations, he has certainly no credibility in those matters close to my responsibility or about which I have been able to carry out investigations. I hope that all members of the Parliament will dismiss his claims as being bizarre and lacking any truth and that the questioning that has been directed collectively in our direction will be turned back so that we get some answers from this person who is so lacking in credibility.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Prime Minister of his stated opposition to the closed shop and denials by his relevant Ministers from time to time that the closed shop even exists in the Australian industrial environment. In the light of this is he aware that in a letter to the Press Gallery the acting national secretary of the Australian Labor Party asked journalists to ensure that they have proof of union membership available at the time of accreditation to the ALP national conference? That letter states in part:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . all journalists, photographers, film and sound crews working at all ALP national conferences be required to be financial members of a relevant trade union, and that they be required to produce proof of union membership at the time of their accreditation at national conferences.

Is this not an attempt to establish a closed shop? What action will the Prime Minister take to ensure that this disgraceful, intolerable enforcement of compulsory unionism and restriction of Press freedom is not proceeded with by the ALP or tolerated by his Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In anticipation of the event in June-the ALP National Conference-I would love to have a bet with the honourable member as to whether there will be any shortage of media coverage of that event. I am quite sure that there will be a total, perhaps overwhelming, coverage of that event. Therefore, part of that question is obviously a nonsense. There is no intent on our part to try to restrict coverage of our conference, as distinct from the charade at the Hyatt Hotel in Melbourne last weekend when the Liberals would have been well served to have kept the Press out. Unfortunately, no matter how successful they were in doing that they did not succeed in stopping the Federal President of the Liberal Party of Australia from talking to the Press. I have ascertained the sorts of things that the Federal President had to say about the Federal Parliamentary Leader of the Liberal Party. As a result of my own very keenly developed sense of what is right language and my understanding of the rules of this Parliament, I would not be able to say in this place what the Federal President of the Liberal Party said about the Party's Parliamentary Leader. The language was disgusting.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am serious, it was disgusting. The Federal President used words that would never pass my lips. I could never have said about some of my colleagues-even when I felt very deeply about the rare occasions on which they had differed from me-the words that John Elliott used about John Howard. If Opposition members seriously wish to talk about restricting Press coverage, they should make sure that the Federal President of the Liberal Party is barred from talking to the media because these things get out. I can assure honourable members that if such things were ever printed they would make their ears burn.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to our Federal conference, we regarded it as appropriate to respond positively to suggestions that were made to us by representative organisations of the media that if a proper, professional job were to be done by the photographers and the journalists, then those attending the conference should be accredited by their organisations. In this respect I know that it would be very difficult for the Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for North Sydney, and all other honourable members on the Opposition side with legal training to attach any weight to this question because they know that in regard to their own profession-the legal profession-they are members of the tightest closed shop in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Treasurer, is prompted by the clear and widespread concern in the community about the possibility of a broad-based consumption tax and the clear indication that the Opposition intends to introduce a tax of that kind. Is the Government giving consideration to a tax of that kind? Is there any intention on the Government's part to introduce a broad-based consumption tax, and what could be the implications of such a tax?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Tim Fischer

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 144 which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: The question of the honourable member for Charlton is clearly asking for Government policy on the matter of a consumption tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not asking for policy.
—You are trying to direct attention away from your--
—Order! The honourable member for Moreton has had a couple of goes. I suggest he stop now.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is no on both counts. As honourable members will recall, at the National Taxation Summit in 1985 the Government proposed a consumption tax to deal with that part of the economy which was not being fully taxed. As a result of those deliberations the Government proceeded with other measures which are now yielding much more than the consumption tax was ever designed to yield. The result is that with the introduction of a fringe benefits tax (FBT), the abolition of entertainment as a deduction, substantiation, capital gains tax, other changes and increased Australian Tax Office action, between $2.5 billion and $2.75 billion has been raised in a discretionary way by the Government as a result of those discretionary changes. This far exceeds the $1.5 billion which was then designed to come from a consumption tax. At the time the Government adjudged that, given the fact that we were in the context of a large depreciation of the Australian dollar, the attendant wage changes to mute inflationary effects of the consumption tax could not be lived with.

ANSWER.PARA: Having changed and broadened the direct tax base, having made it fairer and much more decent and having passed those changes back in the largest tax cuts in our history by reducing those marginal rates of tax and introducing a full imputation system for business, we now have a debate from the Liberal side of politics-after all their opportunities in public office-about a consumption tax proposal from the Chairman and Federal President of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr Elliott. Mr Elliott has a great wish list of changes which he says would be funded by a consumption tax. First on the list, he says, are company tax cuts. Apparently the logic of the argument is that higher food prices for households should finance reductions in the company tax rate, but these reductions would be expensive. He then went on to suggest that a consumption tax could take place of the current alcohol excises. In other words, existing nominal ad valorem rates of 100 per cent and 150 per cent, expressed as taxes on alcohol per litre, would, under a consumption tax, be subject to massive reductions in taxes for alcoholic beverages. One does not need three guesses to know whose companies that would help! One does not need many guesses to understand the massive cost of such reductions.

Mr Elliott then went on to say that the consumption tax would also fund the removal of the wholesale sales tax system. A consumption tax of 6.5 per cent to 7 per cent would be required simply to neutralise that which is lost by the wholesale sales tax. So to do any of these other things that Mr Elliott has in mind would imply a consumption tax of between 10 per cent and 15 per cent. After that, he also suggested that such a tax could fund the removal of the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the changes that this Government has introduced, which, as I said, are worth $2.5 billion to $2.75 billion. On top of that, he says it will fund massive reductions in personal tax rates. This is the original Liberal Party magic pudding. It will fund company tax cuts; it will cut the current alcohol excises; it will cut and replace the wholesale sales tax system; it will provide massive personal tax cuts, it will pay for the abolition of the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the return of the deductibility of entertainment expenses. All the rorts would be back and it would have to pay for that lost revenue. It will do all this but still find that the pudding is intact. The Opposition will take all this out but says that there will still be money there for tax cuts. That is, of course, patent nonsense.

The Liberal Party thinks that there is some bottomless pit of funds. In fact, much of the area which has been taxed and which would have been subject to the consumption tax back in 1985 has now been taxed by the Government in an alternative way-with FBT, entertainment, substantiation, capital gains, et cetera. Much of this part of the indirect economy has been taxed, but nevertheless this approach is still touted.

The Liberal Party President insisted that this matter go on the agenda. Then he dragged the Leader of the Federal parliamentary Liberal Party to a public meeting-as the Prime Minister remarked, meetings of this sort are not public meetings-to ram a consumption tax down his throat to put on the agenda of the Federal parliamentary Liberal Party. We know what has happened inside the Liberal Party. The power has passed from Mr Howard to Mr Elliott. We heard about the meetings. We heard about all the business representatives milling around Mr Elliott as though he was some sort of ageing political rock star, with Mr Howard apparently by himself on the other side of the room, full of nervous energy and trembling, wondering whether he was going to be able to keep his act together over the weekend. Of course, providence struck. The Liberals beat the National Party in Groom.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Labor Party too.

—As the honourable member knows, we lost nothing out of it. If the Liberals could not beat the National Party in view of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, they will never beat it. The National Party is so much on the nose in Queensland that the Liberals could have beaten it staying home in bed. In view of the fact that Mr McVeigh has been given a government job, and we know how that has been treated electorally lately, is it any wonder the Liberals won?

ANSWER.PARA: It is an ill wind that blows no good. The Federal President, who is now the power in the Liberal Party, is not prepared to go into the Parliament and take his proper place as the Leader of the Federal parliamentary Liberal Party. We have the shadow Treasurer afraid of power and unable to strike down the honourable member for Bennelong. So it is a case of the living dead. The honourable member for Bennelong has taken the lightning strikes of the July 1987 election. He has taken all the opprobrium of his failure to perform up to last Christmas. By any reckoning in Australian politics, he should have been replaced on two or three occasions, but he is still there. It is like live political art-the sorts of things one sees in art galleries. It is only because of the wink that we know it is a person.

I described the Leader of the Opposition the other day in political terms as a political carcass. I am saying to Mr Elliott: cut him down and let us get back to a proper basis of politics, where the real power of the Liberal Party faces us in the Parliament. Let the Opposition get its policy out. If it wants to put a tax on food and a tax on kids' clothes to fund company tax cuts and to put the rorts back into the system, let the mouthpiece who is advertising that policy come in here and defend it in the Parliament instead of doing it at some Liberal Party council meeting, sharing power with a political neuter who cannot win an election and cannot face the public issues in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Over the past nine years, successive Ministers have had the responsibility of reporting to honourable members on progress with the new Parliament House. The achievements over that period can now be marked by what will probably be the last such report to be presented within the confines of the building that has served this nation for 61 years as the home of its national parliament. The new building, as all honourable members can see for themselves, a few short weeks from its official opening by Her Majesty is virtually complete. As I informed the Parliament last October, it will be ready for its formal opening on 9 May and to commence operations in August.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now provide a budget update for the three months period from September to November last year. The revised building budget for the three months to November 1987 now stands at $897.46m, with another $158.85m for the non-building items budget. This includes a transfer of $11m from the non-building items budget to the building budget. The total project budget is therefore increased from $1,047.8m at August 1987 prices to $1,056.31m at November 1987 prices. This updating includes $4.68m for the effects of inflation in the three-months period.

There are some additional components to cover costs outside the control of the Parliament House Construction Authority. The first has been an allowance of $2.41m for the cost of industrial disputes. If I could just digress to give a breakdown which may be of some assistance to the House: the cost of the quarter's industrial disputes can, in the main, be attributed to a demarcation dispute between the furnishing trades and the Transport Workers Union of Australia in October; a series of stoppages in each month involving the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia and the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australia; and a plumbers strike in September. The costs respectively in breakdown order were $540,000, $800,000 and $270,000.

There is a cost of $1.42m for reinstatement of previously deleted works, including two Ministers' suites and the area to house the Australian Protective Services in the southern area of the building. There is still a need to provide for a revised layout to the ministerial media group area for the third additional Minister's suite. After discussion between myself and the Parliament House Construction Authority, the Authority has decided to reject all tenders for this work as being far too high. Subject to agreement by the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, a revised layout will be achieved by effecting minimal changes to the ministerial media group area at less than 50 per cent of the lowest tenderer's price.

I again digress to give some late information sought by the Opposition regarding the cost of the decision not to use rainforest timber in the building after last August. I was informed today that to date the cost of this decision is $647,933. We estimate that the final cost may reach $700,000. The cost includes the settlement of some claims from timber suppliers and furniture manufacturers and the additional cost of replacement timbers. However, and I ask the House to take note of this, the amounts do not take into account the underlying additional costs the Authority would have incurred due to the delays imposed on it by timber suppliers had the decision not been taken. That is, we will never know what the cost would have been had we not taken the decision, particularly if the north Queensland suppliers had continued to boycott supply to the manufacturers. Two points can be made: the indicative cost so far of $700,000 is nowhere near the $15m that some Press reports have implied. Secondly, it has to be spotted off against an unknown quantitative cost as to what the cost may have been had we continued to allow ourselves to be stood over by suppliers who would not supply the timber. I look forward confidently, and with some pride, to presenting our next progress report from our new and permanent Parliament House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am sure that the House welcomes the advice of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) that the new Parliament House is progressing on schedule and will be ready for the official opening on 9 May and the subsequent commencement of operations in August. However, our approval of the content of the Minister's statement ends at that point. When the budget for the new Parliament House was first drawn up, it included $220m for construction and $82m for non-building items, a total of $302m. The Minister now advises us that the cost of the new Parliament House is set at $1,056m, an increase in excess of 350 per cent over the original estimate.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the fact that the construction phase is almost complete and the Government is now concluding the fit out, the blow-out in cost continues. One of the most disturbing reasons for the blow-out is the cost of the continuing and high level of industrial disputes. It is a sad reflection on the pathetic state of this nation under Labor that this Government is willing to sit back and report calmly that the cost to the taxpayer of the industrial disputes, industrial blackmail, strikes and disruption which have occurred on just one government building site over the last six months is over a quarter of a million dollars a week. Remember that the building is almost completed and the Government is still paying a quarter of a million dollars a week to satisfy the unions which continue to brawl among themselves. Today the Minister expressed not a word of regret that this has continued to occur. The bland acceptance of this totally unacceptably high level of industrial disputes is just another example of how this Government has lost touch with the people. The Australian community is no longer prepared to tolerate this industrial lawlessness. The Australian taxpayer should not be called on to pay the costs of irresponsible union action fostered by this Government's weak compliance. Whilst the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Ministers continue to cling to the existing outdated, outmoded industrial relations system, the nation will continue to suffer through higher taxes, lower production and a lower standard of living.

The Minister's statement also reveals the chaotic state of this Government's administration. In an earlier forlorn attempt to control the cost blow-out, the Government deleted some of the works that were planned originally for the new Parliament House. Now, as the time comes to use the building, the Government has put those works back on the program at, of course, an increased cost to the taxpayer. In a costly change of mind, this Government has reversed its earlier decisions.

As we know, the Government has seen fit to match the massive growth in the size of the Public Service in the last five years with an increase in the size of the Ministry. Not only are we told by the Minister that we have to pay the extra salaries for the extra Ministers whom the Prime Minister has seen fit to appoint but also we are up for $1.42m in new office accommodation for those extra Ministers. This is another example of the Government thumbing its nose at the public. It has no qualms about spending taxpayers' money.

It is interesting that the Opposition on a recent visit to the new Parliament House discovered that the room set aside for shadow Cabinet meetings is about half the size required. That highlights a regrettable lack of consultation in planning of the building.

TALK.START.PARA: —We won't be using it for long.

—A request to remove a wall to increase the size of the room has been rejected. We on this side of the House are glad that it will be only a very temporary problem for us because, as the honourable member for Mallee has just said, we will soon be on the other side of the House and the problem will have to be borne by those opposite. They will have to put up with their own stupidity.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I raise the issue of the use of this building after we make the move up the hill. I raised the matter in the House with the Minister a month or so ago and have still to receive a response from him. As I understand it, the Government has set up an interdepartmental committee to consider the future use of these premises when we move up the hill. No information has been given to the House or the public as to the future use of these buildings. I again ask: When will the Government put a proposition to the House in relation to these buildings? It is a matter of great public interest. Not only is the public interested in the opening of the new Parliament House and in seeing the new Parliament House but also people want to know what will happen to this building which has served us so well for so many years.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The uncertainty, insecurity and fear among members of the aged community and their families arising from the Government's approach to aged care.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are to debate a matter that affects a large number of Australians, their families and the people who care for them. Many groups in Australian society have been attacked by the Hawke Labor Government since it came to office in March 1983. I guess no group has been attacked more than the aged in Australia. The Australian Labor Party began its first few months in office with a super tax and an assets test. Then it broke a promise to increase the pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings; delayed consumer price index adjustments to the pension; perpetuated poverty traps; introduced tougher assets tests and cut back on veterans' entitlements. It has done about all it can do in that area and now it is directing its attention to the frail aged in our society. Many people would think that this is not a significant issue because not too many people want to address the problems of the frail aged. We, as a society, tend to want to avoid unpleasant images and many of our nursing homes for the aged are not in the mainstream of our community.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me tell honourable members that there are around 70,000 residents of nursing homes in Australia. They have families and staff who care for them. The issue we are debating today is real; it is not a statistical issue or something that an academic economist within the Department of Community Services and Health could debate in terms of working papers. We are talking about people who suffer, who are scared about their future. We are talking about families whose means are not sufficient to cope with additional financial burdens and are very concerned about the Government's intentions in this area. There is general agreement about the direction of the Government's policy. We on this side of the House agree that there is a need for diversity in aged care. We recognise that it is desirable to allow people to choose the most appropriate and adequate type of care available to them. That, of course, includes intensive care in nursing homes, hostel care for those people with greater capacities and facilities and home nursing for those people who are still able to look after themselves, either in their own homes or in the homes of their families. But that is just about as far as the agreement with the Government goes.

It is not just the Opposition which objects to the implementation of the Government's policy; it is the entire nursing home aged care industry-without exception. Later I will make reference to the views of the industry. It is not just the private operators, the people who operate at a profit, who are objecting to the Government's proposals; it is not just the voluntary or charitable operators who are objecting; it is not an objection from South Australia, Victoria or one other State; it is a universal opposition to the Government's proposed implementation of its policy. The opposition is based on the way the Government is going about implementing this policy, which is autocratic, remote and theoretical. There has been totally inadequate consultation with people with immense practical experience in aged care in Australia.

So that the Parliament will understand exactly what I am saying I will quote from the 20-odd page submission made by the Australian Affiliation of Voluntary Care Associations. It is not a submission from a private nursing home and not from the Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association of Australia but from the association that represents the voluntary care providers in the society-the charities and the churches. They are not profit motivated; they are motivated by concern for their fellow human beings. They are concerned at the impact the Government's policies will have on the frail aged in Australian society and the flow-on impact on those who care for them, on their families and on society in general.

It is a striking condemnation of this Government, that claims it is caring and concerned about the status of Australians, when we find that charities are saying that the Government is out of touch and does not know what it is talking about. The President of the Voluntary Care Associations, in writing to the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), in terms of the consultation and lack of consultation, said:
Some of the documents, and especially some of vital concern to the industry, were not distributed until the persons were present at the meeting.
The Government did not want people to read what was in those documents because they might have understood what was going on. He also said:
Sufficient time was not allowed for the reading of the documents-
when they were tabled at the meeting-
The State consultations were more a matter of sharing information and gaining initial reactions from those present-
than seeking a considered position-
There has been little time allowed for the industry to consult among its members . . .

before responding to a very complex working party document on this very significant issue. It is no wonder that the industry is concerned because the Government has politicised the issue of aged care, almost from the day it was elected. In fact, last year in the Victorian newspapers, when this issue first arose as a major community concern the Government, with taxpayers' money, started placing advertisements. The text of these advertisements is an absolute disgrace. It is stated:
The nursing home scandal is over! A fair deal for nursing home residents. Some greedy nursing home operators claim recent government changes . . .

The greedy nursing home operators are the churches and charities. Everybody agrees that the Government's policy is off the rails. Yet it has the nerve to use taxpayers' money to place a blatant political advertisement in a newspaper, to take advantage of its political circumstances. It is a wonder that the advertisement does not contain a photograph of a Minister smiling, as the right wing machine of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales perfected the technique.

The issue is very complex. The whole question of nursing home financing is most complex. But what it really comes down to is that the Government has taken a decision, which it has not yet announced but has foreshadowed in working paper documents to the industry, that it proposes to limit the number of staff care hours per patient in nursing homes throughout Australia. It will have a uniform standard. The Government apparently is moving towards a standard of 17.1 hours per patient in the most critical case; for the most frail aged patient in nursing homes. The industry, with immense practical experience, has said that a minimum standard is 27 hours. That is the basis of the dispute. The Government says 17 hours and the industry says 27 hours. I am simplifying the debate deliberately because we have only 15 minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —You certainly are simplifying it.

—The Minister says that I am. I challenge the Minister to have an open debate and let us debate this issue for half a day because that is the kind of debate we really need on this very significant issue. There is the related issue of the assessment teams. The Minister has run around this country saying-and it is to his disgrace that he would make such a statement-that an overwhelming majority of nursing home patients are getting inadequate or inappropriate care. So we have trial assessment teams running around the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry thinks that those assessment teams are running a gate-keeping operation to limit the number of people who can get into nursing homes, irrespective of their need. There is immense concern in the industry about the adequacy of the assessment basis, the instrument by which people will be assessed and by which it will be determined whether they need the intensive care of a nursing home, whether they can cope within a hostel or perhaps whether home nursing is the right way to go for them. The very basis of that assessment is in dispute by the people who are responsible for caring for these frail aged in our community. Yet the Government persists with its approach-no consultation. It is an autocratic approach.

Many people do not really understand what this will mean. It will mean a return to totally inadequate standards of care-according to the industry-for the frail aged. The industry has said that this will be akin to custodial care rather than caring care, a return to the standards of the nineteenth century. The Voluntary Care Associations, in a submission on behalf of the entire industry, including the Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals Association of Australia, has started to quantify what these changes will mean. They will mean restrictions on the capacity of nursing homes to feed patients. There will be production line feeding and if people do not get adequate feeding in the time available that will be too bad and they will have to find some other way to be fed. There will be problems with continence. That is a very delicate subject. But the easiest way to cope with it, if one does not have time to look after the particular needs of a patient, is to use a catheter. I wonder whether the Minister has any understanding of what this means for people-not statistics-the frail aged people; the grandparents and parents of Australians on whom the Minister is implementing a policy which will cause considerable hardship.

The industry indicates that the capacity to bathe patients will be reduced. We could have a situation where patients will be washed only every second day. I wonder what that will be like in the summer. Patients will be left in bed for longer periods and that will have a significant impact on their health. Does anyone really understand what that means? Have honourable members ever seen a bed sore? Has the Minister seen a bed sore? I invite him to look at them because we are talking about people. That is not a statistic; it is a real consequence of inadequate care in a nursing home. The opportunities to bring people out of nursing homes and give them social interaction will be reduced. The capacity to cope with patients who have physical and mental problems will be reduced and there will be a need for physical and chemical restraint.

The Nursing Homes Association lists 18 problems which entail a reduction in the standard of care as a result of the Government's proposed changes. As I have said, there is concern in the industry that the assessment teams will be gatekeepers and will restrict the access of aged Australians to intensive care. The Government's figures indicate that the cost of these assessment teams will rise from $4m to $16m. The industry says that the standard of assessment is inadequate and inappropriate. It thinks that industrial disputes will arise because of the extreme pressures that will be applied to people responsible for caring for the aged in our society.

We are really talking about a significant issue. The people who are concerned about it, and who are expressing that concern, are not, as the Government would have us believe, profit hungry entrepreneurs. They are dedicated nurses, directors of nursing, senior sisters, churches and charities. I have received a great deal of correspondence from virtually every nursing home around Australia expressing concern in practical terms about the way the Government is implementing a policy that, in principle, has considerable merit.

The dispute is about the standard of care. There is one thing that the Government should do to try to receive industry support and to restore some credibility to its policy; that is, to actually prove its figures. A working party is out and about suggesting to the industry that certain things will happen. One way to go about it would be to conduct a practical trial. I have suggested this before and today, on behalf of the Opposition, I suggest it again.

If the Government believes that its standard of staff care is appropriate, it should apply its policy to the government owned and government managed, nursing home in Canberra-it should apply CAM, or the care aggregate module-and prove to the industry that it works. The Government should prove it before 1 July. If that is possible, the industry will have no choice but to accept the Government's proposal before it is forced to implement it Australia-wide. However, if the Government is not willing to trial its figures, it should sit down with the industry and work through the figures again.

At the outset I said that this was a major problem. It is indeed a major problem; it affects hundreds of thousands of Australians, not just the residents and their parents, children and grandchildren; it affects also the staff of nursing homes, who will have to try to cope with these new standards. We all know what the attitudes of nurses are; they will try to make do. Directors of nursing will cut corners and place extra stress on their staffs to try to comply with this Government edict. Of course, we will see a reduction in the standard of care. Australia, which has an enviable reputation throughout the world for looking after its aged, will have its reputation diminished. The problem will be compounded because anyone who has examined the demographics of the Australian population will realise that the number of aged in Australia is increasing rapidly, and for that reason we had better get aged care right, not only in financial terms but also in care terms.

There is a need to ensure that the industry can work positively with the Government. There is a need to do away with the politicisation of this entire debate. When one is unable to win an argument on merit, there is no justification for getting into the polemics of the argument. One has to understand that people and not statistics are involved. If what the Government should like to do in financial terms will not work, maybe it should recast its Budget and rethink its spending priorities. Apparently at the moment the Government is rethinking its spending priorities. Aged care is one area where the Government should give urgent consideration to rethinking its spending priorities.

The Government has immense damage to undo. As I have said, the way to go about undoing that damage is to conduct a trial to prove that the figures work. If the figures do not work, the Government should move to a standard that will work-a standard that the industry is capable of implementing. The last thing we want in this country is a return to custodial care for the frail aged and a return to the standards of the nineteenth century for those people in the Australian community who are not capable of looking after themselves without the support and assistance of government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Aged Care)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this debate today. I am glad that the Opposition, through its shadow Minister, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), has placed before us today its concern for `the uncertainty, insecurity and fear among members of the aged community and their families arising from the Government's approach to aged care'. I believe that the statements of the shadow Minister, from his own mouth and from his own papers, will return to haunt him. The shadow Minister has set out to terrorise the aged population of Australia. He has set out to terrorise their relatives and anyone else he can get to. He is picking up on a campaign that is being waged currently by some organisations. I shall not differentiate between them. Some people are out to protect their own interests, as well as-they may well be saying in other instances-protecting the interests of nursing home residents.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the present system is inequitable and does not really work. However, one should look back to the time when the Opposition was in government-back to 1981, two years before the Opposition was voted out of office. One should look also at the years before that time when the Opposition was in government. I draw to the attention of honourable members the Auditor-General's report on an efficiency audit of Commonwealth administration of nursing home programs. In his findings concerning management and planning the Auditor-General criticised the operations of the Government of that time-that is, the Opposition that now criticises this Government-because the existing systems of management control exhibited weaknesses that gave rise to a lack of economy and lack of consistency.

The Auditor-General said also that planning was fragmented. He said that admission procedures were defective in terms of cost control and matching patients' needs with optimum care. He found also that approximately 20 per cent of nursing home patients could be more appropriately cared for in alternative accommodation, if available, at lower costs. With regard to standards, the Auditor-General found, basically, that the Commonwealth funded varying levels of nursing care because States had different nursing standards, and that the efficiency of inspection activities was hampered by the absence of comprehensive guidelines on standards of nursing home care.

He found also that existing growth controls lacked the support that would be provided by integrated planning. Also, the fees control mechanism did not appear to be effective in terms of the objective of restricting fee increases to costs necessarily incurred. He found that costs of deficit financed homes were significantly greater than costs in privately operated nursing homes that were charging up to the standard fee. In relation to admission procedures, the Auditor-General suggested that multidisciplinary panels-what we call geriatric assessment teams-should be set up to review some or all applications for admission to nursing homes. He said that maximum standards for nursing hours should be established and joint inspections with the States promoted. He said also that there should be some control over the number of nursing home beds.

What did the Opposition do when it was in government? Nothing. What did the Opposition care about people in nursing homes? Nothing. The shadow Minister threw at me across the table a photgraph of a person with a bed sore. I refer the shadow Minister back to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes tabled by Senator Giles and other reports that have been tabled in this Parliament. Had he visited nursing homes during those times, he would have witnessed the care that was not being given to people in nursing homes under his Government's administration. This matter of public importance is a sham. It is an absolute disgrace. The Opposition is terrorising people.

Let us examine what the shadow Minister has been releasing in his media statements. He talks about uncertainty, insecurity and fear among members of the aged community. Who is creating that uncertainty, insecurity and fear? Let us examine his record in 1987 when the standard aggregate module-SAM-and infrastructure cost proposals were being put forward. In a Press release of 23 October 1987 he said that 60 per cent of Tasmanian nursing homes would go out of business, involving up to a third of that State's aged in care. Have 60 per cent of nursing homes in that State gone out of business? No. He said also that the Labor Government planned to restrict the staff to patient time ratio to around 14 hours a week. Wrong again. He said further that the Hawke Labor Government seemed intent on sending patients of nursing homes far away from their families.

Who is causing the insecurity? Who is causing the uncertainty and the fear in this Parliament and in this country today? Again in his repetitious Press releases the shadow Minister has criticised the Government's plans. He has claimed that nursing homes with fewer than 30 beds would be forced to close and it would be impossible for voluntary organisations to provide respite care. He did not stop there. This year in Press statement after Press statement he has referred to nursing and personal care funding. These statements have caused uncertainty, insecurity and fear among the aged community and their families. The honourable member opposite is creating the concern. He is running around the country terrorising people by claiming, for instance, that patients will be washed less often, possibly only every second day. A heading in a Queensland newspaper reads `Plug might be pulled on daily wash for oldies-Blunt'. That is as blunt as it can be.

The honourable member for Richmond says in a Press release on 23 March 1988 that nursing homes will be forced to leave patients in bed longer, use more chemical and physical restraints, cut communications with patients and families, implement production line feeding, and use non-individual continence maintenance. He says that some nursing home beds may close and residents will be forced to look for alternative accommodation. That is what he is saying. He is terrorising people in this community.
In another Press release the next day, 24 March, he again terrorises the aged and their relatives with uncertainty, insecurity and fear. He says:
When the Government first announced its latest aged care policy it said 25% of nursing homes residents would be moved to hostels.
He further says:
Now we are told 40% are to be moved.
The assertions by the honourable member are beyond the pale. They are a symptom of the Opposition's tactics and of its lack of policies.

Let us see what this Government has done in its time in office, compared with the record of the Opposition, for people in nursing homes, for people who have bed sores like the person in this photograph. The Opposition has been condemned by this Parliament and it has been condemned by reports. We are the ones bringing standards into the nursing home industry. When we came to government there was no comprehensive national planning system. The Government has introduced a national population based, statistically determined, planning structure for nursing homes and hostels. There was no response to the problems of the ethnic aged from the Opposition. This Government did respond and is bringing in ethnic specific beds. There was no response from the Opposition in its period of government to the Aboriginal aged. There was no response to the financially disadvantaged. Where were the upgrading grants? Where were the upgradings in nursing homes of fire, health and safety levels?

What did the Opposition do in government? There were no upgrading grants. Under this Government there have been 477 projects to upgrade nursing homes. What about dementia? What about the people in the nursing homes and hostels who suffer from dementia? Where was the Opposition's dementia program? It did not have one. It needed one but it did not have one. Where was its program to assist the elderly confused? Where was its program for 100 per cent capital funding for the disadvantaged? It did not have one. Yet the Opposition comes into this House and accuses this Government of creating uncertainty, insecurity and fear. It has not got a leg to stand on.

The current situation is that this Government has a policy which we are implementing. It is a reform strategy that we are taking gradually. It is a very difficult area. Our policy will ensure that aged people receive services that are best suited to their needs, that facilities are developed where they are needed, that care is of a high quality and that residents are allowed the maximum level of independence. In line with the needs of the aged population, which is growing very greatly-and the costs are growing greatly-this Government is addressing the concerns of the Auditor-General that were expressed back in 1981. They were concerns that the Opposition failed to address. This Government is addressing those concerns in terms of hostels, in terms of the home and community care program and in terms of nursing homes. This Government is taking a very compassionate approach to the problems involved in aged care in Australia. We have needs based planning, assessment services, quality of care and quality of life outcome standards.

Why did not the Opposition think of those things? What was it doing during that time? Why was it not responding to the problems facing people in their outcome standards? The funding system that the Opposition administered was an absolute mess. What about the special services programs? What about the cost to pensioners? What about the people in nursing homes who have to pay? What happens about them? The Opposition wants them to pay more and more without giving them the security of standards-standards which will be scrutinised-and affordable accommodation.
