The Opposition does not care about those things. The present system is inequitable and we are fixing it up.

The honourable member for Richmond talked about an advertisement from the Department of Community Services and Health. That advertisement was in response to one that appeared a couple of days before that from industry associations that said people would be thrown out. The honourable member was the one who was scaring people as he is trying to do today. People have not been thrown out. The reality is that Opposition members are the ones scaring people. They are terrorising people.

The honourable member for Richmond says he is concerned about consultation. The Opposition is concerned about consultation! There have been over 300 hours of consultation with major national industry bodies. There has also been extensive consultation on the issue of nursing and personal care. There was extensive consultation with unions, professional bodies and consumers. There have been several sets of lengthy consultations in every State and Territory. There have been over 60 rounds of meetings and that is what the Opposition will not tell anyone about. I ask the Opposition not just to take my word for it. Let me quote from the NSW Nursing Homes Chronicle. I will refer to the infrastructure issue. On 29 May 1987 the NSW Nursing Homes Chronicle stated:

. . . the principal negotiators for government . . . have proven to be men of their word throughout the 12 months period and that during the entire time they have taken into account many points raised by us during the discussions, modifying their own proposals accordingly.
That was last year. Let me talk about this year. The NSW Nursing Homes Chronicle, which is not a government publication, but an industry publication, stated on 11 March 1988:
. . . we have at least had the good sense to recognise the willingness on the part of the Commonwealth bureaucracy to try to meet the need for communication as best as possible.
It went on:
. . . the goodwill that has been shown to us by the very top members of the Department's staff, and given their openness and willingness to talk as freely as they possibly can . . .
Further it stated:

Since the beginning of this year, from the very earliest days of January, there have been a considerable number of meetings at nursing and financial levels between the national negotiating team and the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health and there are further meetings to be held in Canberra next week at that level.
It went on:
. . . we have been most appreciative of the manner in which the very senior officers of the Department have handled their portfolio in respect to communication with this Association.

That is part of the answer to the Opposition's claim. I have only two minutes left but I will go on. The fact of the matter is that the honourable member for Richmond was out there talking about the uncertainty, insecurity and fear among members of the aged community and their families arising from the Government's approach to aged care. Where is the Opposition's policy? Who will make its policy? Is it the loving and caring Senator Stone? Is it the warm, loving and caring Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard)? How does this fit in with the Opposition's consumption tax policy? Where are the Opposition's policies on just about any matter in front of this Parliament? Where are its economic policies, its tax policies, its aged care policies? It does not have any. This Government has and we will ensure that the benefits of those policies flow to the residents of nursing homes, to every aged person in Australia, through the hostels program and through the home and community care program. The elderly people of Australia and their relatives will be secure in the knowledge that there are now outcome standards, that there is now scrutiny and that when these new arrangements are brought in there will be care according to need. By 1991 no person in a nursing home in Australia will have to pay more than 87 1/2 per cent of his or her pension plus rent assistance. That is the situation. This Government is committed to an aged care policy that works for the care and quality of life of those people in our ageing population. We are determined to make sure that future funding arrangements are directed to the areas of greatest need and that our aged people are treated in a dignified and caring way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on this matter of public importance on the concern of older members of the community about the changes that are taking place at the moment, I want to begin by talking about some facts as distinct from the 15 minutes of waffle we have just heard from the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples). He talked about funding. Yes, funds have gone up by 68 per cent in five years. However, the consumer price index increase for that period is 41 per cent and that takes funding down to an 18.4 per cent real increase. In addition over the past five years the population over 75 years of age has increased by 22.6 per cent. This means there has been overall a 3.4 per cent reduction per capita in funding for older people in this country. That is hardly care and compassion. Over the same period the per capita gross domestic product has increased by 14.6 per cent. That is what most Australians have shared in but not older people. Under this Government they have had a real per capita reduction in funding.

SPEECH.PARA: Funding itself is not the whole story. It is not as important as outcomes. Particularly in the aged care industry, one must look at the outcomes of funding. The Victorian aged services peak council earlier this year received a report after 24 Victorian nursing homes were sampled. Some 60 per cent of people in those homes could not control their bowels or their bladders, yet only 20 per cent of them were being washed daily; that is, 40 per cent of people in those homes were not being washed though they were soiling themselves. If they were not being washed it was because staffing levels were inadequate, and staffing levels in every nursing home in that State were approved by the Minister's Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his electorate, too.

—In his electorate, too. If they are inadequate, it is because the Minister has failed to provide adequate staffing through the bureaucratic control he provides in nursing homes. The Minister said that people now have to pay because of the inadequacies of the previous Government. I looked through the Minister's Press releases, and I found a total of four newspaper articles. Yesterday's Age carried an article stating that Victorian nursing homes imposed a heavy burden on many residents by requiring them to pay money they could not afford. That is totally untrue. The Minister provides a subsidy and controls the fee the nursing homes charge and the difference is met by the patients. If a Victorian nursing home charges more than the Minister's approved fee, it is fined $10,000. Thus there are only three components: the Minister controls the fee, he controls the subsidy, and the patient has to make up the difference. In the five years that the Minister's Party has been in government, the fee of $418 has increased by $6. In spite of that, there has been an inflation rate of 41 per cent. So it is not the nursing homes that are forcing people to pay extra money. It is the Minister, his Department and his Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government says that the present system often forces people into nursing homes when they need only minimal care. The Minister quoted from a 1981 report a figure of 20 per cent. That might have been so in 1981, but the Minister should update his figures. In 1981 the average age of admission to nursing homes in Victoria was 73. In 1987 it is 82. Today people in nursing homes have become on average much older and much more dependent. This has happened in a short time. Recently in the western health region of Melbourne every one of the 500 nursing home beds was sampled to see whether there was anyone in those homes who need not be there. Only one person was found, and one person out of 500 is not `often'.

The development of the present patient classification system is an absolute scandal. It is true that the Minister did run a trial on 17,000 patients, but he then fitted those patients into five predetermined dependency categories-categories of 20 per cent, 20 per cent, 30 per cent, 20 per cent, and 10 per cent. The Minister did not consider the patients' needs; he put them into categories that had already been decided. The Voluntary Care Association has trialed this system in its nursing homes. It does not work. The Association has told the Minister so. One group of nursing homes partly within my electorate trialed the Minister's system to see how many of their patients, many of whom are highly dependent, they could put into category one, the highest dependency category. Out of 140 patients, they got three. A director of nursing at a church-run nursing home told me, `I can't make this system run unless I lie, and I'm not prepared to do that'. The Minister's system is unfair and inequitable. I shall give an example. An elderly person who is crouched in the foetal position, unable to do anything whatsoever for himself, on the proposed system would be classified category four, and that is a category of minimal care. Under the Minister's proposals, that person eventually will be moved out into a hostel.

On consultation, the hours mentioned by the Minister sounded impressive. But one should look at what has happened. I talked to someone who had experience of one of the Minister's consultations. The person was at a meeting on 18 February attended by 100 people representing directors of nursing and some of the most important people in the nursing home industry in my State. Half of those people had not received the documents they were supposed to talk about and be consulted on at the meeting. That is not consultation; that is sheer incompetence. In Victoria, the Minister's State and mine, nursing homes will be hit hardest. Victoria has the lowest number of nursing homes per head of elderly population of any State in Australia. It has the highest number of dependency patients. Geriatric assessment teams have been operating for three years to make sure that only the most seriously afflicted people get into nursing homes. Under the Minister's arbitrary system, they are forced into predetermined classifications. I repeat: Victoria will be hit hardest.

I had intended to reply to more of what the Minister said; but, really he said so little. It is a joke for him to talk about 1981. I was then still at university. This is 1988. The Minister spoke about scaring the population. The people are scared, but it is not members of the Opposition who are trying to scare the population. The Voluntary Care Association, the private geriatric hospitals, the Archbishop of Melbourne, the Moderator of the Uniting Church, and the head of the Australian Catholic Health Care Association are the ones issuing the Press statements. They are not trying to scare the population. They are committed people, trying to get a fair deal for the frail and elderly under their care. I find it hypocritical of the Minister to talk about members of the Opposition trying to scare the population after listening to the bunkum that came from the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) about a possible Opposition health policy and saying wildly inaccurate things-doing exactly the same thing, scaring people, as he is criticising members of the Opposition for supposedly doing.

The Minister spoke about the dementia program and said that before Labor came to office there was no dementia program. Does the Minister know that the only nursing home in Australia that caters exclusively for demented people was set up in Kew, not far from his electorate, by the Fraser Government? Continued requests for similar additional programs to give elderly demented people dignity in an environment specifically designed for their needs, not just an organ in a hostel to keep them busy, have been refused by the Minister's Department.

What of care according to need? I have shown that really is a farce. I want to show the Minister the depth of feeling on care for the elderly. I have a document with 24,000 signatures, not one of which was collected by a branch member of the Liberal Party. Those were collected in just two weeks. They are the signatures of average Australians in the Minister's electorate and in my electorate who are concerned about what is happening to their elderly relatives. The Minister has effected a real reduction in funding for the aged in our population. He has presided over gross bureaucratic over-regulation. There has been a terrible decline in standards. It is the Minister's Department that controls and approves absolutely everything. The proposed new system has had totally inadequate consultation. It has set predetermined arbitrary limits and forced people into those arbitrary limits. It does not take account of vast differences between the States in award wages and different infrastructure costs. That is illogical, inflexible and unfair. The public will not accept a situation where the Government shows a total lack of understanding, a total lack of care and a total lack of compassion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —After hearing the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) and wiping the tears from my eyes I would like to speak on this matter. The honourable member, no doubt, has made an intensive study of this subject because that is his profession. However, I should point out that he mentioned dementia. I have a great interest in this subject because one of the main supporters of the Liberal Party of Australia in my area, a certain Reverend Bob Payne, a Festival of Light organiser, happened to lose a dementia grant that this Federal Government gave him. It got lost in the money pot that he sort of spread around; the $20m of debt of the Baxter Retirement Village which arose when he made some incorrect investment decisions. Honourable members opposite do not have to talk about spending on dementia grants. I know all about it. I know what has happened to grants to supporters of the Liberal Party and the conservative parties. I would like also to comment on the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt). The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) brought to my attention a story in a Queensland newspaper in relation to a statement by the honourable member for Richmond. The honourable member has repeated it again today. He has said that elderly patients will be force fed-as if they were chooks in some sort of production shed. Being a National Party of Australia member, I imagine that he would know all about that. What he and his Party have done, and what they are trying to do through total misrepresentation, is spread fear among the community. This is typical of the conservative parties in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I can remember a couple of years ago when we had a certain Mr Hodgman as the honourable member for Denison in this place. His claim to fame came during the assets test debate when he said that there would be social security storm-troopers knock, knock, knocking at the door. Those were the sorts of theatrics he used all the time. He said that they would be knocking at the door and coming to rip out the gold teeth of pensioners. My parents have lived through all of this. They are still alive. They had no one knocking at their door. I think that my Dad still has his gold teeth. That sort of hysterical stuff from the conservative parties is typical of what is happening in Victoria now, what has happened in New South Wales and what happens all the time. The only way that they can stir up any sort of publicity whatsoever is to spread fear in the community. Fears and half truths are their tactics. They are experts at it; they have been doing it for years.

I see that the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) is sitting in the House. He is an assets test expert and knows all about it. He is still peddling this sort of thing. The fears about nursing homes that honourable members opposite are starting to peddle now are exactly the same. Let me go through some of the things they are starting to do. No doubt we will get more and more of this. A document headed `Attention relatives and friends of nursing home patients' is typical of what is being passed around in nursing homes in Victoria at the moment. It is a proper printed document which goes through various issues that they believe should be brought to the attention of the Minister and the local Federal member. However, the letters that we have received from constituents all have a similar ring about them. I have here faxed copies-which I received just an hour ago-of every letter that has arrived in my office in relation to the nursing home problem. I would like to repeat a few sentences from each one to enable honourable members to see the connection. One letter states:
We have appreciated the high standards of care that have been received-
at a certain nursing home-
We will not sit idly by and see those standards eroded as a result of cuts in nursing and personal care staff.
Some of the letters are typed and some are hand written. Another letter states:
We believe that this country owes something to the older citizen.
Another letter states:
I will not sit by and see that those standards are eroded as a result of cuts in summary care.
This country owes something to its older citizens.
Another letter states:
I will not sit idly by and see the standards eroded as a result of cuts in nursing care.
Do they sound the same? Another letter states:
This country owes something to its older citizens. Many have given everything for their country in difficult times.
I will not sit idly by and see these standards eroded.

These quotations are all from letters that have arrived in my office from constituents of mine. It is funny how they use the same sentences. The odds against this happening are pretty rare. I do not know why they are using the same sentences. However, I do have a few other letters. One letter states:
A study by a private individual indicates that the minimum care hours per patient per week is 27.3 hours.
Another letter states:
A study by a private individual indicates that the minimum care hours per patient per week is 27.3 hours.

One begins to wonder a little when one gets all these letters that are exactly the same. They vary a little bit here and there, but they have the same sorts of sentences. What is going on? One asks whether this is some sort of concerted effort. Then out of the blue comes a Labor supporter who says, `Did you know that there is a standard letter going around?'. I said, `Well, I sort of had that impression'. That document is headed `Suggested letter for concerned people to their local Federal member of Parliament'. It then goes on to say, `Say either/or'. There are variations of how one can write the letter. I will just read out one little sentence which states:
This country owes something to its older citizens. They are in many instances people who have given everything for their country in difficult times.

Who writes these letters? Could they have been written by a Federal Liberal member who then sends them around? They could not have been written by a Labor member. No Labor member would be scurrilous enough to do that. That is the sort of concerted effort undertaken by the conservatives of this country to try to ruin a good and effective review of what is happening to nursing homes in Australia today.

I will bring to honourable members' attention the variation in some of the benefits applying from State to State. The Commonwealth benefit per week is $418 in Victoria; $357 in South Australia; $325 in New South Wales; $295 in Western Australia; $282 in Queensland and $269 in Tasmania. We hear the Tasmanians screaming all the time about the high cost of things in Tasmania. However, in nursing homes in Victoria the Commonwealth benefit per week is $418. In Tasmania, it is $269. There could be some reason for this-such as administration. Maybe in Victorian nursing homes there are slightly different costs. However, these things should be pointed out to people who have relatives in nursing homes.

Not only do many people in nursing homes have to pay over their pensions but also their relatives have to supplement the amount of money that they pay. I know of many nursing homes in my electorate where this happens. In the electorate of Dunkley I have one of the largest populations of aged people in Victoria. Going down the Mornington Peninsula to the electorate of Flinders, which I also have a bit to do with, I see that there are also many people there who require nursing home accommodation. What has happened in the last five years? In our area there has been quite an increase in the number of nursing home beds. There are more beds to come and more nursing homes are being built. The situation did not change for years and years. The local councils were allowing all these retirement homes to be established on the Mornington Peninsula. The elderly from all over Victoria and interstate were being brought down to that area. Now there is a crisis. We are trying to do something about it. We are trying to assist all elderly and frail aged people. By undertaking this review-it is only a review and it will be reassessed in 12 months-we are trying to make a better system. We are trying to get rid of those unscrupulous operators within the nursing home industry. It is an industry. Many people have made millions of dollars out of nursing homes. They will continue to make many millions. However, there are many well run nursing homes. There are many charitable and church homes which are run not only at a loss to the charity or church but also in a way which benefits the patients.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The debate is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: PASSENGER MOTOR VEHICLE PLAN: MID-TERM REVIEW

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In May 1984 the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, announced in the Senate a new policy package for Australia's passenger motor vehicle industry. That plan was an early and major initiative by this Government to begin the process of change, renewal and revitalisation of Australia's manufacturing sector. We faced at that time a profound sense of pessimism and lack of direction which had come to permeate our motor vehicle industry. Through the passenger motor vehicle plan the Government sought to encourage confidence where there had been uncertainty. We sought to foster a shared strategic vision after a decade of crisis containment. The plan set out to take an important Australian industry in difficulty into a position of competitive strength in the 1990s. The plan was from the outset a key element of the Government's approach to industry policy. It was established to provide the framework for the necessary transition from a high cost domestically oriented industry towards a more competitive, internationally oriented industry supplying Australians-and the world-with better quality automotive products at more reasonable prices.

SPEECH.PARA: The agenda for the industry in the 1990s set the following long term objectives: the industry needed to be able to prosper, with lower levels of government assistance; it must provide consumers with quality products, at reduced prices in real terms; the necessary restructuring needed to be carried out with minimum levels of disruption. While most though not all of these objectives are being met, they remain the objectives which the Government seeks to achieve through its passenger motor vehicle policy.

To allow us to achieve the objectives we set up the Automotive Industry Authority (AIA) and asked it to embark on a strategy with the following elements: rationalisation of the industry in terms of models and manufacturing groups; an increase in the competitiveness of the industry to become an area of strength of the Australian economy rather than weakness; arrangements to accomplish the changes with minimum disruption and cost.

These strategies remain as relevant today as they were in 1984 and the industry, with the active participation of the AIA, has made substantial progress in implementing these strategies. After only three years there has been major rationalisation of producers. Holden's and Toyota are to enter into a joint manufacturing venture, while Nissan and Ford are investigating ways in which they too can integrate their manufacturing activities. By the end of next year it is expected that the number of models produced in Australia will have reduced from 13 to eight. Average volume per model will have increased from 25,000 units to over 40,000. Automotive exports reached $755m in 1987, an increase of $290m or 63 per cent over the previous year. This is almost double the level of 1984. Other export programs which are planned or about to be implemented promise a continuation of this growth in dollar terms over the next two or three years. Investment has also increased sharply. For example, in the vehicle sector, investment has risen from an average of $194m per annum in the period 1982 to 1984 to $503m per annum in the period 1985 to 1987. This shows confidence in the viability of Australian car manufacture into the next century. In the past four years, the industry has embraced the challenge of restructuring, in spite of a very weak vehicle market. The plan has enabled this to happen without major disruption to the people employed in it, with one notable exception: the closing down overnight of the Besco battery plant in Sydney. Even where there have been plant rationalisations to improve overall efficiency, these have been achieved with long term planning, and significant consultation with the work force.

The terms of the plan have always provided for a mid-term review of its progress. That review has been carried out by the Automotive Industry Authority with the aim of ensuring that the plan's mechanisms are continuing to reinforce that strategy and promote achievement of the objectives as we move towards the 1990s. The review found that while good progress had been made there was room for improvement. It concluded that the better competitive environment for the Australian industry now enabled some acceleration of the original plan provisions to ensure that the incentives for adjustment are maintained. The review also found that there was room for improvement, particularly in the objective of achieving more affordable cars for consumers.

The level of prices of local production is a real concern to the Government. The initial plan had as an objective a reduction in real prices over time. This objective remains. The Australian consumer deserves to receive benefit as soon as possible, given the level of assistance afforded this industry. Resulting from that review, the recommendations made by the Authority and consultation with the industry and its unions is a series of adjustments to the mechanisms of the plan to ensure that the plan remains on track and the objectives are achieved by 1992.

The primary objective of the decisions announced today is to reinforce the original plan framework. But there is a secondary objective. The Government is also taking the opportunity provided by the improved competitive position of the Australian industry to ease the passage of the industry into the post-plan environment from 1993. An abrupt shift in the policy environment at the end of the Plan would be in no-one's interest. The Government had considered announcing this decision in the May statement but due to the potential impact on the motor vehicle market of delaying the announcement we have decided it should be released without delay. I now turn to the specific refinements to the plan decided by the Government. Details are provided in an accompanying paper.
Quota/Tariffs

The major unforeseeable change since 1984 has been the fall in the value of the Australian dollar. International competitive pressure on the Australian car industry has slackened considerably. The Government intends to reassert that pressure in several ways to restore the incentives for change originally envisaged. First, from today tariff quota protection for the Australian industry is abolished. These quotas, which have been in place in some form since 1975 were not to have been finally withdrawn until 1992. This decision will be recognised in Australia and abroad as a milestone for an industry getting back on its feet. In taking this historic decision the Government noted that this was a further demonstration of Australia's commitment to the current round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations.

Second, tariff rates are to be reduced faster and further than originally announced. From today, the operative tariff of 57.5 per cent is to be reduced to 45 per cent. There will be further annual reductions from 1989 leading to a rate of 35 per cent in 1992. To retain competitive relativities, tariffs on light commercial vehicles and four-wheel drives are to be reduced immediately from 35 per cent and 25 per cent respectively to 20 per cent and will then be phased to 15 per cent by 1992. The Government is pleased that these reductions will be a direct and immediate contribution to containing costs for business and farmers.
Local Content

The Government has given particular attention to the local content arrangements of the current plan. As a result of the plan's stability, the depreciation of the Australian dollar particularly against the Japanese yen, and the 85 per cent local content scheme, the Australian component producers have found themselves in a very competitive position compared with imports. In addition there has been extensive company rationalisation which has created a significant number of sole suppliers in this sector of the industry. While some components companies have taken advantage of these benefits to improve their general performance, a significant number have not. This lack of performance has come about because this sector has tended to experience less adjustment pressure from the plan than other areas of the industry. The components sector should be subject to the same pressure for change as other parts of the industry. This will be achieved within the framework of the 85 per cent local content scheme.

The system of prohibitive compounding penalties imposed on plan producers for non-achievement of the 85 per cent local content target will be removed. They will be replaced from 1 January 1989 by a less stringent system of non-compounding penalties on imported content in excess of the 15 per cent duty free concession available to plan producers. Beginning in 1989, these penalties will be the same as the duty rates applying to passenger motor vehicles. The additional flexibility to be provided to plan producers by this measure will add to the competitive pressure on component suppliers.
Export Facilitation

The aims of the export facilitation arrangements of the plan are to facilitate product rationalisation and to reduce component costs in Australia, as well as to open doors for exports of vehicles and components in their own right. The car plan seeks to give the Australian industry every opportunity to join in the increasingly integrated global market for vehicles and vehicle components.

The Government values, the export facilitation arrangements and the achievements which have already flowed from them. Major overseas markets have been prised open where they would otherwise have remained closed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just like oysters.

—Or better than that. It is incredible to think that we are now exporting motor vehicles to Japan, engines to Germany and so on. This is a remarkable achievement. Production runs for certain components have been increased towards world scale. Export facilitation will continue to be a feature of the car plan.

SPEECH.PARA: Details of the changes proposed are in the accompanying paper. In essence, there will be an expansion of the available credits of 5 per cent, although these will only be earned at 50c of export credits for each dollar of exports. The changes we have made in this area partly restore the effect of this scheme envisaged in 1984.
International Trading Practices

The Government is committed to ensuring that the Australian industry not be disadvantaged by unfair trading practices by exporters to Australia. Accordingly, Senator Button and I have instructed the Automotive Industry Authority and the Australian Customs Service to intensify surveillance.
Monitoring and Review

These adjustments to the plan have been designed to re-establish the competitive circumstances for the Australian industry originally envisaged in the plan. The Government does not expect, therefore, that there will be serious disruption of production or employment as a result of the adjustments. Nevertheless, Senator Button has instructed the Automotive Industry Authority to monitor and report to him on the impact of the adjustments.
Post-plan Review

Consistent with the Government's concern to provide a stable environment for longer term industry planning, I am confirming today the Government's intention to provide reasonable notice of the environment to be faced by the industry after the plan ends in 1992. To provide the necessary period of notice, the Government envisages that a reference would be sent to the Industries Assistance Commission in 1991, for consideration by the Government early in 1992. However, it should be clear from the nature of the changes I have announced today that the present plan-as adjusted-is very much a transitional mechanism designed from the outset to enable our automotive sector to move from the difficulties of the 1970s to a less protected, more open environment in the 1990s.
New Zealand

The Government is conscious of the potential implications of these changes for trans-Tasman rationalisation. The changes to motor vehicle arrangements in New Zealand recently announced by the New Zealand Government may have corresponding importance. Accordingly, Senator Button has spoken with David Caygill, our counterpart in New Zealand, and we have agreed to begin immediate discussions between officials about a range of issues.
Implementation Arrangements
Legislation will be necessary to effect the changes in tariff rates. The Government will be introducing the changes in the context of a Customs Tariff Amendment Bill as a matter of urgency.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another one.
—We look for the co-operation of the Opposition. Alterations to administrative arrangements will be published in a forthcoming Australian Customs notice.

SPEECH.PARA: Conclusion

In 1984, Senator Button announced a policy for this industry which set clear goals, and a means to achieve those goals. The automotive industry has accepted the challenges I put before it in 1984. Restructuring is taking place without significant disruption. Exports are increasing significantly. The industry has been investing heavily to enable it to compete with reduced levels of assistance.

The measures announced today ensure that all we have so far achieved is not lost. In addition, it creates the right environment to achieve those aspects of the plan which have not yet been realised. I present the following paper:
Mid-term review of the car plan-Ministerial statement including attachment, dated 13 April 1988.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The paper brought forward by the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), on behalf of the Government, is welcomed by the Opposition. However, I cannot help but wonder what prompted the Government to act. The Minister in his statement said that the major unforeseeable change since the implementation of the plan in 1984 has been the fall in the Australian dollar. That fall occurred in 1986. Two years later the penny has started to drop about what is going on in the car market. During that time we have noticed that sales of motor vehicles have declined to the levels of the early 1960s. One of the prime reasons for this has been changes to the fringe benefits tax and to other areas. The industry's figures show that about 447,000 new motor vehicles were sold in 1987-about 250,000 fewer than in 1985. Does that reflect well on the car plan?

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister's statement makes reference to the unforeseen circumstances of the devaluation in 1986. However, this was not caused by anything but a loss of confidence in the Government's ability to handle foreign debt when overseas people sold the Australian dollar. That was triggered by the remarkable exercise involving the MX missile which at the time really shook confidence and forced the dollar down. As a consequence of that, increasing amounts of protection were given to Australian motor vehicle manufacturers. This happened at the time when imported motor vehicles became so much more expensive. One might have thought that in this environment there would certainly be a competitive push on the Australian produced car price. What happened? Instead of that, the cost of the Australian produced Laser motor vehicle, for example, went up by nearly 60 per cent in the period between 1984 and 1987. During the same period, the price of the popular family car, the Ford Falcon, which now starts at $20,000, went up by some 43 per cent.
I draw the attention of the House to the opening comment of the Minister:
The agenda for the industry in the 1990s set the following long term objectives:
One of the objectives is:
. . . it must provide consumers with quality products, at reduced prices in real terms;

I invite honourable members to try to weigh up the Minister's comment with the facts. Just to choose a couple of cars at random, there has been an increase in the price of a Ford Falcon of 43 per cent and an increase in the price of the Laser of 60 per cent. At the same time, car prices in the last two years have increased at about double the rate of the consumer price index. There has been a 20 per cent discount in car sales in the last two years. It now takes an Australian worker on average weekly earnings 46 weeks of wages to buy a standard Commodore compared with 39 weeks as recently as 1985. I invite the Minister to address those questions because they reflect that the plan has not worked in terms of the criteria set down by him in the paper. He needs to look at what is going on and the Government's response.

Just before Christmas a debate on tariffs was under way in the Australian Labor Party. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) said, `Let us cut tariffs by 25 per cent across the board'. After Christmas, he was followed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), who talked about a 20 per cent cut across the board. Then I noted that the Caucus structural review committee-I do not know what factions are involved in that-talked about a cut of some 15 per cent. There has been quite a picnic going on. I do not know which one the Government is going to adopt-25 per cent, 20 per cent or 15 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to talk about the Liberal Party in a minute?

—I am going to talk about the Labor Party. On top of that, the Kerin plan on structural change came out today. All of these things should have been addressed when devaluation occurred in 1986. Two years later we are gradually getting around to them.
—Just as the dollar goes up.

—As the honourable member for Farrer says, just as the dollar is going up. That is great timing! It is almost as good a timing as the by-elections we have just had. As a consequence of those acts by the Government, I cannot help but wonder what it is attempting to achieve. Firstly, consumers should benefit from the decrease in tariff levels on passenger motor vehicles as they move from 57 1/2 per cent to 45 per cent and eventually, in 1992, to 35 per cent. At last the consumer might get a go. Under the old rules the Australian market was divided-that is, 80 per cent for the Australian domestic product and 20 per cent for imports. Because of the devaluation, fully made up imported cars have decreased to about 5 or 7 per cent of the market. So a big deal is made about knocking out the quotas, but there was no longer a premium to buy those cars. No-one could buy them because of the devaluation. The pricing factor came into it. As the level of imported cars went up, we took away the pressure on the domestic product. As a consequence, we have seen a rise in the price of a Falcon or a Laser. Secondly, the Government does not get many bonus points for the fact that tariff quotas will be abolished altogether. Effectively they have already been abolished because of the movement in terms of devaluation.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, tariffs on light commercial vehicles and four-wheel drives are to be reduced immediately from 35 per cent and 25 per cent respectively to 20 per cent, phasing down to 15 per cent. That will come as a major relief to the primary sector and those involved in rural and mining areas. Those items have become very expensive in the last couple of years. In the consideration of the post-1984 plan by the previous Government, it was thought that a four-wheel drive vehicle might be a suitable substitute for a sedan car. That is no longer the case because the pricing mechanism put the four-wheel drive out of reach. Those vehicles became far too expensive and campuses are no longer blocked with four-wheel drive vehicles. They are probably the domain only of those few yuppies who are left after the share market crash.

Fourthly, from the beginning of next year, the 85 per cent local content regulation will be relaxed because penalties for non-compliance will not be so stringent. That is the only area that puts some pressure on local producers. The Government has caved in to pressure from small component manufacturers. Many of those manufacturers are in marginal electorates held by the Government, and that is why the Government has not addressed the question. The Australian manufacturer is required to use 85 per cent Australian content and 15 per cent imported content-imported duty free. The Government provides for export facilitation, which allows adjustment of those figures. However, the 15 per cent duty free import has been affected by devaluation. The Minister may not be aware of it, but between 1986 and today the price of an imported engine for use in putting together, say, a Toyota has doubled. Australia has had a good market for the export of engines, but there are also some imports in that area. Those percentage requirements could well have been adjusted to make the area more competitive. Instead, the Government has taken the soft options of the continuing shambles: it has removed the compounding penalty and imposed a simple penalty. If people wish to go beyond the 85 per cent, they pay a simple penalty rather than a stiff penalty. The Government is thereby continuing to encourage the non-competitive situation of some local component manufacturers.

Fifthly, there is to be export facilitation. That is a worthy step with which I would agree. The export facilitation package was brought in by the late Sir Phillip Lynch. It was welcomed by manufacturers, particularly General Motors-Holden's Ltd, because it was able to step up production lines and aim those products overseas, thereby reducing the marginal cost of the unit. That package was well received in the manufacturing area.

I now turn to two other matters which go beyond the five changes in stage 2 of the car plan announced by the Minister in his statement. Firstly, the stage 2 plan is notable for the fact that it contains very few trade-offs, the only one being some reduction in local content requirements. Secondly, there is absolutely no comment on the question of deregulation of the labour market. If we are to achieve some efficiencies in the car manufacturing industry, those areas must be addressed. Fiddling with percentages will not force results because the compelling elements will not be there.

On behalf of the Opposition, I say that the plan and its general direction is welcome. It provides for a reduction in tariffs and acknowledges that we have to live in the real world. It points to the fact that when we afford very large elements of protection, the Australian consumer ends up footing the bill. The requirement set out in the statement that the consumer should benefit has not been met. That has been demonstrated by the price of cars and by the fact that it takes more working days to buy a car today than it did two years ago. For a person on average weekly earnings it takes five more weeks to buy a car today than it did two years ago.

Living standards have fallen enormously under Labor. That is why Labor's results were so bad in the by-elections, and they will get worse. In the end, falling living standards will put the Government out on its neck because it has not addressed the question. That is reflected in the car industry. Sales are down because living standards are down, while the cost of the average car has increased. In addition, there has been no attempt to come to grips with the issues. The Government has deferred most of the options. We believe that, while the general direction is correct, the ultimate outcome is short of the mark. Many of these plans seem to present difficulties in terms of administration. In opposition it is hard to make a judgment on exact figures unless one has access to the Authority's programs. If those programs were made available to the public or to the Opposition, I am quite sure that a more realistic assessment could be made. In the short term I have to say that the program put forward is welcome, despite its many shortcomings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), who has just spoken, demonstrated quite conclusively that the Opposition has learnt absolutely nothing from the destruction of Australian manufacturing industry that took place during the latter part of its tenure of office. There was an overvalued currency resulting in the decimation of large sections of Australian manufacturing. It does not seem to have learnt anything from that experience. The honourable member bemoaned the fact that the value of the Australian dollar had fallen. That was portrayed as a terrible thing and a sign of poor economic management on the part of the Government. In actual fact, the key result that has flowed from the depreciation of the Australian dollar so far as the passenger vehicle industry is concerned is a 30 per cent improvement in international competitiveness. That, in turn, has created an environment in which, firstly, there has been a major growth in exports of passenger motor vehicles, as well as a range of other manufactured goods, and secondly, a climate in which it is seen to be tenable for major car manufacturers to undergo a substantial investment program.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition might regard that as of no great consequence. The long term potential that gives to create a viable industry, to create employment in the long term, and to provide an economic structure where employment growth can occur over the long term is obviously not important to the Opposition, but the Government thinks it is important. The honourable member's comments show that the Opposition has not progressed much over the last few years. Almost all sections of the Australian community have come to recognise that a viable manufacturing base is an essential prerequisite to turning around our balance of payments problems and securing continued growth in living standards.

The previous speaker also began by posing the rhetorical question of what caused the Government to undertake this review at this time. He said that the exchange rate depreciated from 1985-86 and asked why something had not been done before this. The simple answer is that the Government has an approach to industry policy which hinges on trying to create a climate of predictability and stability for those involved in the industry, those on the labour side and also the major manufacturers, where they can look ahead and make decisions based on a reasonable level of medium term certainty of expectations.

The mid-term review was part of the original plan. It was envisaged as a mid-term review, not something that would take place after the first year of the plan's operation. Obviously the Government determined that it was desirable to have a stable and predictable protection regime for a reasonable time and then, after that time, in accordance with a preordained plan, conduct a review of the arrangements. That is precisely what has been done. That broad approach has been vindicated by the results not only of this industry plan but also of the other industry plans that the Government has implemented or is in the process of implementing.

At the time the car plan was implemented there was a pervasive mood of pessimism throughout the car industry and there were some suggestions of very substantial employment losses and a very major collapse of production and capacity in that industry. That was the fear or expectation at that time. There was also the fear that such an occurrence would be a disaster for the economy. The motor vehicle sector is a key part of Australia's manufacturing activity. As I said earlier, the preservation of a viable manufacturing base is crucial for our economic future.

There is a school of thought that as an economy evolves there is a gradual shift, first from agriculture to secondary industries and then, over time, a gradual movement into the services and tertiary sector, and that that is a natural and reasonable sort of thing to happen. The claim is made that many people on the Labor side of politics attach excessive weight to the need to preserve a manufacturing base. Those views basically are misconceived. If we look at the shift between sectors-the movement from blue collar-type activities into services and so forth-there is not just an intersectoral shift from manufacturing to services; there is also a significant intrasectoral shift where a great deal of the information technology effectively is an input into the manufacturing process. I refer to such things as computer-aided design and manufacturing. There is an increase in white collar, highly skilled, information-oriented activities within the manufacturing sector as well as a shift from manufacturing into these other areas. That is a key point. A lot of that sort of activity is dependent on the continued existence of a viable manufacturing base.

It is hard to see how we could have an industry engaged in the design of motor vehicles without there being a viable motor vehicle manufacturing activity. So the preservation of a viable motor vehicle industry is crucial. That is the Government's view but the previous speaker made it perfectly clear that it is not really an Opposition priority.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish!

—The previous speaker lamented the fall in the value of the Australian dollar which is an absolute prerequisite for the preservation and regeneration of Australian manufacturing. The honourable member says that is rubbish but the previous speaker belies that interjection. It is not just my opinion. I add that the motor vehicle sector has also been in the forefront of the introduction of a number of key technologies that, again, are essential to sustaining a viable manufacturing base outside the motor vehicle industry. Such things as total quality control and `just in time' techniques are things for which the motor vehicle industry has provided the cutting edge but they have an applicability that goes well beyond the motor vehicle industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is conducting a mid-term review in accordance with its preordained plan. The key change over the last few years, as the previous speaker said, is the fall in the Australian dollar. So far as the motor vehicle industry is concerned, the most crucial part of that is the fall of our dollar compared with the yen. As a result we have seen a 30 per cent increase in effective protection for the motor vehicle industry. That was not originally expected to occur. In some sense it represents a windfall competitive gain for the motor vehicle industry. That has had an impact on prices. Unfortunately, some motor vehicle manufacturers have chosen to take advantage of that improved change in the exchange rate relativity to reap the benefits of higher prices, without seeking to compete in the price area. That is a major deficiency and is something the Government is seeking to address by these changes in the protection regime. It will try to put a bit more pressure on both domestic car manufacturers and the component manufacturers through changes in local content requirements, the abolition of tariff quotas, the reduction in the general level of tariff and so on. The idea is to bring about some downward pressure on motor vehicle prices and put a bit more pressure on the manufacturers of cars and components to try to get them to compete effectively in the price area. A consequence of this mid-term review has been an attempt to address the problem that the previous speaker referred to, but to try to do it in an orderly fashion as part of a predetermined review rather than throwing the carefully negotiated plan out the window after the first year of its operation.

On the competitive gain flowing from the devaluation, according to calculations carried out by the Bureau of Industry Economics, if we were to reduce tariff levels in such a way as to completely compensate for the competitive gain that has come from the devaluation and try to get the industry back to the competitive position it faced in 1984-or we expected it to face in 1984-we would be looking apparently at an end point tariff of around 10 per cent, compared with the 35 per cent envisaged in the plan. Even if we look at the possibility of a 25 per cent appreciation in the exchange rate between the Australian dollar and the yen over the next four years, to get back to what would have been a reasonable expectation in 1984 the implied tariff rate would have been 25 per cent, compared with the Government's revised tariff level post-1992 of 35 per cent. So whichever way we look at it there is a pretty substantial safety margin.

The change in the protection regime that has been carried out is broadly consistent with meeting the reasonable expectations of potential manufacturing investors at the beginning of the plan. So what is being done is reasonable. The one-off drop is fairly large admittedly-from 57 1/2 per cent to 45 per cent, followed by several years of incremental reductions of 2 1/2 per cent per annum down to 35 per cent. The initial drop is quite large but when we look at the overall picture I think that what is being done is not unreasonable. I would be rather surprised to hear a strong reaction of concern from the manufacturers or unions.

There is a contrast so far as this tariff cut is concerned between this industry and the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) industry. At the moment we are looking at the possibility of across the board tariff cuts. There was some speculation that the TCF industry could be included. I would be concerned about that although I am not so concerned about this instance because the TCF plan was negotiated in the latter part of 1986 after the major devaluation of the currency had taken place. There is nothing analogous to the windfall competitive gain that has flowed to the motor vehicle industry as a result of the 35 per cent drop in the value of the Australian dollar since the plan was originally introduced. There is a significant difference. Speaking personally, I should be rather concerned to see a significant tariff cut impact in the textiles, clothing and footwear industry at this time when it is at the beginning of a negotiated phased reduction in protection levels which has been arduously negotiated over a period of time.

There are a number of other points that one could make but I shall conclude by saying, as is clear, that the motor vehicle industry has had difficulties during the past couple of years. Despite those difficulties a significant element of restructuring has taken place in accordance with this plan. We have seen a significant rationalisation in the industry, a reduction in the number of manufacturers and models, big investment programs, and a shift towards exports. These are all matters that the effects of the plan sought to bring about. The evidence is that the plan has been very successful. However, for a variety of reasons, we have had a period of depression in the local motor vehicle industry.

I believe it is most important that the effects flowing from a change in a protection regime of this sort should be monitored very carefully. In effect, the Government has committed itself to doing that, by instructing the Automotive Industry Authority to examine carefully the impact on employment and other consequences of this change in the tariff protection regime. Generally, the Government has attempted to act to avoid too large a change in the protection regime because of the destabilising effect that it would have. Hopefully, as the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) pointed out in his speech, the impact of these changes should not be too severe. It is critical, however, that there be a thorough monitoring of effects. I certainly intend to continue to push for that careful monitoring to take place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, 13 April, is a very significant date for the Australian automotive industry. Today tariff rates have been reduced from 57.5 per cent to 45 per cent and will decrease by a further 2.5 per cent per annum to reach 35 per cent in 1992. The tariffs on light commercial vehicles and four-wheel drive vehicles are down today from 35 per cent and 25 per cent respectively, to 20 per cent, and are expected to reduce to 15 per cent by 1992. I must say that I approve of these reductions. From 1 January 1989, in line with the 85 per cent local content provision, there will be no compounding penalties and penalties will be imposed at the same rate as the motor vehicle tariff, which is 45 per cent. We all should be concerned about local content and local manufacture. There have been problems concerning the lack of competitive pressures on component manufacturers and we will have to monitor this situation very closely.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased also that the export facilitation scheme will be expanded by an additional 5 per cent. I note too that the Minister in his statement made some reference to other export programs that are planned or are about to be implemented. The Opposition, as I am sure would the industry, would be pleased to learn what those other programs are that are planned or are about to be implemented.

Interestingly, today the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) said that the level of prices of local production is of real concern to the Government. I inform the Minister and the Government that the level of prices of local production is of real concern to the Australian people also. It is of real concern to the average family, whether in Geelong, Sydney or Coffs Harbour, that wants to buy a new motor vehicle. All Australians are concerned at the prices of locally manufactured vehicles. It may be of interest to honourable members if I reflect on how prices of motor vehicles have risen. On 22 December 1982 the basic automatic Ford Falcon cost $11,737. On 1 December 1985 the price was $14,007. Today the price is $19,758. Of course, to be fair, I must say that changes have been made to the vehicle; it has been upgraded. Nonetheless, the increases in price have been significant. In 1983 the basic automatic Holden Commodore cost $11,795. In 1985 it was priced at $14,226. Today the price is $20,088.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is almost double.

—That can be seen from the percentages that I will provide shortly. The Minister said also that the major unforeseeable change since 1984 has been the fall in the value of the Australian dollar. The Australian dollar fell three or four years ago and it is now going up again. Is this the reason for the timing of the changes that are being implemented now, instead of their being introduced in May in the mini-Budget?

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) made some reference to the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) saying that he lamented the fall in the Australian dollar. That was not so. The honourable member made the same point I have just made. The honourable member for Sydney also made some reference to the Government's desire to create a climate of predictability and stability for those in the industry. I assure the Minister that that is what is required but the Government is encouraging far too much speculation with tariffs, and has done so over a matter of months. Before Christmas the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was blithely talking about a 25 per cent across the board cut in tariffs. Early this year, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) were all flying kites about a 20 per cent cut in tariffs across the board. What they have done is to fuel uncertainty, not just in the motor vehicle industry but in all industries in Australia that are affected by tariffs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially component manufacturers.

—As the honourable member for Farrer says, especially component manufacturers. I am concerned also about other industries. One might well ask: What are those in the textiles clothing and footwear industry wondering? What about the chemical industry? What is it wondering? Are those industries asking: What will happen to us in May? What will the mini-Budget do to us? I think that that is a very strong likelihood. They are concerned about what might be happening to them. I appreciated the comments of the honourable member for Sydney when he expressed his concern for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the significant things about this lack of certainty-and it really is a lack of certainty-is that investment will be held up. For years now we have been discussing the need for Australian manufacturing to get up and going, for our exports to increase and for our manufacturing industries to be more competitive. For that to happen, there has to be investment. If a manufacturing industry proposes to increase its manufacturing capacity, by importing new plant for instance, it is not an easy thing for it to do, new factories and new manufacturing lines are not just created out of thin air. Orders have to be made well in advance. There is a long lead time and the industry needs to know what the tariff situation is going to be. Throughout Australia there is a perception that the Government has not done what it should have done to do away with speculation.

I ask the Minister: How much consultation went on with the industry and unions before the announcements today? The Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia has a good track record. Its members work in a sane and sensible fashion. I wonder whether the Minister has done the right thing with adequate consultation. We in the Opposition support the car plan and its thrust to create competition. But that has not happened. Prices have increased. I repeat: in December 1982 the cost of an automatic Ford Falcon was $11,737. Today the cost is $19,758; a 68 per cent increase. In 1983 the basic automatic Holden Commodore was priced at $11,795. Today the cost is $20,088; an increase of 70 per cent. Those increases make it very difficult for ordinary Australian families to buy a new car. If one is looking at the cars of the Australian people the Holden and the Ford are the basic cars. Of course many other imported cars are very popular, but historically the Ford and the Holden have been the basic Australian cars.

The honourable member for Sydney also mentioned that because of the rise in the dollar local manufacturers were reaping the benefits of higher prices which were related to the cost of imported vehicles.

TALK.START.PARA: —He danced around a bit.

—He did dance around a bit and he laid this charge against local manufacturers. I cannot claim to be totally conversant with the profitability of all Australian vehicle manufacturers but my memory suggests that it is only Ford that is doing particularly well and the rest are not doing well at all. The rest are in need of assistance. They are in need of a boost to profitability. But the honourable member for Sydney said that they have reaped the benefits of higher prices. I do not think that that is correct. The honourable member for Sydney also said that the automotive vehicle industry-and this is a classic piece of understatement-in Australia had been in a period of depression for a variety of reasons. Boy, what a statement! It is more than a period of depression and it is more than a variety of reasons. I would be very pleased to give the Minister some of those reasons. They are quite clear cut. The prices of local manufactured cars have gone up so drastically because of the actions of his Government. They have gone up because of what the world's greatest banana republic Treasurer has done, because of what the Minister has done and because of what his colleagues have done. The prices of locally manufactured cars have gone up to such an extent because of the action of his Government. They have gone up because of interest rates which have been right beyond the pale. They have gone up because of the changes in sales tax. Without any doubt they have gone up because of the fringe benefits tax. They have gone up because--
—Because of interest rates.

—I have already mentioned interest rates. The honourable member should pay more attention. They have gone up because of the collapse of the Australian dollar. Labor's policy has put a new car beyond the reach of many Australians. It is worth noting that car prices have increased by about double the rate of the consumer price index over the last two years. Sales of new motor vehicles have declined to the levels of the early 1960s. This is what the Labor Party and the honourable member for Sydney call a period of depression.

SPEECH.PARA: Sales are down to the levels of the early 1960s. Industry figures show that about 447,000 new motor vehicles were sold in 1987. That is almost 250,000 fewer than in 1985. As a result-and everybody knows it-production of new motor vehicles in this country has declined dramatically. Many jobs have gone. In fact, just in the motor vehicle industry in South Australia between August 1984 and August 1987, 3,000 jobs were lost. That is 3,000 workers in this country who are now without a job because of the uneconomic basis of production, because of the interest rates, because of the sales tax, because of the fringe benefits tax, because of the collapse of the Australian dollar and because of the Treasurer's policies. As well as that, throughout this country motor vehicle dealers have gone to the wall. It is not good enough. What we need is a strong Australian automotive industry, a viable automotive industry, a competitive vehicle industry which produces cars that can be afforded by all Australians. I hope that these measures introduced today by the Minister will help bring that about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motor vehicle plan is an extremely important measure that affects the electors and constituents of Dunkley, because in the area surrounding Dunkley we have a large industry base that supports the Victorian and Australian car industry. We have in Dandenong the General Motors-Holden's Ltd factory. Many of its workers live in the Frankston area. At Westernport we have the Lysaght company, which supplies much of the steel that goes into Australian cars. We have in the electorate of Dunkley itself at Frankston the firm of Yazaki Australia Pty Ltd, which supplies all the wiring looms for every car manufactured in Australia. So I have a great interest in this change to the motor vehicle plan.

SPEECH.PARA: We have not had much time to look at it or to check all the facts, but I know from discussions with the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) this morning that there has been a great deal of consultation between the industry and the unions. I trust that both the industry and the unions will agree with stage 2 of the motor vehicle plan, a plan which has certainly assisted the car industry. It will protect the industry and it will also add a bit more competition. There was some sort of windfall assistance to the Australian manufacturers when there was a devaluation. I do not know whether they increased the prices of their cars because prices for Japanese cars increased considerably.

However, the increase in prices in the domestic market reflects a number of things. I think there are reasons for this increase. First of all, the cars that are manufactured today are of a much better quality than they were a few years ago. They last longer and there is a lessening tendency for people to replace their cars every couple of years. I bought a Ford Falcon two years ago and I will be keeping it for another year or two. The motor is good and it is an excellent car.

There have also been changes in patterns of expenditure. People do not put a lot of money towards buying a car. They use some of their earnings for overseas travel and home improvements. They are buying video recorders, electronic gear and other things for their home. The emphasis is no longer on the private car and this is one of the reasons why people are not buying them continually. Many years ago for some it was a matter of prestige to have a fancy car. I think those days have gone. People use a car as a functional item these days and that is another reason they hang on to them just that little bit longer. That is reflected in the fact that car sales have dropped quite a bit.

In Victoria we are the main base for the car industry. Just recently the Premier, John Cain, was at General Motors-Holden when the millionth engine was exported. That is a tremendous record, and all this has happened in the last few years. It would never have happened under the conservatives in Australia. Had they continued in office the steel industry would have been gone. It was closing down in 1983. I remember when I was first elected going to Lysaghts with the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones). The company was in a desperate state. Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd was going to close everything down. Lysaghts just did not know what to do.

Without a doubt Senator Button and other people within the Government saved the steel industry in Australia. It would have gone if it had been left to the conservatives. They would have imported all our steel. I would say that the same thing would have happened in the car industry. One has only to look at the increase in the number of job vacancies even in one of my local papers, the Frankston Standard. The number of pages of job vacancies has increased from one or two in 1983-84 to four to five. Many of them are in the manufacturing industry and in industries connected with the motor car or steel industries.

We have brought about a climate that will accept some sort of change. We have made certain that our manufacturers in Australia are competitive, that they will be able to compete on the world market. As I said, we have an example of that with the millionth engine being exported. I know that Ford is looking at exporting a sports car to the United States of America in the very near future. I believe General Motors also has plans to be involved on a larger scale in the export market. So there are many good things happening.

This plan will make us more competitive on the world scene, and that is important. I trust there will be some spin-offs for the consumers. The plan should provide better competition and make prices drop a little bit. That is what we are all about, supplying better conditions for the car industry and better conditions for Australian consumers to benefit from lower prices.

I take this opportunity to mention my particular hobbyhorse, that is, the field of robotics. I know Ford has, in a big way, gone into robotising its body and assembly plant. It has installed extensive robotics to make the work easier and have fewer people working in that particular area. For some time I have been talking about a technology tax. However, no-one likes the word `tax' so I change it to technology compensation. Every robot installed does not actually consume anything in our society, but it does take up jobs. Robots are not specific machines; that is, they are not dedicated to a particular task. This is the first time in human history that a machine has been able to do a multitude of tasks and actually take the place of a worker. Some sort of compensation should be paid to the Government, to the unions and the people displaced. That compensation should be vested in some sort of trust fund, and workers displaced by the robots that are starting to be introduced into our society should be retrained in other areas. I have been pushing this particular thesis for some time. I trust that someone will pick it up and do something about it.

As has been stated in this debate, there has been much speculation about tariffs. This plan ends speculation on tariffs in the motor industry. It will be interesting to see the reaction of many in the community to this change to the motor vehicle plan. However, I think the reaction will be good. I trust that those within the industry will see this as a positive step to making certain that Australia is competitive on the world scene and will once again make its mark in the manufacture and export of the motor vehicle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the words of my colleagues the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) and the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl). In so doing I should like to begin by taking up a couple of points made by the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth). I cannot let them pass without some response. From listening to his speech I got the impression it was all excuses, excuses. He lamented the fact that the price of a car had increased dramatically, as was pointed out by the honourable member for Cowper, and that that big rise in the past five years has occurred under the administration of the present Government. Many of the reasons for the price of cars rising dramatically have already been elaborated upon by the honourable member for Cowper. The rise is roughly twice the increase in the consumer price index for the same period, certainly in the last few years. The honourable member seemed to be accepting this, but lamenting it. He pleaded-in hope, I think, rather than any belief-that the change to the tariff structure might lead to cheaper cars. I do not think he really believes that himself. The simple fact is that a car costs considerably more today than it did when this Government first came to power. There are no excuses. The fact is that most of that increase is due to measures that were brought in by this Government, such as the fringe benefits tax and the effects of high interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: I take umbrage at the honourable member's talking about the impact of the steel plan. Much credit has sought to be claimed for the steel plan and what it has done to help the steel industry. I agree that there have been some dramatic improvements in productivity in the steel industry. In fact, in some places, productivity per man employed has roughly doubled. But when one talks to people in the steel industry they admit privately that the biggest impact on saving the steel industry was not the steel plan but the fall in the value of the dollar in 1985. That, more than anything else, saved the steel industry.

The honourable member for Dunkley spoke about robots. I suppose robots have a rather interesting psychological impact. I have no doubt that anyone who sees them working is amazed and can quite clearly see that robots take a lot of jobs from human beings. But, really, it is flat earth thinking from the honourable member to suggest that there should be some special tax on robots because they are displacing people involved in those jobs. The increases in productivity and efficiency allow people to have a higher standard of living, and also allow many other jobs to be created in other areas. This has been proved time and again. I cite an interesting example. No-one was heard to suggest that there should be a special tax on tractors when they were introduced into the agricultural industry many years ago, but tractors probably had a far greater impact on employment and productivity in that industry than robots have done to date in the car industry. But tractors also allowed a dramatic increase in the standard of living of probably all Australians.

I could go on and give many other examples of what increasing output has done. It has increased the living standards of all Australians. Generally, if handled sensibly, technology has allowed those displaced from industry to find jobs elsewhere. The reason they have not been so successful in the last few years has far more to do with the rigid, centralised wage fixing system that exists in Australia today than the introduction of these various types of new technology.

I thought the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) was talking utter nonsense when he said that the Government was very concerned about predictability and stability of the car industry, because it was only just after the car plan was introduced that the value of the dollar fell, and to the lowest level in the living memory of most Australians. The honourable member kept on talking about predictability and stability. Interest rates went up to record levels. Things such as the fringe benefits tax were introduced. All of these things had a massive impact on the car industry. Yet three years later we are told that because the value of the dollar fell there is a good argument for beginning to reduce tariffs. I, like all honourable members, am keen to see tariff protection reduced. I still believe there is quite a lot of resource misallocation because of high tariff protection in some secondary industries.

It is interesting to note-and I know the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table, would agree-that the greatest increases in employment and in production have occurred in manufacturing industries that have the least protection. They also have been the most successful exporters. I shall return to the question of exports and the car industry in a minute.
