We ought to keep these things in perspective and remember which industries are achieving and which industries are being dragged into the twentieth century. The honourable member for Sydney commended the introduction of `total quality control' and `just in time methods'. They are excellent. We would see far more of them in Australia today if it were not for the recalcitrant unions that are still causing problems in industries, particularly export industries, where time and again an exporter is held over the barrel by a union holding up supplies. The cost to Australia and its markets is staggering if one honestly assesses what is happening.

After listening to the honourable member for Sydney quoting figures, comparing costs of cars in 1983 and today, I would have thought he put together an excellent, watertight argument for reducing tariffs to, at the most, 25 per cent and possibly even less.

I should like to make a few general comments about the question of industry protection. Despite this car plan, the bottom line is that the consumer has not really benefited. The figures have already been quoted extensively. One of the simplest measures is that it now takes a worker on average weekly earnings another five weeks of work to pay for a motor car compared with 1983. By any measure, this plan still has not achieved what it really set out to do.

In that context I want to say something about the importance of looking at an economy-wide approach to industry protection. Too often we have seen situations in which an industry is looked at in isolation and not enough attention is paid to the effect on other sectors of the economy, in particular those sectors that have far less protection. I draw the attention of all honourable members to an excellent discussion paper put out by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics in February this year headed `Primary Industry Assistance in an Economy-wide Context'. I think this is probably the first time that the Bureau has put out such a working paper, which obviously was very much to the benefit of the Government in its discussions and its deliberations. There has already been some mention of what the Government is doing in regard to industry protection in general.

The paper points out a fact that should not be forgotten, and all honourable members should be reminded of it: assistance to the motor vehicle industry and to the textiles, clothing and footwear industry contributes around half of the total effect of all assistance to the manufacturing sector on general price levels and on sectorial returns. In other words, in the motor vehicle industry we are talking about one of our most heavily protected industries. While we welcome the reduction, let us not lose sight of the fact that this is a reduction from a very high level of protection. In fact, if we follow through this paper we will find that the effective rates of assistance calculated by the Bureau show a staggering level of protection for the motor vehicle industry in particular. Even back in 1982-83 the effective rate of assistance was calculated to be in excess of 250 per cent of the value. In 1986-87 that figure is still in excess of 250 per cent. I do not know what the figure will be after this reduction in tariffs but obviously it will still be a highly protected industry by any measure. I do not think we should lose sight of that fact.

On the question of protection, much debate is focused on the level of protection that comes through the Budget. Because the Budget and the level of assistance that comes through the Budget are highly visible, it is often easy for people to get the wrong perspective. If we look at the level of budgetary assistance for the manufacturing industry we see that in 1985-86 it was in the order of $320m. It is interesting to compare that with the level of budgetary assistance for agriculture in 1985-86, which was $430m. In fact, if we then look at the net subsidy equivalent of the assistance to agriculture and manufacturing we get a very different picture. Taking the same year, 1985-86, the net subsidy equivalent of the assistance to manufacturing was nearly $6,477m compared to $699m for agriculture. In other words, there was ten times as much assistance for the manufacturing industries as there was for the agricultural industries.

I think it is important to make this point: the figures I cited earlier show that if one looks purely at budgetary assistance it would appear that in fact agriculture gets more assistance. However, when one looks at the overall picture one finds a very different story. I would like also to draw the attention of honourable members to an article that appeared yesterday on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald and which talked about what the Government may or may not be doing in regard to assistance right across the industry range. It really is a quite amazing article. No doubt some of it comes from very good sources. If the article is taken to be correct, the Government is still prepared to hit agriculture far more heavily than it hits the manufacturing industry. I say that particularly in relation to the statement made today by the Minister about a sensible, albeit rather small, reduction in support and tariff protection for the motor vehicle industry.

I would like also to touch on the area of export facilitation, about which much was made. The Minister was very quick to talk about automotive exports and how they have increased faster than exports from any other major area of manufacturing. He went on to say that this rate of growth was expected to continue for some time. I draw the attention of honourable members to an excellent publication put out last year by the Centre for International Economics. The main author of the paper, entitled `The Game Plan: Successful Strategies for Australian Trade', was Dr Stoeckel, well known to many people as the former Director of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. Dr Stoeckel draws some excellent suggestions for improving our exports and our trade performance. In one section he talks about improving exports of motor cars and tells a very interesting little story which I think should be drawn to the attention of all honourable members. He talks about what some of these export incentives really can do, about the so-called manufacturing surge in exports, and about the export of engines, about which we have been hearing and to which the honourable member for Dunkley referred. He went on to say:

Australian cars are being exported to Japan-of all places! Perhaps these cars are being driven around by the Japanese but more likely they are sitting in warehouses doing nothing. After all, these cars have already completed a good life's work for their manufacturers, having earned them valuable export credits-credits paid for-
I ask honourable members to take note-
by Australian car buyers and taxpayers.
This may be another reason, of which people may not be aware, why the cost of cars is going up. He goes on:

Astounding as this story is, it makes sad sense of a riddle involving our car industry-how can a highly protected industry apparently become so competitive? Our car industry is an industry which can barely compete for Australian buyers even with the help of huge protection and yet it can suddenly take on the world's best, Japan. The explanation is that . . . there is a scheme which can subsidise these exports to the tune of almost 30 per cent of export value.

Briefly here is what happens. In Australian car manufacture, 85 per cent of the car components are required to be locally made (the local content scheme); that is pretty hard on Australian manufacturers as local components are expensive by world standards-

I see that my time is running out, so I had better get to the point. As Peter Robinson reported in the Australian Financial Review of 7 July last year, if every car exported from Australia is to be subsidised to the tune of $10,000-that is what he has estimated it to be-then the proposed export target of 40,000 units will cost Australia a staggering $400m. I draw that figure to the attention of honourable members because it is significant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond very quickly to one or two of the points that have been raised. The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) said that he would like some details by the time the debate concluded about other export programs which are planned or about to be implemented, referred to in my speech. The explanation for that phrase, which perhaps could have been rephrased to advantage, is that the companies involved in the car plan, such as the Ford Motor Co., have their own plans for the export of cars. It is not as though there are secret plans that are not ready for disclosure. I want to make that absolutely clear.

SPEECH.PARA: I will follow up a couple of other points. It is simply a matter of restating, as the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) and the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) put it, that when we came to office both the motor vehicle industry and the steel industry were in a state of crisis. Their survival was put in question.

It is, I think, one of the most significant achievements of this Government that these industries now have considerably stronger long-term projections than they had in 1983. That is true of other areas as well. Obviously the textiles, clothing and footwear industry looks stronger and more viable than it did in 1983. The mid-term report on what we have achieved in passenger motor vehicles since the plan first came into operation in 1984 stands up very well.

It must be conceded that there is one fundamental difference in our situation with the motor industry and our export prospects. In the motor industry, Ford, General Motors, Nissan, Toyota and Mitsubishi all have in common brand names not automatically recognisable as being Australian. Nobody seeing a Ford or Mitsubishi motor car driving around automatically says, `Ah! That must be an Australian product'. That is our great difficulty. We lack that sense of Australian identity-the sense of identity that the Swedes have with Volvo, Saabs and Scania trucks. Sweden is a notable example of a country which developed an international reputation for quality, held that reputation, but maintained that sense of national identity.

In many areas of manufacturing we need to learn that many nations do not export on price alone. In some ways we have been obsessed with price. We have not done anything like enough to develop the notion of quality and that rather mysterious quality called `reputation'. A tremendous amount of international exporting is done on the basis of reputation, and quality. That is the great lesson that we must teach industry. If we are to survive as a manufacturing nation, it is essential that that lesson be learned and enforced. We have a long way to go. I thank all honourable members for their contributions to this discussion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Beazley) agreed to:
That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the notice lodged by Mr White relating to disallowance of Statutory Rules 1988, No. 17 being called on forthwith.
Motion for Disallowance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the regulation repealing the Australian Rifle Club Regulations as contained in Statutory Rules 1988 No. 17, made under the Defence Act 1903, be disallowed.

These regulations which the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) seeks to repeal relate to rifle clubs and associations throughout Australia. It is quite clear that the Government wants to weasel out of its responsibilities in relation to these rifle clubs and associations. It is not clear why it wants to do this because no one has provided me with a satisfactory explanation. The fact is that since 1903 the Federal Government has had a responsibility for the supervision of these clubs and associations-some 500 clubs with some 8,000 members throughout Australia. Why the Government would want to abrogate its responsibilities in this regard I simply do not know. For the Government to say in a statement that it is no longer appropriate for the defence organisation to be involved in these affairs seems to me entirely inappropriate. Nothing could be more appropriate to the Department of Defence and the Minister for Defence than to make sure that every effort is made to increase the defence preparedness of the civilian population of this country. If this can be done at practically no cost whatsoever to the Commonwealth, by providing this umbrella of supervision for rifle clubs throughout the country, I would think that was a very sensible way to go.

By repealing these regulations, the Federal Government would virtually be handing the control of these clubs and associations back to the States. The Opposition is very much opposed to that and I am pleased to say that the Australian Democrats are also opposed to that course of action. If the repeal of these regulations is not blocked in the House of Representatives, it will almost certainly be blocked in the Senate. It is an abandonment of the Government's responsibilities to hand these clubs back to the States and it is part of a sell-off pattern that in recent years has been typical of this Government's approach to defence facilities and land. The Government has already sold, or is in the process of selling, the rifle range at Williamstown. It is trying to sell the Anzac Rifle Range in Sydney. The New South Wales Rifle Association has taken the Government to court, and rightly so. I understand that it will take some 18 months for that matter to be resolved one way or the other. If I were a developer interested in dealing with the Government over the Anzac Rifle Range, I would be very wary indeed.

Also, in relation to the Government's efforts to flog off these ranges the question arises of compensation to those clubs and associations which have their facilities on those ranges. That does not seem to have been decided in any way at all. It is not just a matter of rifle ranges which the Federal Government wishes to dispose of. We have seen the fiasco of the Sydney foreshore land prior to and during the last New South Wales election. The Federal Government would not answer queries on this matter and seemed determined to flog off foreshore land around Sydney Harbour, particularly at Balmoral. It would have been an absolute tragedy if that land had been sold off to developers for a few million dollars in order to fill the Government's coffers. This is prime foreshore land and everyone involved wanted that land to go to the Sydney Harbour National Park. The former Minister for Planning and Environment in the Unsworth Government, Mr Carr-a great protectionist-was strangely mute on the subject. We are all very grateful that Mr Carr is not now in any position to influence events. The new New South Wales Government has made it very clear that it will not participate in rezoning or the provision of services for that land. Perhaps during this debate the Minister will indicate the Government's present approach to that land at Balmoral and to other land that it has been trying to sell in recent times.

There is the question of Victoria Barracks in Melbourne and other defence land. The point is that once the Government gets rid of these assets it will never get them back. If the land is not in use at the moment, the time will come when some of it-perhaps not all of it-will be required. Flogging off defence assets in order to get money in the coffers is a disgrace. If these regulations are repealed, as the Government proposes, some of the land on which these ranges are located-some of it is leased land and some of it is owned by the Commonwealth-will be handed over to the States. The States will put pressure on the clubs and the clubs will not be able to sustain that sort of pressure, so for one reason or another the land will become vacant and no doubt it will be sold off as well.

I wish to run briefly through the sequence of events of this mess. Order No. 56 was proclaimed to repeal these regulations. It left out any consideration of the small bore shooters and it penalised the owners of semi-automatic and automatic weapons. The Minister does not seem to realise that military shooting is also carried out on these ranges with semi-automatic weapons. These are skills that we want to develop. It is all very well to have a grand academic view of Australia's defence, but the fact is that Australian Army defence is based on one infantry division in which there are six battalions of infantry soldiers as a core force. It is absolute nonsense to try to convince anyone that rifle shooting with single shot, semi-automatic or automatic weapons is a skill which, in the view of the Government, we do not wish to encourage. Why would the Government deny people the facility to improve their skills, to learn to handle arms as an adjunct to our defence preparedness? It is absolutely beyond us on this side of the House why the Government would want to give all of this away to the States.

For some reason which no-one understands, the Government has tried to limit ownership to four guns. As far as I know, one can shoot with only one gun at one time. So why does it matter how many one owns? Order No. 56 was obviously a mess. Order No. 66, which was brought forward on 4 March, included the Small Bore Association and lifted restrictions on the four-weapon limit. It also very sensibly lifted restrictions on semi-automatic weapons. But this interim order was issued for only six months to give a breathing space to the rifle clubs and associations before the State governments wished to put the squeeze on them. At the end of six months these bodies were cast adrift. They were given no protection and the whole thing was going to be a fait accompli.

I wrote to the Minister asking for some discussions. We attempted to get some discussion going to establish whether there was some good reason for the handover of these clubs or the repeal of the regulations. We would have helped if this had been in the interests of Australian defence, Australian shooters, sensible gun control and people learning how to use weapons. I received no answer. On 24 March I was briefed by two officials. This was after the Australian Democrats had been briefed first in a futile attempt to get them to support the Government on the issue. The Government cannot say that we did not try to come to some reasonable arrangement. I still do not know to this day why the Government wants to get rid of the rifle ranges.

It is clearly a Commonwealth responsibility to encourage people to learn to shoot and to handle arms. This is an important adjunct to our defence preparedness. The Minister's academic view of big ticket capital equipment items and his neglect of people and the basic military skills that go to make up a defence force are beyond understanding. For the Government to say that it is no longer appropriate for the Department of Defence or the defence organisation to be involved in rifle ranges is incredible. We have had a long tradition of drawing on skills which have been developed in civilian clubs. We wish to maintain that tradition.

We must also address the question of where the defence personnel themselves, the members of the various units who use these rifle ranges, are going to go. It is quite clear that the clubs are not going to be able to continue if the Government repeals these regulations. I would hope that the Government realises that the States have different safety regulations. Their templates are entirely different. In fact, some of them are twice as big as the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) standards under which these clubs operate. There is also no doubt that the States, which do not have a defence responsibility, will put the squeeze on these clubs and associations and force them out. Rifle clubs do not have the resources to move. They do not have the money to acquire new land within reasonable reach of their members. People would be discouraged from going to rifle clubs if land were purchased a long way from towns and established centres.

The States do not have a national interest in this matter. They do not have a responsibility to make sure that these ranges continue to operate. The NATO regulations which apply to rifle ranges seem to be entirely adequate. I have never heard any complaints that they are unsafe. Why should the clubs be forced into a situation where they cannot exist? There is also a problem in terms of the disparity between States. National associations will have difficulty in conducting national shoots across State boundaries as well as in the transference of arms.

I believe that in the context of the current debate on gun laws a very serious problem will arise if rifle ranges cease to exist, and this will happen if they are handed back to the States to administer. People who have been encouraged to join rifle clubs and associations and who wish to shoot-and there are a lot of them-will simply have nowhere to go. They will simply be forced to rampage around the bush as too many people do at present. Would it not be much more sensible to provide facilities and encourage these people to go to clubs and associations and learn to shoot and handle arms properly?

Nothing would give us honourable members on this side greater horror than to have to hand over rifle ranges to, for example, the Victorian Government, which is absolutely determined to wipe out anyone who has a sensible interest in shooting. The clubs would be left to the mercy of the Victorian Government. Thank God we have avoided that in New South Wales, which had the same approach until the last election. The then Government realised too late what a fool it was making of itself.

The Opposition's aim is to ensure that the clubs and associations are encouraged and maintained. We want to ensure that there are opportunities for people to learn to shoot and handle arms. This is important to our defence effort. We believe that this Government is weak for opting out for reasons which are not clear and which have never been explained. We see this as an important national responsibility. To abrogate that responsibility is to weaken our defence effort, which is weak enough at the moment.

Yesterday the Chief of the Naval Staff produced a paper to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which is looking at wastage from the Services. He again said that his operational capabilities have been eroded, that he cannot meet his responsibilities and that he needs another 1,200 men. We know the situation in the Royal Australian Air Force. For example, the fighter squadron in Darwin has seven pilots. The Minister for Defence gave the weak excuse that the rest of them are being trained. I thought that it would have been of fundamental importance to keep the one fighter squadron in Australia up to an operational level while a new one is being trained to take over.

Just recently the commander of the 1st Division of the Army asked for 4,000 men. The Minister came into the chamber today and pranced and posed while talking about the Opposition's defence policy on nuclear ships. He would be better off looking to his own responsibilities. It is to his everlasting disgrace that he has never looked properly at the nuclear option. He is frightened that all of that mob in the corner on his side will open up that debate to his detriment. We intend to look at that; we intend to look at it properly.

What I have just outlined shows that under this Government the operational capabilities of our defence forces are steadily declining. It is absolutely beyond us why the Government would abrogate a further responsibility for something that is costing us nothing by handing over rifle ranges that are used to develop the basic skills that have been so helpful in past conflicts and in keeping our defence forces strong. We look forward to hearing some explanation from the Minister on this matter. For our part, we intend to oppose the repeal of these regulations. With the support of the Australian Democrats in the Senate, I am sure that that opposition is going to be successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and wish to speak forthwith in accordance with the arrangements worked out between the Government and the Opposition.
—The honourable member for Farrer may proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully support the motion ably moved by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White). The motion deals with a regulation that was drawn up by the Government as a knee-jerk reaction, as an overkill and as an uncoordinated and ill considered response. Frankly, the Government's regulation is fundamentally objectionable.

SPEECH.PARA: Having had some experience in the Army, I like to think ahead and anticipate what the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) might say when he gets to his feet to respond in a few minutes time. I suppose one of the things that he might trot out by way of response is that the Opposition, by taking this attitude, is trampling on State rights and the rights of the New South Wales, Victoria and other governments to proceed down particular paths with regard to rifle shooting associations and the like. I want to fortify what the honourable member for McPherson said in the course of this debate by quoting parts of our great Constitution. It makes it very clear that the provision of defence rests with the Australian Government. Section 68 states:
The command in chief of the naval and military forces of the Commonwealth is vested in the Governor-General as the Queen's representative.
Section 69 states:

On a date or dates to be proclaimed by the Governor-General after the establishment of the Commonwealth the following departments of the public service in each State shall become transferred to the Commonwealth-
Posts, telegraphs, and telephones:
Naval and military defence:
Lighthouses, lightships, beacons and buoys:
Quarantine.

Elsewhere in the Constitution it reiterates the Federal Government's fundamental role in defence. What this debate before the House deals with is the acceptance of that responsibility by the Federal Government, albeit the acceptance of what some would contend is a relatively detailed aspect of that responsibility. It is a vital ingredient in our overall defence capability, particularly our Reserve capability, as it provides a practical way in which members of the community can boost their weaponry skills in a realistic, reasonable and practical manner. The Opposition has taken a very responsible approach. We will study with interest what the Minister for Defence has to say. Clearly, the Australian Democrats are thinking about the matter again, as instanced by the Minister's interjection during this debate. He will not know which way the Democrats will jump on this or on any other issue until it actually comes down to the wire in the Senate. I hasten to say that there is nothing new about that. We will see what the Democrats do at the final moment when the equivalent debate takes place in another House.

This motion for the disallowance of regulations comes before the House the day after the Victorian State Government caved in on gun laws. The heading `Cain caves in on gun laws' appeared on the front page of today's edition of the Border Morning Mail which is published in Albury-Wodonga in my electorate of Farrer. That is what has happened. The Cain Government in Victoria has finally started to come to its senses regarding gun laws. At the same time as it is coming to its senses, the Federal Government is proceeding with a matter which stemmed from a boil-over reaction to the immediate situation in November and December and the gun summit in December when, suddenly, bureaucrats were asked to cast around for things that the Federal Government could do on the guns issue. The Minister went to his Department-probably fairly quickly-and, as is his wont, probably demanded some option papers and action within the Federal Government scope regarding the gun laws issue which was raging very strongly at that time, and still is, across the community. So the boffins, at some level or other, in the Department of Defence produced this little gem.

We have caught the Government out with this little gem. This little gem should be tested on the floor of the House and on the floor of the Senate. It should be discussed, debated, explained and considered on the floor of the House and on the floor of the Senate before the Government is allowed to get away with its somewhat complicated provisions. So complicated were those provisions that, as the honourable member for McPherson pointed out, in the very drafting of them, the Government managed to get it wrong and it had to come back with additional phraseology, additional regulations, to alter the thrust of its original regulations.

In terms of the consideration of the guns issue in the Federal Parliament, I wish to place on record the unbelievable reaction in the community at large to removing the right of law-abiding citizens to own a gun, to go to a rifle range and fire a weapon on a Saturday or whenever in proper and safe working conditions, to go recreational shooting and to use a weapon as law-abiding citizens, in a safe and secure way. I think that the Australian Labor Party across the nation, particularly at the New South Wales State level, was so out of touch with its own grass roots and its own blue collar workers that it jumped down the path of this gun issue the wrong way without consulting its own grass roots. Hundreds of blue collar workers in Albury and the capital cities across Australia were absolutely devastated that their Labor Government intended to take unilateral action against law-abiding citizens who wished to be law-abiding sporting shooters in our community. Of course, there has been a proper outcry against the massacres which, sadly, have occurred. I think I would enjoy the support of all honourable members in deploring the use of guns on aircraft in hijacking situations, which are absolutely horrific and deserve universal condemnation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both of the weapons that were used were illegal.

—The weapons used in the Hoddle Street massacre were illegal under existing legislation. That shows that the laws that were in operation at that time were not impacting on the situation which unfolded in the horrific Hoddle Street massacre. In many ways, the whole attitude of the Federal Labor Government, the ex-New South Wales State Labor Government and other Labor governments on guns has been out of touch with the grass roots and the reasonable thinking, law-abiding citizen, be he a blue collar worker, a white collar worker or an elector in the electorate of Cook, Farrer or beyond.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that it is germane to quote in this context what Senator Richardson said on 21 March 1988. He said that the Labor Party had `forgotten what the common people are all about'. He said, `We don't understand them any more'. That is what Senator Richardson said about the Labor Party. On the same day, former Premier Unsworth said:
I suppose if they-
that is, the working class-
see their leadership dressed in black tie, smoking cigars, hobnobbing with representatives of capitalism, they might question where the party is going.
A member of this House, who is having difficulty in finding this House of late-I refer to a former Minister of the Crown-said on 21 March 1988:

The perception is that too many people have been extraordinarily arrogant, and it's not just people in Cabinet, including Hawke himself. A little humility would go a long way. There's too many egos. Too many politicians think they're invincible. Who the hell do they think they are?
The honourable member for Robertson (Mr Barry Cohen) gave that little gem to the community at large.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was when he was an ex-Minister.

—As an ex-Minister and present backbencher, he is now deliberating on his resignation date from this Parliament. What all those quotes demonstrate, and I think that they are relevant to this debate, is that the Labor Party is so out of touch that it failed to recognise the proper and legitimate aspirations of its own grass roots supporters with regard to being able to exercise properly their right to go sporting shooting should they desire to do so and their right to carry on normal activity as law-abiding citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to say that I helped to organise and participated in one of the largest ever public meetings held at Albury which saw some 2,000-plus citizens reject totally Labor's approach on gun laws, both State and Federally. I might add that the massive swings against State Labor members in southern New South Wales were greatly related to the guns issue and cost the Labor Party the seats of Albury, Burrinjuck, Monaro and Bega-to name just four seats. I accept that in acting on this issue it is not just a matter of straight political gain or otherwise. That should be only a part of the consideration of the Government and the Cabinet. The whole priority surely should be to get the right approach with regard to gun laws. So the Government called a national summit on this issue and there was State and Federal participation.

The approach the Federal Government took at that national summit was united and co- ordinated. That is what the Government was seeking at that meeting in December. At the same time, it has now gone down the path with these regulations of a quite contrary approach, to push emphasis back to the State level with regard to rifle club associations, the ranges, safety and template requirements and the like, and to provide a variation of approach which could be six different approaches at the State level with no consistent national approach. So the Government, with these regulations, is doing the very opposite of what it set out to do last December when it sought national consensus and a national approach on gun laws. The House and the nation should be aware of that and the Minister should address that in his response to this disallowance motion before the Parliament.

The Government, in hindsight, would have liked not to have proceeded with this regulation. The Government is somewhat embarrassed, particularly with the Cain Government caving in on gun laws, at now having to defend its regulations especially as it might now recognise that not only will that wreck a consistent national approach, but, as the honourable member for McPherson has properly mentioned, it will further reduce our defence capability in a very practical and meaningful way. For those reasons I second the motion ably moved by the honourable member for McPherson. I believe that the House, in the absence of any concrete information put by the Government to the honourable member for McPherson, should take this action as part of a responsible approach to getting the right gun laws in place at the State and Federal level and to getting the right regulations in place under the Defence Act. It should be absolutely certain that the gun law outcome will be satisfactory and that the regulations finally determined are determined by this Parliament and relate to the requirements of the community at large.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the suggested repeal of the regulation that we have brought into being. As usual in these situations where regulation is involved it seems that the Opposition has not necessarily thought through all the implications for the people whose interests it is supposed to be defending when it presents its arguments. It is another case of the Opposition yet again wandering off half-cocked on a defence matter, wishing to make a point without having a systematic study of the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition spokesman on defence, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), did not realise how ludicrous he was when he criticised me for having an interest in the equipment of our armed forces, suggesting that this distracted me from the minutiae I ought to be concerned with, at the same time that he was loudly advocating that we really need to get into billion dollar nuclear-powered aircraft carriers and cruisers. There is area for argument but it is a slightly ludicrous juxtaposition. A further ludicrous comment from the representative of the National Party who spoke in this debate on the basis of a 20 per cent swing against his Party, lecturing us on whether we were in touch with the grass roots. We have suffered no 20 per cent swings against us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you forgetting Adelaide and Port Adelaide?

—There was not a 20 per cent swing in Adelaide. The National Party put up an argument on the basis of having just witnessed that appalling charade in Melbourne when the Liberal Party spun on the spit of trying to rid itself of the overweening influence of its millionaire mate-which it simply cannot do. Harold Wilson once said that a week is a long time in politics. The last two weeks have indicated aptly the very sound warning of Harold Wilson to politicians when they contemplate their future in the long haul.

SPEECH.PARA: Several points need to be made. Historically, rifle clubs were treated as part of the defence resource at the time these regulations initially were brought into being. That happened for a very simple reason. At that time rifle clubs were given a specific defence task. They were not used to train people to shoot but the people were employed as vulnerable point guards and as cable guards. There was a direct relationship between a particular defence function and the functions of rifle clubs. As, over time, rifle clubs came into a position of obviously being sporting associations-and we do not condemn them as sporting associations; we support them-governments considered that supporting them was no longer appropriate.

The most dramatic step to this point-and this was only the final step in a process initiated then-occurred in 1959 under the Menzies Government when that Government decided that a process of disengagement and progressive removal of Commonwealth support of rifle clubs should begin. This was not advice based on a response to what the Premier of Victoria might have been doing at the time had the Menzies Government looked at that; it was a result of advice from the professional military to the Menzies Government that this is what should occur. The professional military said that the rifle club movement had no defence value. Whatever value it may have had in terms of sporting activities-where I think it has very great value-as far as the Department of Defence was concerned, and as an absorber of defence resources, the military in 1959 said to Menzies, `The clubs have no defence value'. So Menzies started to put in process the uncoupling of Commonwealth defence support from the rifle clubs.

The Menzies Government decided to withdraw direct financial support from the rifle club movement and to separate rifle clubs from Commonwealth association. That separation was to be achieved by 1965. In 1962 the Government only partially reversed that earlier decision and agreed to an association on a revised basis. Since the late 1970s there have been further moves towards disengagement of the rifle club movement from the Commonwealth. Agreement was reached for repeal of the Australian Rifle Club Regulations leaving the movement responsible for its activities under the framework of the National Rifle Association of Australia.

All these activities have been taking place under the auspices of Liberal governments on the advice of their military advisers. The military advisers told them at the time that it was not appropriate under the Defence Act for these activities to continue. The Opposition needs to contemplate that. It also needs to contemplate the position that has been achieved since then because unfortunately considerable misnomers operate among our rifle clubs and in the Opposition as to the legal protection that rifle clubs now have. Rifle clubs effectively have been operating outside the framework of strict Commonwealth approval, under this legislation.

There is and has been to this point goodwill on the part of Commonwealth and State authorities and individuals such as nearby residents who may be affected by rifle club activities. Ours is not a litigious society. No-one has sought to challenge the implications of the fact that the Commonwealth is not enforcing regulations but is having them effectively enforced by the process I have outlined-that is, the generous attitude that the Commonwealth has had to the issue of enforcement. I suppose in the contemporary atmosphere it is possible for State governments and citizens to call enforcement into question. If it is called into question, the possibility is that individuals will be at risk. I am sure that none of us would want to see that situation develop. Fortunately, the regulations we have introduced, which provide for that interim arrangement, have cured that situation.

I shall take this matter a point further because I am sure members of rifle clubs do not understand the exemption. In both the generous and the strict interpretations, exemption from State licensing requirements means just that: an exemption from State licensing requirements. If weapons prohibited by the States are held by a rifle club member no exemption exists. That matter is not well understood among members of rifle clubs, and they will be afforded no protection in that regard. The Opposition has raised the matter of templates associated with the operation of the ranges. That issue is not caught up in this debate. I happen to have considerable sympathy for the view of rifle clubs so far as the templates that would be imposed upon them are concerned. Rifle clubs are not, however, protected by this particular ordinance so far as that matter is concerned; they are protected by other interests of the Commonwealth.

I am willing to use what authority the Government has to protect the interests of rifle clubs concerning templates. In relation to this and other associated matters, before they are considered in the Senate, I am prepared to have discussions with rifle clubs. In the course of action proposed by the Opposition, rifle clubs are potentially placing themselves at risk. This is an area of legislative mess which, after that initial pristine pure decision, if you like, by the Menzies Government to uncouple the relationship and the development of appropriate regulations associated with them, the various compromises that have been arrived at have put rifle clubs in a position whereby they would be at some degree of risk if a nasty-minded individual were to seek to deal with this matter in legalistic fashion.

I am willing to discuss with rifle clubs in good faith how their various problems in this regard may be overcome. I do not believe the problems will be overcome, but were the Opposition to have its way in the Senate, in a contemporary environment the fat might well be in the fire. The disposal of ranges is a decision, unrelated to these matters, that the Commonwealth can make at any time it desires, whether or not the regulations are in place. However, that does not mean that such decisions are arrived at easily. The Government is prepared to get rid of ranges in cases when it is appropriate to do so.

According to the Opposition's defence spokesman, the Department of Defence may not rid itself of any unwanted property. This is now the position of the Opposition spokesman. That is an unusual stance to take, particularly as his Leader wanders around the place saying, `Yes, of course we will rationalise Commonwealth functions. Yes, of course, we will dispose of Commonwealth assets that we do not need'. When one bears in mind that the Department of Defence is responsible for, I understand, about 80 per cent of Commonwealth-owned property, it seems a bit of a nonsense that on the one hand the Leader of the Opposition says, `We will go through Commonwealth assets with an efficient broom and rid ourselves of things we do not need', and on the other hand the Opposition spokesman on defence, who technically would be responsible for about 80 per cent of those assets, wanders in here and says, `Look, we will not get rid of any defence land because you never know when you may need it'. It creates something of a problem.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has his problems with his front bench; we all understand that. They have to be gagged every now and then when they spout forth. After all, the shadow Minister for Defence is a rotating Minister, and if he makes a few commitments between now and when he is rotated in June, perhaps it will not matter that much. He can liberally commit himself to never getting rid of a defence asset, at great cost to the Commonwealth; he can liberally commit himself to buying nuclear powered aircraft carriers. He can do all these sorts of things, and I suppose it does not really matter if he disappears off the political scene two years in advance of the next election. Of course, if the Leader of the Opposition intends to keep the shadow Minister, he will have problems with that substantial list of commitments.

I have indicated that I will make available the representative of the defence function in the Senate to discuss with rifle clubs the various problems that are associated with this. It is not our intention to discourage in any way a legitimate sporting activity associated with weapons. This is simply not a defence function. Prime Minister Menzies did not think it was back in 1959, nor did his military advisers. We are finishing off the process that Menzies began. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original question put:
That the motion (Mr White's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.DATA.PARA: (Mr Deputy Speaker-Hon. J. D. M. Dobie)

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is an omnibus Bill for legislation administered within the primary industries and energy portfolio. Its introduction will facilitate the passage of amendments to existing legislation. The Bill contains minor typographical and administrative amendments to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, Dairy Produce Act 1986, Pig Industry Act 1986 and Rural Industries Research Act 1985; and repeals a redundant Act, the Dairy Industry Act 1967. These amendments will be self-evident and are sufficiently explained in the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill. I propose to confine my comments to addressing the more significant changes which will be made by the Bill.
Canned Fruits Marketing Act 1979-Repeal
Canned Fruits Levy Act 1979-Repeal
Canned Fruits Levy Collection Act 1979-Repeal

The Bill provides for the repeal of the Canned Fruits Marketing Act 1979 and two associated Acts, the Canned Fruits Levy Act 1979 and the Canned Fruits Levy Collection Act 1979. These amendments were foreshadowed in September 1987 in the announcement of the Government's decision on the Industries Assistance Commission Interim Report on Canned Fruit (Statutory Marketing and Interim Assistance Arrangements). Under the Canned Fruits Marketing Act, the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation is empowered to acquire canned deciduous fruit produced in those States where complementary State legislation exists and to market the acquired product in Australia and overseas. In addition, the Corporation operates a pooling scheme whereby returns from gazetted pool markets are equalised and an equalised return is paid to canners.

The Government considers that the canned fruits statutory marketing arrangements have served their purpose of bringing about a degree of stability to the industry. However, the industry now needs to adjust further to changing market circumstances, and the repeal of the legislation will allow for necessary structural adjustment and encourage more innovation. In reaching its decision to wind up the Corporation, the Government has also taken into consideration the possible future relationship of the canned deciduous fruit industry to the Australian Horticultural Corporation, for which legislation has recently been passed. The Government believes that certain functions currently performed by the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation could be transferred to the Australian Horticultural Corporation either directly or on a fee for service basis. These are matters to be decided upon by the industry.
Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977

The purpose of this amendment to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act is to make clear that shipping lines involved in the carriage of meat or livestock on behalf of licensed exporters do not themselves need to hold a meat or livestock export licence. Whilst this has always been the understanding and intention of the legislation, recent legal advice to the Government has indicated that the matter is not beyond doubt and that clarification is therefore desirable. The amendment maintains the status quo, and has the support of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation.
Export Control Act 1982

The amendments will restrict `authorized officers' to persons appointed under section 20 of the Act, will put beyond doubt the power of an authorised officer to take photographs or video tape recordings as evidence of a breach of the Act, will permit the regulations to impose penalty for non-payment of fees and will clarify that the orders can impose penalty for the non-payment of fees but cannot impose penalty for offences against the orders.
Fishing Industry Research and Development Act 1987

This amendment is to place beyond doubt the power of the Fishing Industry Research and Development Council to enter into arrangements with the Department of Primary Industries and Energy for the provision of, and payment for, clerical and administrative services.
Meat Inspection Act 1983

The amendments will permit the regulations to impose penalty for non-payment of fees, will put beyond doubt the power of an authorised officer to take photographs or video tape recordings as evidence of a breach of the Act and will clarify that the orders can impose penalty for the non-payment of fees but cannot impose penalty for offences against the orders.
Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981

The Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981 provides for a regime to allow exploration for, and exploitation of, minerals from the seabed. Administration of this regime will be shared between the States, the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth in accordance with the Offshore Constitutional Settlement of 1979. Although passed in 1981, proclamation of the Act has been held up pending the passage by the States and the Northern Territory of complementary legislation which is necessary before a common regime covering offshore minerals activity can be established. The purpose of this amendment is to remove the current requirement that the States and the Northern Territory pass legislation to authorise their respective Ministers to carry out the day to day administration of offshore minerals activity under the Act. Instead the States and the Northern Territory will be able to authorise their Ministers by administrative action.

The Commonwealth has received expressions of interest from companies seeking to explore the seabed for minerals beyond the three nautical mile territorial sea and the Government does not wish to unduly delay exploration pending the establishment of a common offshore minerals regime. The Commonwealth is therefore considering proclaiming only those portions of the Act as will be sufficient for a regime covering exploration. Once the complementary States and Northern Territory legislation has been enacted the Commonwealth will proclaim the remaining portions of the Act.
Plant Variety Rights Act 1987

Subsection 3 (1) and 3 (7) will be amended to change `public knowledge' to `common knowledge'. The concept of public knowledge requires only one person to know about the new variety whereas common knowledge infers that the variety is known within the trade, that is, by experts in the field. This change is in line with the intent of the Act and will more closely reflect actual practice. Common knowledge is used in plant variety rights legislation overseas and in the International Convention of the Union for the Protection of New Plant Varieties. Australia will now conform to international practice.

Section 46 of the Act will be amended to remunerate all part time members of the Plant Variety Rights Advisory Committee equally. Under the current legislation only two of the six part time members receive Remuneration Tribunal allowances and remuneration. The others receive only Senior Executive Service travel allowances. This is clearly an anomaly as the members all contribute equally to the working of the Committee and were appointed for their expertise and experience in areas specified by the Act. The extra cost involved will be $3,000 per annum, which can be absorbed in the current appropriation.
Wool Marketing Act 1987

Wool tax, paid by woolgrowers into the Market Support Fund, administered by the Australian Wool Corporation for the operation of the wool reserve price scheme, is refunded when market circumstances and the amount in the fund allow. The Bill provides for the Commissioner of Taxation to provide specific information to the Australian Wool Corporation to facilitate the payment of the refunds of wool tax to woolgrowers. These provisions effectively reinstate two paragraphs from the part dealing with refunds in the now repealed Wool Industry Act. It was the original intention that all the administrative procedures relating to refunds should be included in Wool Marketing Regulations. However, advice from the Attorney-General's Department was that delegated legislation could not confer powers over another Commonwealth body. Accordingly these provisions are to be reinstated in the Wool Marketing Act, with the concurrence of the Treasurer (Mr Keating).

Wool is expected to be Australia's major export income earner in 1987-88. To preserve the market dominance of Australian wool and its competitiveness relative to other fibres, everything possible must be done to ensure that wool sold for export meets the quality requirements of buyers. The Australian Wool Corporation has powers under section 74 of the Wool Marketing Act 1987 relating to quality assurance. These provide for the Corporation to prevent the sale, at export auction, of wool which does not meet industry standards. This includes wool which contains unacceptable levels of pesticide residue and wool which has not been classed by a registered wool classer. These powers are limited to the sale of wool at export auctions and do not cover the 20 per cent of the woolclip which is sold outside the auction system. They are also inconsistent with the Corporation's power under section 63 to formulate and secure the adoption of industry standards and terms for the sale of wool at auction or otherwise. Therefore, the amendments will bring the Corporation's powers under both sections of the Act into line and enable it to prevent the sale of wool contaminated with pesticide residues, for export, by private sale as well as through the auctions system. These powers are necessary to ensure that the international reputation of Australian wool is maintained.

The Attorney-General's Department has advised that the present penalty provisions of the Wool Marketing Act and Wool Marketing Regulations are ineffective with respect to the prosecution of corporations. Accordingly the corporate knowledge provisions to the Bill, based on those of section 84 of the Trade Practices Act 1974, have been developed to enable successful prosecution of corporations. Section 127 of the Wool Marketing Act provides for regulations to be made in relation to registration of wool test houses, but not for their inspection. The lack of any legislative authority to inspect test houses, for the purpose of registration or to ensure compliance with approved procedures, could jeopardise the confidence of buyers in the integrity of Australian wool testing and description, with adverse effects on our wool export trade. A regulation making power providing for inspection of wool test houses will therefore be inserted in section 127 of the Act. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Shack) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mrs Kelly, for Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Over the last two years this Labor Government has embarked on a program of major improvements in the quality of administration and decision making in the social security portfolio. This program has dual objectives: to ensure that every Australian resident obtains adequate income support as and when it is needed; and to protect the revenue by ensuring that payments are not directed to those who do not require them. This program has involved major legislative change and significant new administrative arrangements.

There is no area which more fundamentally shows the difference in approach between this Labor Government and the conservative Opposition. Our approach has been, as Professor Fred Gruen recently noted, to `square the circle'. We have substantially increased the real level of pensions, benefit and allowances while reducing the level of social security expenditure as a proportion of gross domestic product. We have done this through close attention to the detail of the administration of each program to maximise the accuracy of social security decision making.

When in Government the conservatives proved themselves incapable of this form of development. In opposition the conservatives have confirmed their approach. They would reduce social security expenditure-but how would they do it? They would do it by wholesale cutting of programs-by denying help to those who need it. They would terminate eligibility for sole-parent pensions when the youngest child turns 10. They would make people who resign a job wait for six months before paying any benefit. They would not pay benefit to sacked people for lengthy periods, not until their redundancy payments were exhausted.

These measures are exactly the sorts of steps this Labor Government will not take. We will continue to improve the standard of living of all those residents of Australia who cannot adequately support themselves. We will do this, while protecting the taxpayers of this country from excessive burdens, by close, hard detailed examination of social security programs and administration. This Bill is a further step in our program of improving the quality of administration and decision making in the social security system.

Last year this Labor Government introduced the family allowance supplement as part of our attack on child poverty. Under this Bill the administration of the family allowance supplement will be improved by refinements to the treatment of lump sums under the income test. People who take leave from employment and are paid in a lump sum rather than during the period will have their payments spread over the period of leave. At present the family allowance supplement may be forfeited if the lump sum is treated as income within the period of receipt. This disadvantages those who receive leave payments in a lump sum compared with those whose leave payments are staggered by their employers. Lump sum education payments will also be spread over the period to which they relate.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —A measure will be introduced to protect student parents who, in 1988, were not aware of their family allowance supplement entitlements until they received education payments. As the education payments may be made in respect of an earlier period, family allowance supplement will be payable to cover this earlier period of entitlement. To obtain these arrears of family allowance supplement the student parents must claim family allowance supplement within six weeks of receipt of the education payments.

SPEECH.PARA: Improvements will also be made to the parental income test on job search allowance. The year of parental income that is tested will be moved forward to the year ending in the month of June in the previous financial year rather than the month of June in the previous calendar year. This will assist in ensuring that the level of payment is more closely aligned to real need. Where a parent is a social security recipient the parental income test will not apply.

This Bill contains measures to improve the administration and integrity of compensation recovery provisions. Where a person receives personal injury compensation that makes up for lost income the Social Security Act provides that pension or benefit may be reduced or recovered. This is one way in which social security expenditures are directed to those most in need.

Settlements of lump sum compensation particularly in the workers compensation jurisdiction are being manipulated to obscure the economic loss component and to avoid recovery of social security payments. To prevent this abuse the Minister announced on 8 February 1988 that, for future personal injury settlements made by agreement or by consent order, 50 per cent of lump sum compensation will be deemed to be in respect of economic loss. This Bill gives effect to that proposal. Where, on the other hand, a court has made an order after a contested hearing specifying the economic loss component, the Secretary to the Department will continue to have regard to the characterisation given to the award by the court.

To improve consistency in the treatment of income of social security recipients the Bill proposes to exempt German restitution payments from the definition of income under the Act. This will ensure that payments from West Germany made by way of compensation for nazi persecution are not treated as income. Only those payments expressly paid for lost income will continue to count as income.

The rules preventing payment of arrears of sickness benefit to those who have failed to lodge their claim within the necessary time limits will be modified to accommodate those whose incapacity has prevented them from lodging their claim in time. Up to four weeks arrears from the date of claim will be payable in such cases. This will ensure that the very ill have access to four weeks arrears just as those who are able to claim shortly after the date of their incapacity. In recognition of the care required by a disabled child who attracts child disability allowance, a sole parent will not lose his or her entitlement to sole parent's pension when that child turns 16 years of age.

Other measures contained in this Bill clarify provisions in the Social Security Act or close gaps remaining from amendments enacted last year. Asset limits for married beneficiaries under the benefits assets test have been clarified. Previously the benefits assets test for a married beneficiary was linked to the pension assets test. Where only one spouse was in receipt of benefit but claimed additional benefit for a dependent spouse this resulted in a limit that was half the combined married limit. The assets limits in these cases will now be twice the sum available to each individual spouse under the pensions assets test.

The residence requirements for children who attract additional pension and benefit for their parents have been adjusted to reflect the particular residential status of special beneficiaries and non-Australian residents with portable pensions. Sickness beneficiaries or their spouses who temporarily leave Australia, for example to seek medical treatment abroad, will be permitted to continue to receive sickness benefit or to attract additional benefit for up to three months of their absence. Finally, to complement the introduction of supported employment services under the Disability Services Act 1986, sheltered employment allowance will be available to disabled people who are employed in these services.

The Social Security Act is amended regularly in the interests of good administrative practice and to improve the efficiency of the services provided to clients. This Bill will ensure that these aims continue to be served. I commend this Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Porter) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mrs Kelly, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to enable the application to members of the Defence Force of the 3 per cent productivity superannuation benefit. This benefit flows on from the June 1986 decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on this subject. Because there are complex superannuation issues involved in the application of the benefit to the government employment area the final form of the benefit has not yet been decided.

In applying the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's decision to the Public Service and to the Defence Force it was found that, because of factors peculiar to the Defence Force, there would need to be differences in matters of detail in the application of the scheme to the Defence Force and the Public Service. These differences include:
There is only one `employer'-if I may use that expression-for the Defence Force as distinct from the many employers in the Public Service sector.
The Defence Force scheme does not apply to part time service.
The Defence Force scheme has to have regard to concepts in the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973 which differ from those in the Superannuation Act 1976.
The Defence Force scheme has to have regard to the conditions of service peculiar to the Defence Force.
The Defence Force has a centralised pay system.

As the scheme is an interim one and will shortly be replaced by a permanent scheme, it is proposed to empower the Minister for Defence to determine details of the scheme and to provide that any determinations made by him are to be subject to the usual tabling and disallowance provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

The Bill sets out guidelines that the Minister will be required to have regard to in making a determination. These are: the decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the scheme for the Public Service as set out in the Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Bill 1988, the terms and conditions of service of members of the Defence Force and the arrangements for the administration of the Defence Force.
