PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 March, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Excise Tariff Proposals Nos 7 to 10 (1987) and Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 14 to 17 were introduced in September last year. It has always been a bit of a mystery as to why they were not dealt with on the one occasion; they are still going on in bits and pieces. The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1988 relates to the oil market and the excise on liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and avgas. In the case of the oil industry, the Government moved to a deregulated crude oil market from 1 January 1988. As a consequence of this the six-monthly adjustments to the consumer price indexed excise will be removed. As a move to that position the adjustments made in October and December 1987 will be the last associated with the indexed excise payment. From here on in the Government will move to collect its excise at the consumer rather than the producer end. I hope this does not mean that the garage proprietors, operators or lessees of Australia will become yet another government taxing base. I well remember the Treasurer (Mr Keating) talking about the tax gathering potential of this legislation when it was first introduced. I have not noticed any propensity on the part of the Government to reduce any of these taxes. In fact it indexes them every six months in order to give them a good kick along. The recollection process of the Government on other occasions is somewhat amiss.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the changes in this legislation, it is interesting to note that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), making some observations about oil pricing in Australia, recently said that he hoped for some reduction in `our phenomenal petrol prices'. I say, `Hear, hear!', as will every motorist, every rural user and every commercial user of oil and petrol products in Australia. They will welcome that move enormously. But there is no reason to assume that under the current arrangement that will be the case, unless the world price of oil deteriorates very sharply. Oil prices are still subject to the Prices Surveillance Authority. I remember that when the Prices Justification Tribunal was about-a legacy of the Whitlam days-I moved to abandon that particular body. However, the then Minister responsible said, `Oh no, we cannot do that, we have to have an authority'. A number of price changes were quarantined in order to establish this Authority. I doubt whether the Authority's ability to judge oil prices today is any better than it was in those days. Trying to weigh up the accuracy of some of the statements from representatives of the oil industry is quite a job.

The second part of the legislation concerns the excise paid on liquefied petroleum gas. Here there is a change in the pricing policy because import parity pricing is no longer to be related. Instead there is to be a weighted average of the prices received for exports and local sales of LPG during the preceding six months. Again, this means an increase of about $8.19 a kilolitre. This increase in excise rates is expected to raise an additional $9.5m to the Government's surplus. That is not too bad, considering that the previous adjustment changeover yielded $55m.

The third part of the legislation relates to aviation gasoline-avgas. In this case negotiations were carried out between the aviation authorities and the users of light aircraft in the general aviation area to effect an increase in the price of avgas rather than to pay the landing fees normally attracted by this area. This proposal is identified with the airports at Essendon, Coolangatta and Launceston and the change took effect from 1 January 1988. It is an agreement between the Government and the general aviation sector as it relates to those three airports and adds an extra 0.5c per litre at the bowser for avgas. Obviously, general aviation users do not use the resources that are pertinent to major airports such as Mascot and Tullamarine. I am glad that the Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris) has acceded to this desirable request because it makes a lot of sense. I have been asked particularly to note that the Launceston Aero Club is still concerned about this matter because it appears that in its area negotiations have not come to fruition at this time. The Opposition will not oppose the proposals in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1988. This Bill addresses four major areas of the petroleum product industry. These are: excise duty on liquefied petroleum gas (LPG); excise on aviation gasoline (avgas); import parity price adjustments; and limitation of excise indexation to around 6 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill amends the Excise Tariff Act of 1921 and implements the Government's policy of deregulation of the petroleum industry. It is important as a background to this Bill to reflect on the impact on petroleum product prices and excise rates since the deregulation of crude oil marketing. The excise rate for naturally occurring LPG is adjusted six monthly on 1 April and 1 October each year in accordance with the Government's previously announced LPG excise policy. The formula used to calculate the rate is based on the six monthly weighted average of prices received for export and local sales of LPG.

The excise rate is set at 60 per cent of the amount by which the realised price for naturally occurring LPG exceeds $147 a tonne, expressed as a rate per kilolitre. The increase in the excise rate reflects higher export prices for LPG for the relevant six monthly period-that is, for the October 1987 adjustment, this was the period from 1 March 1987 to 31 August 1987. The increase in the excise rate from 1 October 1987 reflects higher export prices for LPG.

The Saudi Arabian Government's selling price for propane, on which Australian export prices are based, was increased by $US10 to $US125 a tonne on 1 March 1987 and has remained at that level over the pricing period. This increase in the excise rate is estimated to lead to an increase of $9.5m in excise receipts on the production of naturally occurring LPG in 1987-88.

Following consultations with the major general aviation associations early in 1987, the Government introduced in July last year revised general aviation avgas aircraft charging arrangements in the form of a fuel excise surcharge. The major industry associations unanimously supported this charging arrangement. The fuel excise surcharge was applied to all general aviation avgas operators, irrespective of the airport at which they landed. In addition, such operators faced a landing charge, that is, a charge comprising three components, at all Federal Airport Corporation primary airports-the capital city airports as well as Coolangatta, Launceston, and Essendon. The three components of the charge were an airport facility component for runway, terminal buildings, car parks, baggage handling and other facilities; a terminal navigation component for air traffic control; and a rescue and firefighting component.

The question of exemption from landing charges for avgas aircraft at Coolangatta, Launceston and Essendon was raised in the course of consultations with the industry prior to the introduction of the avgas surcharge. However, as this would have meant a higher level of surcharge for all operators, the associations did not pursue this proposal in July last year. Following the introduction of the new charging arrangements, objections were raised by operators of avgas aircraft at these three airports, on the grounds that there was a disparity in treatment when compared with their competitors at general aviation secondary airports. Operators at these three airports incurred the general excise surcharge plus landing charges whereas the users of general aviation secondary airports incurred only the surcharge-that is, there were no landing charges.

The extent of this disparity was not foreseen by either the industry associations, the Department or the Government at the time the new charging arrangements were put into place. As a result, the Government indicated that it was prepared to reconsider the position in respect of these three airports once the views of the major associations were provided. The industry associations were not unanimous in their approach to this problem. However, those associations, representing by far the majority of general aviation operators, supported the proposal to replace Commonwealth Government charges at these three airports with an increased avgas surcharge. This surcharge of an additional 0.5c per litre on avgas excise and customs tariff duty replaces the terminal navigation and rescue and firefighting service charges, which are the two components of landing charges which are levied by the Commonwealth.

The Government has adopted this proposal. These components of the landing charge were removed from 1 January 1988 and avgas excise was increased accordingly from that date. During consultations on these issues, the Government indicated to the industry associations that no action could be taken with respect to the airport facility component at these airports, since these are Federal Airport Corporation airports. The appropriate levels of charges for this function is a matter for the Corporation. This approach is accepted by the industry association.

As a result of the Government's decision to discontinue offsetting excise adjustments, there has in effect been no adjustment to the excise rates on petroleum products since deregulation of the crude oil market as of 1 January 1988 except for the consumer price index indexation which took effect on 3 February 1988. Consumers have, therefore, reaped the benefits of crude oil price falls resulting from the deregulation of the crude oil market. In this regard, the Prices Surveillance Authority recently announced a 2c per litre reduction in the maximum wholesale price of petrol with effect from 10 February 1988.

The Government changed its policy of offsetting excise adjustments because in comparison with the widely fluctuating oil market which dominated most of 1986 when the policy of offsetting adjustments was introduced, the oil market is now more stable than was previously the case, giving more certainty to government revenues. In any case, to continue a policy of offsetting excise adjustments would be difficult in the absence of the import parity pricing mechanism and inappropriate in the new free market environment. However, the Government will continue to monitor oil prices closely with a view to protecting Commonwealth revenue in the case of a sizeable fall in world oil prices or reducing the inflationary impact should there be a sizeable rise in prices.

During his address to the National Press Club in March last year, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made a commitment to place a ceiling on excise rate indexation increases in 1987-88. The Prime Minister said:

The Commonwealth pledges that it will generally restrict the increase in our excises which would otherwise have occurred at the next two half-yearly indexation adjustments to a total of around 6 per cent.

That commitment has been met. It was fulfilled in a manner such as to cause the least disruption to the existing indexation arrangements. This was achieved by applying the normal indexation arrangements for the August 1987 adjustment which resulted in a 3.5 per cent increase. The February 1988 adjustment was subjected to a 2.5 per cent ceiling. The August and February increases, when combined, came to a sum of around 6 per cent. Whilst this procedure has resulted in an increase in the rate of excise of 6.0872 per cent over the year to February 1988, this is well in line with the Prime Minister's commitment to limit the excise increase to around 6 per cent.

I would like to draw the House's attention to the financial impact of these amendments. First, I refer to liquefied petroleum gas. The 1 October 1987 increase in the excise rate for naturally occurring LPG is estimated to result in an increase of $9.5m in excise receipts in 1987-88.

Secondly, I refer to the import parity pricing policy. The alterations in refined petroleum product excise rates due to the change in the import parity prices will result in increased revenue of about $121m in refined petroleum product excise rates effective from 17 October 1987 and decreased revenue of about $66m in refined petroleum product excise rates effective from 14 December 1987. The changes in the excise rates following these changes to import parity prices are intended to offset exactly the forecast changes in revenue from crude oil excise and royalties.

Thirdly, I draw the House's attention to the aviation gasoline surcharge. The measure has no direct financial implications as it has been designed only to recover the revenue which will be foregone by the Commonwealth as a result of the removal of the terminal navigation and the rescue and firefighting components of the landing charges levies at Essendon, Coolangatta, and Launceston airports. Aircraft using avgas ceased to be charged for these services from 1 January this year, the date of effect of the surcharge.

Finally, I refer to the limitation of total excise indexation to around 6 per cent. The financial impact of imposing a 6 per cent ceiling on excise duty rate increases for 1987-88 is estimated to result in revenue forgone of $25m for that financial year. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable members for their contribution to the debate which began, as the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) pointed out, a long time ago. I just take up a point which the honourable member made about the import parity price adjustments and the effect on petroleum product prices. What has happened to petroleum product prices and excise rates since the deregulation of crude oil marketing? As a result of the Government's decision to discontinue offsetting excise adjustments, there has been, in effect, no adjustment to the excise rates on petroleum products since deregulation of the crude oil market as of 1 January 1988, except for the consumer price index indexation which took effect on 3 February 1988. So, consumers have therefore reaped the benefits of crude oil price falls resulting from deregulation of the crude oil market. In this regard, the Prices Surveillance Authority recently announced a 2c per litre reduction in the maximum wholesale price of petrol with effect from 10 February 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that as we seem to have debates on this matter fairly frequently, it is useful to have an update as to where Australia stands in comparative fuel prices. It has been suggested that this could be called the Bruce Goodluck biannual survey on fuel prices. I have some valuable material on indicative international retail prices for Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries and non-OECD countries. With your concurrence, Madam Speaker, I suggest that the table be incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I point out that Australia actually ranks fourth of the 16 OECD countries that are listed. The survey lists the prices in Australian cents per litre that is paid for automotive gasoline. The price in Australia was 56c, in the United States of America 43c and Turkey 36c. In Canada where the equivalent in Australian cents is slightly lower, the price was 54c. But the cost is extraordinarily high in countries like Italy where the price is 153c per litre and Japan where it is 135c per litre. The list includes many Third World countries in which the price is sometimes considerably lower than in ours. Not surprisingly, the price in Kuwait is only 21c per litre and the price in Egypt is 19c per litre. India has a punitively high rate of 80c per litre. The table also includes figures for automotive diesel oil. I thank honourable members for their contribution to the debate and commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Barry Jones) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: BOUNTY AND SUBSIDY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 March, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill he now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second Bill in this group-the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill 1988-gives effect to two amendments which the Government proposes in relation to tractors and book bounties. Firstly, I would like to say something in relation to tractors. There has been a long history of protection in relation to the manufacture of tractors and farming equipment in Australia. The Government's decision to terminate the Bounty Agricultural Tractors and Equipment Act 1985 was made in the last Budget. With the termination of that legislation, we have seen the virtual closure of the tractor industry in Australia. The well-known Chamberlain operation in Western Australia, which has ceased operation, was primarily the recipient of bounty payment over very many years. More recently we have seen the closure of Horwood, Bagshaw Ltd in South Australia. This firm has gone into receivership.
—They never sold so many tractors.
—I was not aware of that.
—Sales were going through the roof.

—They are quite a price no doubt. As a result, there is only one manufacturer of tractors left in Australia: Waltanna Tractors of Hamilton, which falls within the electorate of Wannon. I am quite sure that the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) would like to say a good deal more about it.
—And the member for Chifley.

—Does the honourable member have a tractor? Goodness gracious! What does it plough up? It might make a left wing furrow. Waltanna Tractors is the only remaining viable tractor manufacturer now operating. It has been hard hit by this decision which took effect on Budget day. I am quite sure that the result of that will add to the majority of the honourable member for Wannon. The company developed a niche for itself with a very specialised timber forwarder. However, since all the parts needed to make the forwarders are made in Australia, there are tariffs on them. It hardly makes it profitable for Waltanna to keep producing this tractor. That could be easily overcome by way of a by-law.

SPEECH.PARA: Protection in the form of bounties obviously has not assisted the Australian tractor industry as a whole. As we said in our statement `Approaches to Business', which was released at the weekend, if Australian industry is to become internationally competitive, it will have to operate in a more open environment with less government assistance. It has become increasingly obvious that the Government's web of industry assistance measures, including tariffs, bounties and quantitative restrictions, has resulted in a subsidy culture, along with great disparities in the levels of protection which have effectively favoured some industries at the expense of others, as well as disadvantaging consumers in the long run. There is no doubt that many of Australia's rural producers will lament the closure of some tractor operations in Australia because sometimes the products arrive in Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are listening.
—I am pleased about that. The honourable member for Tangney must have a tractor too. I cannot imagine why the tractor industry is doing so badly if everyone has one.
—I need a new one.

—Obviously the imported ones are not doing the trick. As a consequence of this cessation, it will be interesting to see whether Australia's sole surviving manufacturer can survive the new-found competition.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of the Bill before us tonight relates to the book producing industry. The bounty assistance to the book producing industry has been extended to 31 December and is being phased down from 20 per cent, beginning on 31 December 1988, as follows: 18 per cent from 1 January 1989, 16 per cent from 1 January 1990, 14 per cent from 1 January 1991 and 13.5 per cent from 1 January 1992. All those in politics who are writing autobiographies ought to get busy and do so quickly. If a former Prime Minister could not get his printed, I do not know how the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table, will get his next publication across if the subsidies are not there. The cost of the bounty will be $18m in 1987-88; $21.4m in 1988-89-that increase is due to the number of bicentennial books produced this year; and $19.3m in 1989-90. Prior to 1993, when the scheme expires, the bounty will be further reviewed.

There are also some minor changes which will facilitate administration of the scheme: an increase in the minimum production run from $200 to $500; a minimum production run requirement of 1,000 copies or more of the same book-in other words, stricter guidelines in the production runs; deletion of the requirement that children's books contain pictures; and self- financing government publishing enterprises-the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in particular-producing and marketing books in substantial competition with the private sector will be eligible to receive the bounty. Government enterprises should be able to compete on an equal footing with private enterprise, which is one of the first steps to privatisation. We do not oppose the proposals in this piece of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in the debate on the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill. By way of introduction, I remind the House and the people of Australia of the Opposition's position on industry measures, such as those contained in the Bill, throughout the last Parliament. Its position was, by and large, consistent with the remarks of the Opposition spokesman for business and consumer affairs-the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore)-that is, it supports a whole raft of Government initiatives. But it is also true that, come election day, the then Opposition spokesman on industry, Senator Tony Messner, did a complete back-flip on industry policy as it had been articulated in this House over 2 1/2 years, and promised industry in Australia that all forms of government assistance would be completely wiped out overnight. If there is one thing that business finds most difficult to comprehend and to react to, it is radical changes of policy whether by the Government or the Opposition. Given this complete backflip in policy during an election, the Opposition's stance and credibility in terms of industry policy have been brought into question. There can be no guarantee that what is said today will be the policy which the Opposition takes to the people when there is an election.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that the honourable member for Ryan, the shadow spokesman who has just contributed to this debate, has been given credit for being the key architect of a Liberal Party so-called five-point plan to boost the economy. As part of that plan, it is offering lower industry protection. As I said before, when it talks about lower industry protection, there is no guarantee that it will not change its position overnight and completely remove it. The Opposition cannot be trusted.

I now turn to the specific nature of the Bill, in particular as it affects the bounty on agricultural tractors and equipment. The Opposition has suggested that there are only one or two manufacturers. I have a very small producer of specialised tractors in my electorate-E. M. Baldwin and Sons Pty Ltd. That is a firm in which I take a great deal of interest because it suffered under the vagaries of the decline in commodity prices and the lack of purchasing of equipment by agricultural producers. Indeed, it is trading under a scheme of arrangement. Not only was the firm involved in producing super-large tractors for the agricultural sector but it also produces a whole range of specialised mining equipment. I remind the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) and the House that Australia's expertise in manufacturing mining equipment gives it an advantage in world markets. It is seen as a sector that can increase dramatically.

I have raised my concerns about the Bill-incidentally, it was a Budget item, announced in the last Budget-in the Caucus. I think it is only fair that I should raise my concerns about the Bill in the House. Firstly, I do not like it when the Government announces a scheme to last for a certain period and then reduces that period fairly peremptorily. If my memory is correct, the scheme was supposed to run to about 1992 and we have terminated it. Secondly, the Minister, in announcing the Bill, assured everyone that every firm was telexed the decision to cease the bounty. Unfortunately, E. M. Baldwin and Sons received no such telex, and that is acknowledged by the Department. It is extremely bad administrative practice to do away with a bounty and fail to notify every player.

I do not think it is satisfactory to say that the measure was announced in the Budget. As I have acknowledged, this is a small business trading under a scheme of arrangement. A very common factor with small businesses is that they are usually totally preoccupied with their business, trying, as it is commonly said, to make a quid and they are not the greatest readers of government literature, government regulations or government announcements. Unfortunately, this decision vitally affected that business. I wrote to the Minister who I thought was the correct Minister, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). I said, amongst other things:

Please find enclosed correspondence from the company. They were unaware of the cessation of the bounty and were not advised by telex. They only found out of the changes when an application for the bounty was rejected.
The amount of the bounty involved is $18,753 and would be the same approximately for the other 2 tractors mentioned in their letter.
I would be grateful if you would sympathetically review the situation as I feel strongly that we have to bear responsibility for advising of the changes.
I received a reply dated 8 April from the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), the Minister at the table. It said, amongst other things:

The Government took the decision to terminate the bounty scheme as part of the 1987-88 Budget. On the night of the budget telexs were forwarded to known manufacturers of agricultural tractors. No telex was forwarded to E M Baldwin and Sons as it was understood that it was no longer actively trading.

I say frankly to the House: I do not think that is good enough. A bit of sloppiness on the part of a public servant should not be sufficient to jeopardise the viability of this company. I repeat: I think this company has a good future. It is innovative. It specialises now in mining equipment. This is an area of Australian expertise and an area where we have potential for exports. This company ultimately will trade out and export its way out. How does the Government expect a small company trading under a scheme of arrangement, after a series of government decisions which take three times $18,000 away in bounty which the company expected to receive, to survive? I implore the Minister to give this case special attention and special consideration. We have a real onus of responsibility, having failed to advise the company, to sympathetically look at the request.

I also want to talk about another aspect that I find ironic in the proposals. These proposals will do away with the bounty. They will allow the importation of tractors-fully built-up tractors-completely duty-free. If a company operating in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) or in my electorate decides that it wants to trade on, having a specific belief in its expertise, its niche marketing and its ability to adapt to these circumstances, and if that company has to import component parts it has to pay a tariff on those parts. Here we have a contradiction. On the one hand, imported tractors come in completely duty-free. If one wants to manufacture tractors and import some of the component parts, one has to pay a tariff on them. That is a serious contradiction and one the Government ought to look at. The Minister, in his second reading speech, says:

. . . I should like to point out that agricultural tractors and equipment are incorporated in the reference on mining, construction and agricultural equipment currently with the Industries Assistance Commission. It is therefore open to people to put forward their views to the Commission on what they consider to be the appropriate level of assistance for this industry sector.

I certainly invite all the players in the industry to put submissions. I specifically draw to the attention of the Industries Assistance Commission this contradiction in its recommendations and government policy; one can import a fully made up tractor but if one wants to continue some limited manufacture, production and assembly in Australia one must pay tariffs on all the component parts.

I will conclude my remarks by going back to the general proposition that I put. This matter is unfortunate. I have said before in the House that I was truly shocked during the last election to see this backflip on industry policy by the Opposition. If there is anything that this country needs at the moment, it is unanimity of view on industry policy and on general economic direction. We really cannot afford the luxury of cheap point scoring on industry policy or the economy. Every opportunity we lose today has gone forever. I say to both Government and Opposition members that there is a real need for us to get together in the national interest to ensure continuity of growth and of government policies and decisions so that people in industry know exactly where they are and can plan and grow for the future to provide more jobs for more Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to begin my remarks by commending the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) for putting forward a very clear and logical argument as to why the Government has made a serious mistake. It is rather sad that the Government appears to be so out of touch that it cannot even hear a case that is being argued by one of its own backbenchers. There is a clear, logical and irrefutable argument as to why the Government has made a serious error in trying to cut out this bounty for larger tractors. As the honourable member for Chifley has pointed out, the Government gave the industry an undertaking to continue this bounty until at least 1992. It is a very serious matter.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen the lamentable decline in the tractor building industry over a number of years. It has reached the point where probably the only viable tractor manufacturer left in Australia is the one in my electorate, just out of Hamilton-Waltanna Tractors. I recognise the honourable member's case. I hope that company can trade out of its problems, and with the improved agricultural situation that may be an option and a real opportunity. I hope that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table, will take on board these points because there is a genuine case. It is not a question of asking for special favours or any such thing. There is a genuine case as to why that tractor bounty should have been continued and, failing that, why there should be some other special consideration.

I will outline the case now as the honourable member for Chifley has already done so well. Quite simply, there is now the opportunity for the importation of large tractors, such as those in competition with Waltanna, totally free of import duty. Yet a manufacturer such as Waltanna, which assembles its tractors partly with imported components, now has to pay duty on those imported components, a duty that the fully imported tractor does not attract. I am sure the Minister would appreciate that this is totally illogical, quite unreasonable and, if I may say so, rather unAustralian.

The simple fact is that the bounty in the case of a tractor manufacturer such as Waltanna is not some great bonus. It works out roughly equal to the cost of the import duty on those components which the manufacturer has to bring into the country to assemble those tractors. I hope the Government will look at this case as a genuine one, give it proper, sympathetic consideration and realise before the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill becomes an Act that there is a very strong case to reconsider.

I would like to take just a bit of time to explain to honourable members a little of the background of Waltanna Tractors. Waltanna commenced operations just outside Hamilton in 1975 and it has been successfully manufacturing large articulated four-wheel drive agricultural tractors ever since. Waltanna has been competing against the imports of the giants of America, Canada and Europe and has been doing so extremely successfully. It produces a product that the local market wants and it backs up that product with good service and reliability. Although it is a small operation and employs only nine people directly, when the subcontracting personnel for all the components are taken into account, it would employ the equivalent of another 25 to 30 people in the manufacturing of its tractors. Waltanna has established a dealer network throughout Australia and backs up its product with excellent after sales service.

For the last two years there has been a decline in sales of some 70 per cent in Australia's tractor market, with a discounting of about 40 per cent by some of the sellers of imported tractors. Despite that, Waltanna is still operating, is progressing, and is still developing new products, one of which I shall mention shortly. This is an example of another case in which the Government should act and look very closely at what is being done to a local manufacturer with regard to a fully imported product. Waltanna is also actively pursuing export markets and is in fact looking closely at exporting to a number of countries. It has received inquiries from New Zealand and Canada, and also, interestingly enough, from Hungary. One may well ask why Hungary has made inquiries of Waltanna. The answer is quite simple. Currently Hungary supplies some of the heavy axles that are used in the manufacture of the Waltanna tractor. In fact, in relation to axles and other parts that come from Hungary, Waltanna has spent more than $1m.

The repeal of the Bounty (Agricultural Tractors and Equipment) Act by the Budget last year had a fairly adverse effect on Waltanna. The effects could well prove to be very serious. Not only does Waltanna produce tractors, but also it is involved in quite a deal of research and development to try to improve its tractors. It was using much of this bounty to do just that, as well as to offset the cost of tariffs imposed on imported products.

I now wish to relate some of the specifics. The effect of the duty imposed on components that Waltanna uses in its tractors has been almost balanced out by the value of the bounty. For example, in relation to a 300- to 400-horse power tractor the value of the bounty on the components works out at about $9,350. It may be anything up to $12,500 for the cost of these components, which would be added to the retail value of the tractor. For clarification, the value of the bounty adds about $9,000 to the wholesale value and when that is translated to retail value prices it becomes another $12,500. As a further example, in 1987 the retail value of a 280-horse power Waltanna tractor was just over $146,000. The fully imported tractor, which I repeat did not attract import duty, manufactured by Steiger had a retail price of $150,000 and the Versatile tractor from Canada had a retail price of $148,832. By 30 December that year the price of the Waltanna tractor had increased from $146,000 to $157,000. In other words, it went from being the cheapest in its range to suddenly becoming the most expensive. As Waltanna worked through some of the components that it had in stock, with the increased effect of the bounty, I am told that as of 1 April the retail price of a Waltanna tractor will have to rise to $158,625. In other words, from being highly competively priced, the Waltanna tractor is rapidly approaching the situation where it will be priced out of the market.

I have here a table which shows not only the recommended retail prices of the Waltanna, Steiger and Versatile tractors before and after the bounty, but also the cost to the dealer and what has happened in the last three months as Waltanna has worked through its stock of components and will now pay full duty on its components. I seek leave of the House to have the table incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I mention also that Waltanna has developed a timber and forestry machine, which is used in the primary removal of timber from forests. The machine was well built and was well received. Waltanna has received an excellent response to what it has tried to do. The machine has had incorporated in it a crane that loads the logs that are cut from the forest on to what is known as a timber forwarder, and it transports the timber from the forest down to where the timber is loaded onto trucks to be taken to the timber mills. Waltanna, having incorporated into the machine a crane, went to a local crane manufacturer to enquire whether it could build a crane to Waltanna's specifications. The local crane manufacturer said, `Look, really the size of your operation and the numbers of machines you want do not warrant our making that special crane. It would have to be virtually a one-off machine'. Therefore, Waltanna has to import the crane; the local manufacturer is not interested in making it.

SPEECH.PARA: The crane attracts a 35 per cent duty, which in fact adds a further $12,000 approximately to the price of the machine. The same situation arises: a fully imported machine attracts no import duty yet a manufacturer who builds such a machine in Australia finds that a $12,000 duty is imposed upon a major component of the machine. Duty is imposed also on some of the other components it has to import. Consequently, the total duty payable on the timber forwarder is almost $26,000.

The situation is that a manufacturer has developed and built a machine that is considered to be equal to, if not better than, any product that is imported and is able to sell the product at a cheaper price than the imported product, but has to pay duty in relation to it. If one were cynical, I suppose one could say, `If the manufacturer can sell it for less why worry?'. Obviously, the answer is that if the Australian manufacturer can make the product at a lesser cost and is able to compete on fair terms with the imported product, there is obviously scope for export. I am sure that every member of this House would seek to encourage a company such as this to develop that export market.

I ask the Minister and the Government to take this matter on board and examine it closely. This is a genuine case. What has happened to Waltanna because of these duties? The first thing is that it has had to cut its costs somewhere. It has postponed much of its research and development, which has only just recently turned out this timber forwarder. Undoubtedly it would have been able to build on this unit and even manufacture other products. Of course, its program has been delayed and if the duty is not removed-or fair compensation by whatever means is not forthcoming-presumably the company will not develop to its full potential. It is a most efficient and impressive company. I hope that one day when the Minister makes one of his sojourns into western Victoria he will pay a visit to the company premises. I am sure he would be most impressed with what he saw. The manager and owner of Waltanna has informed me that he has other export opportunities in the pipeline, but again they have had to be postponed. He depends very heavily on his research and development program and if he cannot afford to carry that out it is unlikely that he will go ahead with these things.

Although the Government may believe that there will be a small saving involved in the removal of the tractor bounty-and it would be only small in overall terms-the cost to Australia will far outweigh any savings made by the Government. It will greatly constrict the operations of the last viable tractor manufacturer in Australia. From a national point of view it is a source of great embarrassment that Australia is unable to sustain more than one tractor manufacturer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is a great agricultural country.

—As the honourable member for Gwydir reminds me, Australia is a great agricultural country. Really and truly, we should be taking a long hard look at ourselves and asking why this situation has ever been allowed to happen.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I inform the House that Waltanna has assured me that it could develop quite a large market overseas, with a potential market of the order of $5m. However, none of these opportunities will be realised unless it is given a fair chance to compete on a fair basis against overseas imports. I have spoken at some length with the management and they are quite genuine about this. They have had real inquiries. They have openings overseas that no other manufacturer of a similar product has and they have worked hard to get them. But if they cannot get the chance to compete on the local market and develop sufficient cash flow to carry out this work it is unlikely that they will go ahead with these exports. I ask the Minister to advise his Department to look very carefully at this case and at the case mentioned by the honourable member for Chifley. We would be very foolish to ignore what will happen if we do not reconsider the implications of this Bill. As I said, this is a genuine case. I think the Government should have a long hard look at this. We are creating a situation where an Australian manufacturer is worse off than someone who is importing a fully built up tractor. I cannot for the life of me see where the fairness and equity is in such a move.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much has been said about tractor manufacturing in the debate on the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill, and I will return to that matter in a moment. I want to speak briefly about books. I was a little concerned when I heard that we intended to phase down the bounty on Australian books because I believe that Australian books serve a very useful purpose in building an Australian culture. With all the damage being done to the fabric of Australian society by multiculturalism, I think it is a very good thing for us to have a uniform culture that is enhanced by encouraging the publication of Australian literature. When one looks at this issue carefully one sees that the Government is giving trade-offs and that the effect is fairly neutral. This is indicated by the fact that the paper itself says that the effect on revenue is zero. Allowing manufacturers to include different coverings for their books in a 1,000-book run is a very big saving for the industry, and it is very wise of the Government to make that decision. In Australia a run of 1,000 hard cover books is a big run. If soft cover and hard cover books can be mixed, many more books will be brought within the ambit of this legislation. Similarly, standardising picture books and children's books of more than 16 pages is a move in the right direction. I am very happy with what has been achieved there.

SPEECH.PARA: I am a little uneasy about the tractor bounty because tractor manufacture is very much a decentralised industry in Australia. I have said many times in this Parliament that one of the great problems facing Australia is the growing dichotomy between city and country. Australians increasingly live in the coastal cities. There is a tendency for us to grow apart as a nation and we are not concentrating on decentralisation. All governments pay lip service to decentralisation-it is a little like motherhood-but the reality is that we do not do a lot about it. In saying that I mean both political parties.

Australia has a natural advantage in the manufacture of tractors. We have probably the greatest need in the world for large four-wheel drive tractors. It has always been a matter of concern to me that most of these tractors are imported from Canada or the United States of America. As to Australian-produced models, I have a manufacturer very close to my electorate in a town called Merredin in the electorate of O'Connor, where the Phoenix tractors are produced. I think the Phoenix is one of the best designed tractors in terms of maintenance available on the market. I guess if someone has the money they will still build a tractor for him. Removing the bounty will make it less likely that people will have that sort of money.

I want to look at another aspect of this issue. Australia lost an enormous advantage when that bounty existed. Not enough attention was paid to buying Australian tractors. It is true that foreign tractors had a distinct advantage in entering the country duty free whereas Australian tractors had duty imposed on components. This was always a source of annoyance to me, and was something which I thought would have been very easy to get rid of, particularly in a climate where we are talking about reducing protection. Industry itself neglected the Australian tractor. Industry itself failed to support Australian inventiveness and ingenuity, and I hold the gold mining industry particularly responsible for this. This Government gave the gold mining industry an enormous advantage. When I was campaigning for the abolition of the gold tax we were given undertakings that the gold mining industry would look very seriously at Australianising its purchases and developing a demand for Australian manufactured goods. The gold mining industry, unlike the iron ore industry or the coal industry, tends to use medium sized equipment. It tends to use equipment that Australia manufactures. I hope that we will not get involved in the very big equipment because I do not think the Australian market is big enough, but there is a very large market for the medium sized equipment. If the gold mining industry had shown just a little more initiative, many of those agricultural tractors could have been beefed up and they would have been ideal for the industry, particularly for clean-up work around mines. If every gold mine in Australia bought a couple of these machines there would be an ongoing market.

Similarly, a specialised tractor is required for the handling of wheat. Because of the specific gravity of wheat a very large bucket is needed to carry the volume, although wheat is not particularly heavy. It needs a specially designed tractor, and I know that Phoenix put a lot of work into a tractor with a bucket designed specifically to meet this need. The tractor was designed to go backwards very quickly because that is the way a lot of wheat is handled in silos. At the time they lost out to a Japanese product which certainly was not as good but was marginally cheaper. Of course, before the product was delivered the Australian dollar slumped and the Japanese tractors ended up costing a lot more. I think that was one case where the wheat industry, and I guess I could say the farmers of Australia, demonstrated a lack of foresight. Had they supported Australian manufacturing industry in that instance it would have been a feather in their caps and one which they could have traded off at a later date. That was not done and I suspect that that opportunity has been lost.

It is important for Australia to have these sorts of industries in country towns. While Australia has a large per capita demand for this sort of tractor, the price will not be enhanced much by economies of scale. These tractors are too individual to benefit from the economies of scale that are obtained with a mass production run. There is no doubt that the men employed in country towns, be it six or 20 or 30, make a significant contribution to a town's economy whereas in the cities they would go unnoticed. We should be looking at these things in Australia.

It is all very well to talk about savings to government-an amount of $900,000 a year in this case. I suspect that the current account cost will be significantly higher. It does not need many people to buy imported tractors instead of Australian tractors for the current account cost to be much more than that. The problem we have right now is a current account problem and it is one which we should be constantly addressing. I certainly feel for the Baldwin company, and the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) spoke extremely well on that issue, as did the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), albeit a little repetitively. However, they did make the point that manufacturers who had budgeted for that bounty to continue have a legitimate complaint and one which the Government should consider.

I believe we in Australia are tending to lose sight of where opportunities lie. I am a great believer in high technology. I think that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Jones) has made an enormous contribution to the future of Australia by continually pushing the theme that Australia must get involved in these high tech areas. It continually depresses me when those who attempt to move in that direction are thwarted by irrational fears, by vested interests and by what can only be described as sloppy, lazy journalism. I cite a case in my electorate where the Government's message to a French company basically was this: `You nasty French company; you have been exploiting us; you have been taking our monazite overseas and making enormous profits by downstream processing. You have to stop this; and we demand that you process this product in Australia so that we get the value added, we get the new high tech jobs, and we get the employment'. The French company said, `If that is what you want, all right'. Of course, the minute they set up to do that they developed the waste product thorium, a constituent of all granite. Thorium is radioactive. It is only mildly radioactive for it has a half life of 14 billion years, so I guess it will see most of us out.

The irrational fears that were raised by people when the company sought to deposit this waste product in what can only be described as very arid land in my electorate were absolutely fantastic. The sloppy, emotional articles that have been put in the Press have been quite sickening. I was at a public meeting in Coolgardie recently attended by about 200 people, the great bulk of whom were very hostile and abusive about the proposal to store thorium waste. I must say that the State Government handled the matter very badly, but that does not overcome the facts. The former member for Kalgoorlie, Mick Cotter, played on every emotion, fear and unfounded suggestion, and was roundly applauded. He was no doubt the hero of the day. I do not see it in that light; I think it was a disgrace and a tragedy. Australia really must be prepared to bite the bullet on these issues.

I now return to the Bill. I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your tolerance. In many Australian country towns there are companies with the initiative to make machinery that has niche markets. There are companies that can apply the resources for which we as a nation rightly take some credit and produce equipment at very competitive prices. Notwithstanding the new mood on privatisation and efficiency, there has to be the mechanism to encourage these people. I understand the difficulties in that, but I suggest that the problems in encouraging small operations in country towns are not those of mass production, where inefficiencies can very quickly become entrenched. These companies do not become inefficient; they are too small and their work forces are usually far too involved to succumb to inefficiencies. In these towns workers put in more effort than generally occurs in the cities. I know that the Phoenix tractor company in Merredin has workers who are prepared to work beyond their knock-off time to finish a job without thinking of the extra few dollars that that might mean. That is the sort of attitude on which we can build a surprising amount of industry.

If Australia does not face up to its declining rural populations, it will have a real problem. I see that as one of the serious issues facing Australia. I fear it is not being tackled. Notwithstanding the rhetoric of political parties, no one is seriously looking at the problem. I believe we are developing two Australias, one with a rural economy and one a city economy. Australia cannot survive on that basis. If that trend is not reversed, I hold fears for our future. This, our bicentennial year, is a good time for us to start addressing this real problem for Australia. In doing so we can build a nation worthy of our children, a nation which can give them employment and security in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) for the sentiments he expressed, particularly in regard to the importance of industries such as the semi-heavy industries in some of our country towns which are so fundamental to community life and employment opportunities, limited as they might be in some of our regional centres. I commend also the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) for bringing to the attention of this House and the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) his concern about a specific industry in his electorate. I am sure the Minister will give due consideration to the concern that the honourable member has raised in the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to focus my remarks on the protectionist principles involving bounty and subsidy schemes and tariffs aimed at ensuring the so-called viability of industries. I make particular reference to what the Minister said in his second reading speech:

When the agricultural tractors and equipment bounty scheme was introduced in mid-1975, the Government believed it would assist the local agricultural tractor industry to become economically viable in the longer term.
He went on to say:

However, since that time production by the major manufacturers in Australia has virtually ceased, and it has become clear that the scheme has not been effective in maintaining an internationally competitive tractor manufacturing industry in Australia.
I stress the Minister's words:
. . . it has not been effective in maintaining an internationally competitive tractor manufacturing industry in Australia.

That is an incredible state of affairs. In spite of the fact that there has been a 40 per cent devaluation against the trade weighted index in six years, and in spite of the bounty scheme, the tractor manufacturing industry in Australia has virtually ceased-in one of the biggest agricultural trading nations in the world. It should alarm all who are concerned about our balance of payment deficits and our record foreign debt, now passing the $115 billion level. We are not competitive. We want to be very careful that we do not do the same to our own agricultural export industries. Why are we not competitive in the manufacturing industry and in so many other industries? Whilst the tractor industry does not have a large production or throughput, it faces the problem that the vast array of industry in Australia also faces. We are not competitive because our levels of productivity are low; our unique work practices and short working hours are uncompetitive; our domestic economy is racked with inflation much higher than that of competing nations; and our interest rates are double, even treble, those or our competitors.

These problems are due in part to government actions such as the interception of the fall in world oil prices. I wish to elaborate a little on that because this particular action alone rocketed the excise on fuel from 6 cents a litre to 20 cents a litre and exploded Federal revenue from fuel from less than $5 billion in 1982-83 to $7.6 billion in 1985-86. We simply cannot go on with these kinds of insensitive decisions and expect the Australian inflation rate to stay in line with world trends. I urge the Government to review that aspect of its taxing policy. The agricultural tractor industry has once again shown that Australia cannot resolve its uncompetitive dilemma with protective devices which shield uncompetitive levels of productivity, uncompetitive wage increases and outdated work practices.

Our chickens are coming home to roost. We can think back to the days in the early 1970s when the Australian Council of Trade Unions was demanding shorter working hours and work practices that were clearly beyond the capacity of the economy to pay. I recall saying that Australia could not afford such increases and the industrial disruption that went with them, particularly in 1974. I thought at the time that this would surely severely harm our long term competitiveness, particularly in manufacturing industry and in industries such as tractor manufacturing. Indeed, it has. The once proud Australian tractor industry lies in ruins. It is a broken, beaten industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Merredin destroyed.

—The honourable member for Kalgoorlie brought that to our attention. The honourable member for Chifley raised another example and the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) raised another example in Hamilton. It is little wonder that the Government decided that its bounty system was not helping the industry. The two major tractor producers, the Horwood-Bagshaw and Baldwin companies, are both in receivership. Who would have thought that six or seven years ago. The last major producers of tractors, Chamberlain John Deere Pty Ltd, has ceased production. The industry has been smashed. The uncompetitive economic environment in Australia has been a significant cause of the problem; yet, we cannot stop there.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulties experienced with production costs have been severely aggravated by a lack of demand for agricultural tractors. This has been due in large part to the severe erosion of farmer incomes year after year. It is little wonder that, with average farm incomes running at less than half the average wage for season after season, money has not been there to spend on new machinery. In my electorate, which happens to be one of the biggest agricultural producing areas in Australia, the median income of people is half that of people in the industrial areas of Sydney. These people include the farming community, which is absolutely strapped for cash and has not been able to afford recapitalisation or capital investment in machinery.

The crisis has been double edged for Australian farmers, who face increasingly sharp cost increases for imported tractors in light of the 40 per cent plus devaluation and near record interest rates. On top of this, they are expected to continue shouldering the burden of tariffs on spare parts, chemicals and a wide range of farm machinery. The farming industry is expected to carry on with only nominal assistance while shouldering the burden of protection for secondary industry in this country-a burden now running at a minimum of $9,000 per farm per annum.

The farm sector earns 40 per cent of our gross domestic export income. But in net terms it is probably more than 60 per cent. In spite of this, it seems that the anti-agricultural economics of those opposite are set to continue. We hear consistent rumours that the last vestige of assistance for the farm sector is in for the chop on or before 25 May. Yesterday, one report suggested that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) had agreed to a massive run-down of underwriting schemes, wool promotion, the superphosphate bounty, the 50 per cent export inspection charge rebates and the on-farm diesel excise rebate. We have been told that even the rural adjustment scheme is headed for the axe. This scheme is the last avenue for any measure of government encouragement towards industry rationalisation and the retention of viable family farms. These farm industries are largely unassisted. Assistance to the wheat industry comes to 2 per cent; for barley growers it is -1 per cent; oats, zero per cent; maize, -4 per cent; sorghum, -3 per cent; oilseeds, -2 per cent; beef producers, effective assistance of just 7 per cent; wool, 3 per cent; sheep meat, 2 per cent. In total, farmers receive an average effective rate of assistance of about 10 per cent, less than half the assistance afforded to secondary industry.

Our farmers are competing against subsidies as high as 100 per cent in the United States and 160 per cent in the European Economic Community. The Government has already torn more than $500m from its outlays to farming. The total net Budget outlays to farming in Australia are less than one-half of 1 per cent of the total Budget outlays. The Government spends on farming in a year what it spends on social security in a week. The Government has already slashed such crucial measures as income equalisation deposits and tax averaging-so essential to industries which experience wide fluctuations in income. It is harming not only the farm sector but also associated industries such as tractor manufacturing in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —They matter.

—They do matter. As I said earlier, what an incredible state of affairs it is when an industry as important as agricultural production is reaching a stage at which there will barely be a manufacturer of industrial equipment for the farm. I think it is one of the most serious things that we are facing in this country. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business has been pushing technology. He has been pushing the new high tech industries. I think he is wise to do so, but, we really must not forget other industries that have been so important to the living standards of Australian people, and will be for such a long time.
—We must not forget the basics.

—The honourable member is right. We cannot go on hacking up foreign debt by 400 per cent while continuing to hurt the export industries which give us our only hope of reducing our foreign debt. It is high time that the Government undertook a radical rethink of its entire approach to the vital issue of protection and assistance for Australian industry today.

SPEECH.PARA: Failures such as the agricultural tractor bounty are only dragging us deeper into the mire. In particular, there can be no justification for cutting any deeper into the last vestige of assistance to agriculture until the $9,000 burden on farmers of secondary industry protection is largely demolished. To do otherwise would be economic lunacy. Yet there is an effort under way to slash wool promotion, underwriting, the superphosphate bounty, diesel excise rebates and so on. However, I must say that I welcome the tentative step that has been taken in the area of secondary protection today with the reduction in tariffs on imported motor vehicles from 57.5 per cent to 45 per cent and the abolition of quotas. But the action has not gone far enough if the farm sector is to be slashed further. An industry spokesman immediately claimed this afternoon that the changes are unlikely to affect retail prices. The consumer cost of imported passenger vehicles has gone through the roof largely because of the huge devaluation of the Australian dollar. The industry itself has a tariff of 45 per cent to remain in place. This is on top of the benefits of devaluation. If actions such as this are trumpeted by the Government as a justification for attacking the slight assistance left for farming the Government's actions will be transparent. We still have not heard whether such industries as textiles, clothing and footwear are to receive some kind of special treatment in any across the board tariff cut.

If this Government proceeds to fiddle around the edges of the tariff burden, indexes wages, to satisfy union demands and further slashes what remains of Budget outlays to Australian farming, it will deal a lethal blow to many rural industries which presently are on an economic knife edge. Such action would affect all Australians and their living standards. Our living standards have already undergone a sharp decline over the past five years despite unprecedented levels of foreign borrowing. We cannot afford to make more of the kind of economic blundering which has destroyed the Australian manufacturing industry.

This Government's response to the bounty, subsidy, tariff and quota issues has enormous implications for every Australian family. As with Argentina, the health of the farm sector is the key to the overall health of the economy of Australia. Protection policy must recognise that farmers cannot pass on their costs since 80 per cent of their production is exported to very often corrupted world markets. They have met that corrupted competition with minimal effective assistance. They are lean and efficient, but they cannot afford a new round of Government attacks. Slash the farmers any more and the Government will undermine their capacity to play a leading role in rescuing the economy from a probable recession more serious than any witnessed by the past two generations.

Protection cuts must be implemented but in a programmed, steady and predictable manner. They must be aimed first and foremost at those sectors of industry which currently receive the highest tariffs, quotas, subsidies and bounties. In other words, make comprehensive cuts to tariffs first and then see where some budgetary assistance can be withdrawn from the farm sector. I am sure that the farmers will not complain. Once other industry sectors have been brought back to the average assistance level applied to farming, then our farmers will be in a position to stand totally on their own feet against corrupted competition from subsidised countries. The Hawke Government must proceed along this path in a comprehensive and meaningful way, in a progressive move towards reducing industry protection before robbing the farm export sector of the last vestige of its budgetary support. We must not fail to learn from the Argentine experience. They bled their farm sector dry, wrecked their living standards, and today cannot even afford an old age pension.

The Opposition does not oppose this Bill, but expresses its disappointment at the manner in which the Hawke Government has approached the plight of the agricultural tractor industry in Australia. The Bill is an admission of the Government's dismal failure to strengthen the local tractor manufacturing industry, which has suffered not only a difficult domestic economic environment but also the effects of a rural downturn. First and foremost, it should have concentrated on macroeconomic policies to encourage a competitive domestic economic environment-and nothing is more important to this nation than those four words, `competitive domestic economic environment'. But the Government has also kicked the farmers and, in turn, this is undermining their associated service industries and small businesses, such as the tractor industry. It is high time for the Government to concentrate on policies to improve the overall competitiveness of the Australian economy. If it fails to do so, it will leave a shocking legacy to our children and to our grandchildren who at some time will be called upon to pick up the tab for our own failings and the failings of this generation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are suffering now.
—They are suffering today, but they will suffer more in future unless we strive to make Australia a more competitive nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable members for their contributions to the debate. Much of the discussion in this debate has been about the tractor bounty, and a strong case was put by a number of honourable members-by the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) and up to a point, although he did not concentrate on the matter to the same degree, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt). As honourable members will appreciate, it was a Budget decision. I suppose that the decision could have been made in the presentation of the Budget as to whether the decision was to be phased in or whether it was to apply immediately on announcement. In fact, the decision was made to apply immediately on announcement.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable members know, that happens with scores if not hundreds of decisions that are made, and that is part of the whole Budget-making process. Obviously we shall not, I hope, attempt to overturn the Budget tonight, but a serious case has been put. Certainly I undertake to give further examination to the matter. The whole issue of assistance for the making of agricultural implements and equipment is currently being considered by the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC). I hope that people who feel that they are seriously disadvantaged will have already made submissions to the IAC. I think the case was put very strongly.

I want to address some remarks to the honourable member for Chifley who raised, in particular, the case of E. M. Baldwin and Sons Pty Ltd. He complained that on the night of the Budget when telexes were forwarded to nine manufacturers of agricultural tractors, no telex was sent to E. M. Baldwin and Sons because it was understood that that firm was no longer actively trading. I concede that that was a mistake, which is regretted. The file was noted quite correctly within the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce with the words `Receiver and manager appointed'. This firm had been a very small player in the scheme. I think it produced something like only one to three tractors a year. The assumption was made-wrongly, it would appear-that the firm was no longer actively trading. I appreciate the difficulty that it is in. On the other hand, the reality is that it is hard, if not impossible, to see how any discretionary payment can be made. There is no fund which we can dip into and say, `Here is an anomalies case'.

I appreciate that it is poor consolation to say that the industry implications were announced in the Budget and publicised in material that was circulated by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). I feel some concern about this matter. I certainly will raise it with Senator Button because I think it is an object lesson of how careful we have to be in passing on information about fundamental decisions to people who are players in the game.

I want to talk specifically about the tractor industry, then I want to pick up some of the points that were made by the honourable member for Gwydir. There really is a problem. The bounty was set up in 1975 to help maintain an industry that was going to be viable and that was going to significantly serve the Australian agricultural industry. I have been given information that certainly in recent decades Australian manufacturers had something of the order of only 10 per cent of the local market. When Chamberlain John Deere Pty Ltd was removed, the players who remained were making, in a sense, custom designed tractors in very small numbers. It is very difficult to look at those small numbers collectively. These would include the three, perhaps, from Baldwins. I gather from what the honourable member for Wannon was saying that the numbers were very small in the case of Waltanna Tractors. I do not know quite how many but I would think perhaps something less than a score a year. If we turn around and say, `Well, can we say that the system which services something that creates a viable industry and which is serving the whole of Australian agriculture is vindicated?', the answer, obviously, is, `No, it is not'.

I concede that a different kind of argument can be put. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie put very well the significance of small enterprises such as these for elements of the rural economy. I have always conceded that in examining economic realities we often need to disaggregate statistics, instead of aggregating them. Often the national aggregate is a kind of statistical myth. For instance, one might look at the Australian infant mortality figures and say, `Well, there is nothing to worry about in Australia. The figures are very tiny'. If one then starts to disaggregate them, one might say that the infant mortality figures for Aborigines living in country areas are appalling. It is useless to say, `Ah well, but the national aggregate is all right'. One has to disaggregate it in this case, and I think that a strong case can be put that those figures are really misleading.

I urge the honourable member for Gywdir not to persist with the folk myth, as he is inclined to do a bit, that some of our industrial and economic problems have occurred only in a couple of bursts, between 1972 and 1975 and since March 1983. It just is not the case. Look back at Australia's pioneering work and at the work, for example, of H. V. McKay. I was doing some work on this for an article that I was writing not long ago, and I pointed out that back in 1904 the Harvester company moved to Sunshine-it was then called Braybrook-and it was soon the largest Australian manufacturing works and the largest manufacturing exporter, selling equipment to Argentina and South Africa. But international competition was acute. High tariff protection was needed and in 1930 H. V. McKay Pty Ltd was acquired by the Canadian Massey-Harris corporation.

McKay's story is an instructive parable about Australian technology in the global context. I became the member for Lalor in 1974-before the 1984 redistribution-just as the last element of the Sunshine works was closing down. An entire history of the Australian manufacturing of agricultural equipment had come to an end. Whether it is possible to maintain sub-optimal industries is a problem. Craft industries are of great significance, but is it possible to apply any kind of rational bounty scheme when the object of the exercise is, in this case, to get tractors in the hands of the consumers at the lowest possible price? I see the apparent anomaly raised by the honourable member for Wannon. He says, `But this is ridiculous. We import the tractors duty free, the components come in subject to duty and that makes it harder for the local manufacturer'. But the answer to that is to ask whether there is a benefit to the broad range of consumers through their getting the tractors imported duty free. I appreciate the point made by the honourable member and I appreciate the particular cases mentioned, such as that mentioned by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie. But the intention of the legislation is to provide a benefit to farmers generally. If there is a feeling that this is not succeeding and that a duty ought to be imposed, I would be surprised if that view has strong support out in the rural electorates.

The problem is whether we should change the whole system of protection in order to provide additional support for an industry which demonstrably has not been able to satisfy the needs of the Australian consumer. It has provided only a tiny proportion of its requirements. It is a classic case of having to ask ourselves how far we are really able to apply the principles of economic rationality. Of course the situation appears to be exacerbated when we look at the amount of money involved-$900,000. It may be said that the degree of pain involved may well be out of proportion to the $900,000 that is saved for the revenue. I concede that that is a valid point, and I think we have to look at it again.

The honourable member for Gwydir referred to the virtual annihilation of the Australian manufacturing industry. It is true that between 1967 and 1983 employment in manufacturing fell from 27 per cent of the labour force to 17 per cent-a fall of almost 40 per cent in that 16-year period. It is true that there was some decline, but perhaps less than one would imagine, in 1972-73. After the tariff cuts of 1974 there was a fall in some industries, but the fall was surprisingly small. It just meant that there was a long term trend which continued until 1983. Since then the size of the labour force has increased considerably. Manufacturing share went from 17 per cent to 15 per cent in the last census returns of 1986. Of course, that is a phenomenon that is commonplace in virtually every country of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). I do not know of any OECD country in which the percentage of people employed in manufacturing has increased in recent years.

There was a bit of rhetoric from the honourable member for Gwydir that might have gone down very well with some of the National Party branches in his electorate. He said that we have some disadvantages compared with some of our trading partners. I remind him of the economic situation we inherited and of the fact that in the last five years a remarkable series of attempts has been made, and I think with a high degree of success, to restructure the whole nature of the Australian economy. I draw the honourable member's attention to the significance of the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) plan, the significance of the steel plan, the significance of the passenger motor vehicle plan. Only today, as the honourable member for Gwydir conceded, a very striking reduction in protection was announced. It is extraordinary to hear that kind of rhetoric on the other side about protection and concern that levels of manufacturing protection are too high and represent a $9 billion impost on Australian consumers. I must ask: what serious attempts were made between 1975 and 1983 to change the regime of tariff protection in this country? There was no record at all. We inherited a high level of unemployment, a high level of inflation, high interest rates and a projected Budget deficit of around $9 billion.

We are the first to regret that our interest rates and inflation levels are higher than the OECD average, although our unemployment figures are very satisfactory if one looks across the board at other OECD countries. The point is that we have transformed the nature of the industry. Earlier we had a little discussion about what had happened with the midway report that Senator Button issued about the passenger motor vehicle plan. The fact is that in 1983 it was starting to look very doubtful as to whether we would have a motor industry at all. It is true that there has been a tremendous benefit as a result of the devaluation of the Australian dollar, but who would have thought, five years ago, that we would be exporting cars to Japan?
