Who would have thought at that stage that we would be exporting motor engines to West Germany and other parts of Europe? The motor industry is in a stronger position now than looked likely five years ago. The TCF industry is in a much stronger position now than looked likely five years ago. We have a lot to be proud of.

I agree about the importance of our great agricultural strength, although I still insist that the emphasis at this stage has to be on adding value to what we produce. We are still exporting material in the rawest of raw states and we need to add a lot of value to what is a wonderful volume and a wonderful quality of primary produce. I think we ought to talk about some of these issues in future, particularly as we found tonight that there was a good deal of community of interest and people were not talking just from a straight partisan or party viewpoint. There was one final glancing blow from the honourable member for Gwydir. He tried to turn an incorrect speculation in the Sydney Morning Herald into a fact. I refer, for example, to what he said about the rural adjustment scheme. That scheme, as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) could testify most eloquently, is actually at record levels and is being enhanced. Did I say that right?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—I thank honourable members for their contributions to the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, page 7, omit the amendment of the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Act 1981, substitute the following amendment:
``Section 3aa:
Repeal the section, substitute the following section: Increased factory costs
`3aa. Where:

(a) the last condition for the payment of bounty in respect of bountiable yarn (in this section called the ``eligible yarn'') of a particular kind referred to in a paragraph of the definition of ``bountiable yarn'' in subsection 2 (1) is satisfied on or after 1 July 1987 and in a qualifying accounting period of a producer of the eligible yarn; and

(b) in the same qualifying accounting period of that producer, bountiable yarn of the same kind as the eligible yarn, produced by the same producer is sold, or otherwise disposed of, for export from Australia;

the factory cost, whether or not incurred after 1 July 1987, in connection with the process or processes carried out by that producer in the production of the eligible yarn is increased by an amount equal to 30% of the factory cost incurred in connection with the process or processes of producing the bountiable yarn referred to in paragraph (b).'.''.

The amendment, which is to section 3aa of the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Act 1981, repeals the existing section and substitutes a redrafted provision to express more simply the Government's policy initiative introduced last year of extending the eligible production costs upon which bounty is payable under this Act to include a proportion of the producer's production costs associated with export production. On further consideration of section 3aa, it was considered that the original policy could be enunciated more clearly without the use of the formula style which is currently employed. Indeed, claims for bounty received since the commencement of the new regime, that is, 1 July 1987, have highlighted the inordinate complexity with the application of the formula. It was therefore considered that, rather than proceeding with the correction to the formula proposed in the Bill, a redraft of the section was appropriate, and that is what the proposed amendment achieves.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report-by leave-adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Barry Jones)-by leave-read a third time.
Debate resumed from 17 March, on motion by Mr West:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this reasonably late hour the House turns its considerable attention to the Ministers of State Amendment Bill 1988. This is annual legislation which is necessary to establish the maximum annual sum for the payment of salaries of Ministers. Such legislation is regularly required because section 66 of the Constitution prescribes, subject to the Parliament providing otherwise, a maximum annual sum for the payment of salaries of Ministers. This legislation is a case of the Parliament otherwise providing. If we look at section 66 we might hark back to yesteryear when we read that the sum provided when the Constitution was first drafted was stated not to exceed #12,000 a year to pay the lot of them. But on this occasion the legislation seeks to raise the total sum paid in ministerial salaries this financial year by $65,000, from $680,000 to $745,000. Part of this increased allocation goes to pay the 3.8 per cent increase in ministerial salaries, which is the same as the increase awarded to ordinary private members of parliament some little time ago. But there is another reason for this increased allocation and that is to accommodate the rise in the salary bill due to the Government's decision, after the 1987 election, to increase the size of the Ministry from 27 to 30.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not oppose the Bill. We did not oppose the 3.8 per cent increase in parliamentary salaries. We did, however, oppose strongly the increase in the Ministry from 27 to 30. When the Ministers of State Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 was debated, we opposed it. Our position still is that we would not have expanded the Ministry if we had won the 1987 election. However, we recognise the reality of this expansion so even on this ground we do not oppose this Bill. However, the opportunity to debate this legislation provides us in proper context with an opportunity to re-examine the decision of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Government to expand the Ministry last year from 27 to 30. After that examination, this legislation also provides us with the opportunity to ask whether the Australian people are getting value for their money from the Hawke Ministry.

If we recall the circumstances surrounding the expansion of the Ministry from 27 to 30, we will remember that it occurred immediately after the July 1987 election. We would be entitled to ask-as we did then and as we do now-whether this increase in the size of the Ministry was to ensure better government for the country. Was the expansion to bring in people of such talent and ability that only creating three extra places could have allowed it? I regret to say that the answer to both those questions is an emphatic no.

If our recall is excellent we will remember the grubby and sordid episode that dominated the nation's media in July last year. We witnessed day after day in the Press and on television the spectre of the factions battling it out to divide up the spoils of office. The cost of that ultimate settlement was nearly $1m to cover the three extra Ministers. It was nearly $1m per annum to cover their extra salaries, their staff, their offices and all the other circumstances that pertain to ministerial offices. As I have said, that is nearly $1m of taxpayers' money every year.

What happened? The honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) was dumped. Senators Richardson and Robert Ray-those leading luminaries of the right wing faction-came in to take their share of the spoils. Senator Tate was dumped, then he was back in again, the reason being that there must be a Minister from Tasmania. Senator Ryan was almost out-at least of the Cabinet-then was retained because in this balance the Government had to have someone from the feminine sex in the inner Cabinet. It was a sordid factional political deal which, in terms of the two questions I asked, had nothing to do with ensuring better government for Australia and had nothing to do with bringing in people of talent and ability that only the creation of three extra places could have accommodated. It certainly had nothing to do with ensuring that the best people would occupy some of the most important political offices in the land.

I say `best people' because the Prime Minister never resiles from an opportunity to trumpet loud and clear and long the talents of his Ministry. We in this Parliament and in Australia generally outside this place have heard him talk about `the best Ministry ever'. We have heard him say that the Hawke front bench is the best front bench since Federation. As I have said, this Bill provides us contextually with an opportunity to assess that statement. In my State, coming as I do from the West, the Prime Minister is now known affectionately as Black Jack Bob, the one shoe expert. He was quoted in the Canberra Times in November 1977 as saying:
If a man . . . shouts from the roof tops that those in high office should be subject to scrutiny, he should have exactly those standards applied to himself.

As I have said, the Prime Minister never loses a chance to talk up the Ministry, but the record shows that he and many of his Ministers have been involved in incidents which in the Westminster tradition would normally mean instant dismissal or resignation. The Prime Minister's approach has been to tough it out unless public outcry threatens the Government itself. But events have even got to him. After the most recent election the Prime Minister admitted that the Ministry might not be the most talented ever or the most talented possible when he said in his 22 July 1987 Press conference:

There are other criteria as well-of State and gender-but the point I take is that having given proper consideration to those two criteria as well as talent, I will have in the third Hawke Labor Government an extremely talented, competent and relevant team.

Huh! If we look at some of the personal standards that have characterised the various Hawke ministries we could do no better than to start with what we might call the Keating standard. Most Australians were stunned to discover that the Treasurer (Mr Keating), after lecturing his fellow countrymen on tax ethics, had forgotten to file his tax returns for two consecutive years. But that was not enough. Revelations of a tax-free travel rort worth $17,000-plus a year, which the Treasurer engaged in from 1983 onwards by claiming Sydney as his home base while actually living with his family here in Canberra, made his lecturing of others on tax honesty a little hypocritical, to say the least. From the Treasurer we have a standard of behaviour which certainly does not match the Hawke prime ministerial rhetoric.

Let us look at the current Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West). He was forced to resign from his position as a Labor Cabinet Minister after publicly disagreeing with the Prime Minister on the uranium issue. He wanted to preserve Labor policy on uranium, the anti- mining view. In an unprecedented move within the Westminster system, that Minister continued and still continues to hold a ministerial post. After that episode, having been demoted outside the Cabinet, he has subsequently been re-admitted to the Cabinet despite the Westminster tradition of Cabinet solidarity.

Let us look at the former member for Adelaide and a former Minister in the Hawke Government. What standards do we see under that gentleman's banner? Then a Minister, Mr Hurford wrote to Adelaide 5DN radio personality Jeremy Cordeaux, offering to `break stories' from Cabinet in return for regular chats on the radio station in his home electorate. It is true that Mr Hurford admitted his blunder; but according to him in that admission, his proposal to break stories for a quid pro quo was a joke, done in cheek. We are told, `It was a lovely little furphy'. Mr Hurford was not sacked but he was later dropped from the Ministry after the last election. He did not, however, drop out of sight. He resigned from Parliament six months after the last Federal election-which resulted in a by-election that cost the taxpayer $170,000 at least-to take up a government diplomatic post in New York at a salary, plus allowances, of $120,000 a year.

When we look at the standards under the title of the Minister of Education, Employment and Training (Mr Dawkins) honourable members will recall that Minister Dawkins was also an outspoken critic of tax evaders. But in April 1986 it was alleged he was linked with a company known as Coomel Pty Ltd and that shares had been transferred from a bottom of the harbour company to his mother. Even then the Prime Minister did not act. He said the matter had been disposed of satisfactorily.

We do not have to go far to find other examples of ministerial propriety, if I may debase the word. The former Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown)-universally known as the Minister for Having a Good Time-was found to have misled parliament over the World Expo theatre contract and was forced to resign. Only two months after his resignation the Prime Minister indicated an intention to return the honourable member to the Ministry. However, when the honourable member for Parramatta gave in the Weekend Australian his version of the events leading up to his resignation, it caused such embarrassment to the Prime Minister that it now seems unlikely that the reappointment of the honourable member for Parramatta will occur.

In this assessment of the Hawke Ministry standards we certainly cannot go past the famous, notorious Mick Young. The Special Minister of State, and later Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, dear old Mick, was first forced to resign his post after the Hope royal commission into the ASIO-Combe-Ivanov affair. The commission found that Mr Young's actions gave rise to a real danger of significant damage to national security. After a relatively short absence from the Ministry Mr Young was reappointed to Cabinet and to the sensitive national and international security committee of Cabinet. In a second incident he admitted making a false customs declaration, later excusing himself by claiming that the customs forms were too difficult to fill out-that famous infamous Paddington Bear episode. The accident prone Minister finally resigned both from the Ministry and from the Parliament after a scandal over the misdirection of funds donated to the Australian Labor Party by a woodchip company-a scandal that has not yet seen its final days in this Parliament.

Senator Tate, that man of talent who was to be dropped from the Hawke Ministry after the July 1987 election, had to be retained at the last minute because he came from Tasmania. That man was forced to admit that he misled the Parliament by claiming that he had read to the Senate the full text of a police report about a casino for Christmas Island when it was later discovered that the report contained other information that the Minister had not revealed. He refused to resign and the Prime Minister, applying those very selective standards for which he has become famous, refused to sack him.

There was also the Amann affair, which stands alone without mentioning the name of a particular Minister because it involved not one but at least three Ministers. It related to the awarding of a northern air surveillance contract to a company, Amann Aviation Pty Ltd, without any record of performance, and the subsequent scandal involved three Ministers; Senator Evans, Mr Duncan and Mr Peter Morris. The Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Evans, has claimed that it is unfair to describe the Amann affair as a bungle; that there was a systems failure. In my wildest dreams I could not think of a more appropriate analogy-a systems failure. It is a systems failure that is not only common to the Amann affair; it is a systems failure that is prevalent throughout this Government, and the Prime Minister's inability to apply ministerial standards.

Why would I talk about ministerial standards? Because in the context of the Ministers of State Amendment Bill 1988, under which the Australian community foots the bill for the salaries of Ministers and all their other costs, we are entitled to ask: Are we getting value for dollar? Are they doing the job that they are charged with? Are they fulfilling and discharging their responsibilities properly? I have referred to some individual Ministers to make a very sound case that the answer to all of those questions is a resounding no.

Let me leave individual and singular personalities aside and look at the record of the Hawke Government itself, the totality of the members of the front bench who are charged with leaving Australia in a better state for its citizens than it was in when they came to office. That is the charge that we all pick up when we take government commission. The year 1988 is our Bicentenary. It is also the year of the Hawke Government's fifth birthday. There are not many celebrations going on around the country because over the past five years the Hawke Government has presided over the unprecedented financial enslavement of Australia to the rest of the world. The Australian economy is now more financially mendicant than at any other time in the past 50 years.

The Treasurer featured in a list of heroes earlier but his boast that he has restored Australia's economic sovereignty is nothing more than a hollow posturing. The truth of the matter is that it has been this Government's policies which have placed Australia firmly in the hands of foreign creditors and financial markets. It is this front bench that has delivered us a current account deficit which is the second largest amongst the 24 industrialised nations of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. It is this front bench which has given us a foreign debt which has trebled in five years. In that five-year period our overseas debt has climbed from just $24 billion to more than $108 billion and it is rising by more than $1 billion every month. We could pay for a new and permanent Parliament House every month with the amount by which our overseas debt is rising. The overseas debt for every man, woman and child in Australia has climbed to $6,700. This is the legacy of this Hawke front bench, the best we have had since Federation!

I cannot think of a more sobering statistic than the following: servicing our foreign debt now requires 64c in every dollar of export income. Sixty four cents of every dollar of income earned from our export trade now goes to paying off our debt-not to build up this nation, not to build our infrastructure, not even to look after our people, if one is worried about redistribution, but to pay our debt, for God's sake, courtesy of this front bench. In the last five years it has risen from a rate of 26c in every dollar to 64c. It did not happen between 1975 and 1983; it has happened since 1983.

Under this front bench Australia is now a less fair and more unequal society than five years ago. Over 140,000 young Australians are unemployed and at least 25,000 young Australians are being locked out of our higher education institutions. One hundred thousand low income Australians are condemned to the hospital waiting queues of the nation because of Medicare. There are some 60,000 living on the verge of homelessness and 40,000 sleeping in the open or in refuges. This is the greatest front bench since Federation! After five years of Labor an additional 700,000 Australians have fallen below the poverty line, and single income families with two children have suffered a $42 a week decline in their standard of living.

The summary of this case is that the standards of Government under Prime Minister Hawke have fallen alarmingly not only in respect of the personal behaviour of Ministers but also generally, economically and socially. The Prime Minister is presiding over not only an increasingly decaying Ministry but also an increasingly decaying Australia. This is Labor's legacy to this country and that is why the fifth anniversary of Labor rule is not a cause for celebration; it is a time to reflect on lost opportunities, policy failures and promises broken.

Let me conclude with a pithy summary of the economic record of the greatest front bench since Federation! We now have the highest interest rates ever. We have record bankruptcy rates. We have the highest current account deficit ever. We have the highest government spending ever. We have the biggest tax take ever. We have witnessed during the life of this Government the biggest drop in the Australian dollar ever. We have the longest public housing list the nation has ever known. We have record levels of home loan repayments. Real disposable income for our citizens is down by 10 per cent. Tax per week is up by between 40 and 60 per cent. The average level of unemployment is up and those unemployed are staying in that pathetic state for many more months than previously was the case. Inflation is twice as high as that of our trading partners, and hospital waiting lists are the longest ever.

The legislation which we are going to pass is all about using taxpayers' money to pay Ministers their additional salaries over and above that which they receive for being members of parliament. The direct payment of it is not judged on performance, but we in this House and the nation generally are entitled to assess Ministers and the Government front bench collectively on performance. That is what I have attempted to do this evening. On ministerial performance, according to the Westminster traditions and by any benchmark of ministerial propriet, the Government has a cricket team list of people who have failed the test, people who are no longer in the Parliament, people who are no longer in the Ministry, people who have been kicked down the totem pole. There are others who stay on the front bench and who still take the money when clearly, by any personal propriety or ministerial standards, they are not entitled to do so.

But if we leave that to one side a more damning case is to be made, and I have made it in this contribution, about the performance of the Government as a whole, the 30 men and women who have been charged with running this country, improving its prospects and importantly, after their period of stewardship, however temporary, leaving it in a better state than it was in when they first came to office. That is what government policy progress is all about. We are all in here to try to ensure that we leave this country in a better state for our grandchildren, and for our children more immediately, than our predecessors left it to us. On any benchmark, on any criterion, this Government, this so-called greatest front bench since Federation, has failed dismally. Five years after Labor came to power, there is an alarmingly long list of areas in which we can see clearly that Australia is now doing worse than was previously the case.

I said at the opening of my remarks that the Opposition will not be opposing this legislation. We will be guaranteeing that these Ministers receive their extra emoluments and salary. But may I say to them individually and collectively, and I say it to them on behalf of a growing majority of Australians, that we pass this legislation now but we pay them reluctantly. We pay them most reluctantly, and the sooner they go, the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand why the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), who has just resumed his seat, expresses concern about a Ministry of 30. I doubt whether the Liberals and Nationals could find 30 people on that side who would have the capacity to fill a Ministry of 30, or who would even want to serve with the Opposition's present Leader.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member spoke about what I believe is simply a list of falsehoods when he talked about the record of this Government. One falsehood that the Liberals keep touting around the nation is that the overseas debt we have is a debt owed by the Commonwealth Government. What members, such as the honourable member for Tangney, do not bother to say is that 60 per cent of our foreign debt is in fact owed by private enterprise. It is private enterprise that owes $6m out of every $10m. Twenty per cent of that debt is owed by the States and statutory authorities. I suggest that the honourable member go to Queensland, where the electricity authority owes something like $4 billion. He has the audacity to talk about that debt when in fact about 20 per cent is owed by the Commonwealth Government.

I believe he is also taking a very hypocritical stand when he talks about this Ministry, because he is talking about the increase to 30 and the cost. It cost about $700,000 to bring about that change, and yet we are saving $102m or $105m in administration. We are saving the cost of some 3,000 salaries across the bureaucracy of this nation. Let us come back to the hypocrisy. The honourable member now argues against 30 Ministers in a Parliament of 148. Let us go back to 1971, under the then Liberal-National Government. We find that there were 27 Ministers, plus six Assistant Ministers. So 17 years ago we had 33 in the Ministry, but it was not 33 out of 148 members; it was 33 out of 125. If we approach it on a per centum basis we find that at that time the Liberal-National Party Ministry composed 17.8 per cent of the total number of parliamentarians who served in this House-33 out of 125.

If we come to more recent times, in 1982, under the last Liberal-National Government, the Fraser Government, the proportion was 15.3 per cent. Let us compare that with the position now. We have an increase from 27 to 30, yet the Ministry represents 13.4 per cent of the total Parliament, because we have 30 Ministers out of 148 members.

TALK.START.PARA: —No senators?

—No, we are talking about 148 in the House of Representatives. The comparison has been made by the members opposite in trying to make out that we have a major discrepancy, a major growth. What we have done is endeavour to overcome administrative problems. Everyone realises that when changes are made problems can arise, but it is necessary to have the courage to make those changes.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of having a typical Opposition bucket speech, I would have thought that the honourable member would at least have tried to talk through some of the administrative changes that have been made here. What has taken place is a new approach, where 16 portfolio or Cabinet Ministers are responsible for 16 large portfolios. And supporting those 16, we have 14 non-Cabinet Ministers responsible for a specific part of the Cabinet Minister's or portfolio Minister's portfolio and assisting in a range of functions. There will always be difficulties, but no longer will we have the overlapping and the duplication of functions that existed under previous Liberal-National administrations. This will achieve, and has achieved in the period it has been in place, a substantial enhancement of the decision making process. We have seen enhancement of ministerial control over departments; we have seen senior portfolio Ministers being released from detailed administration work and a focus on strategy which is vitally important to the Australian population; we have seen a substantial reduction in the number of administration problems; we have seen savings; and we have seen better policy coordination and improved Budget processes. At what cost? At a cost of a few hundred thousand dollars-a maximum estimated cost of $1.1m in this financial year. Compare that with savings of $105m in a full year; savings of some 3,000 staff members across the bureaucracy; a portfolio saving, just in the Department of Administrative Services, of some 750 staff years. These are major changes.

A streamlining is taking place, yet honourable members stand up in this place and criticise. They ought to come back to the problem that we have a massive country to administer and service. It is a very much decentralised country. There are departments and subdepartments all over the nation and Ministers have a huge job. Yet honourable members criticise the Ministers in effect because they are getting a few per cent increase in salary. This change is necessary because, as the honourable member said, the Constitution locks in ministerial salaries, and unless we amend the Ministers of State Act, Ministers cannot have an increase in line with other members of Parliament.

I believe that Ministers are worth every cent they get. Let us consider the amount of money they are paid. A Minister has a base salary of $68,750. I suggest that is not a lot of money. If one compares that with some of the private salaries and incomes of members of the Liberal Party and the National Party, it is a pittance. Compare Ministers' salaries with the incomes earned by real estate agents, by people in the insurance industry, and by middle business leaders.

TALK.START.PARA: —By double dippers in the parliamentary pension scheme. They are pretty big bickies.

—The honourable member should look at pensions in the private system. When Joh Bjelke-Petersen froze my entitlement from the State House I made a check on what it would have been worth. Had I invested $70,000 in a private scheme, I could have walked away with $450,000, instead of the $300,000-odd that is held in Queensland. So that is nonsense. Let me come back to the responsibilities. Tonight I asked a Minister, `What are your responsibilities in dollar terms?'. He said, `About $4.7 billion'. What would we pay a private sector person to be ministerially responsible for a business worth $4.7 billion? I would suggest a little more than $68,750. We ought to pay Ministers properly. We ought to ensure that we get the best. That is what this Government has: we have 30 of the best. We have 30 members who come from the grass roots of the Labor Party and from every aspect of the community. We have lawyers, business people and teachers-right across the full spectrum of the community-serving this nation and serving it extremely well.

SPEECH.PARA: I take exception to the personal criticism and attack on Ministers by the honourable member for Tangney. He spoke about what the Government is supposed to have done. Let us think about what the Government has done-the millions of jobs created; overcoming the $9 billion deficit the Liberals and Nationals left us; overcoming the poverty that young people and families have faced; renewing and reshaping the health system, which was a shambles under the Liberal and National Government. Members of the Opposition talk about business and the problems that businesses face. Let us not forget that in 1982, under the Fraser-Howard Government, 70 per cent of small businesses went broke every three years. Those were the facts and figures that came out between 1976 and 1982. There had been a massive failure of business. This Government has proved itself over and over again as a government of the people. It has been led by Ministers who deserve the salaries they get. As I said, those salaries are a pittance compared with what they could earn if they went out into the private sector. It is not even $70,000 a year.

I have no hesitation in supporting this Bill. I believe that it should have the full support of the Parliament. It is a measure that is necessary because of the constitutional constraints that exist. We are simply keeping ministerial salaries in line with the salary increases that we, as members of parliament, have received.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Arrival Tax-Death of Mr M. Lynch-Televising of 1990 Commonwealth Games-Nuclear Free Zones-South Australian Nursing Homes-Assistance to Farmers

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On arrival at Sydney Airport from overseas in February this year, I fully expected to be approached for payment of the controversial but legal arrival tax of $5. I have to admit that at the time I was not sure whether it had been prepaid, and I have to also confess that I was relieved when no-one asked me for it. It was more than interesting to note that there did not seem to be any place I could have paid it, even if I had pursued the matter on arrival.

SPEECH.PARA: On establishing that I actually had an unfulfilled obligation to pay the tax, I instituted inquiries as to how I might go about it after I returned to Perth. Inquiries having been made, I commenced on the assumption that someone in the Department of Finance or the Department of the Treasury would be likely to accept the money. Accordingly, the Department of Finance was contacted. Advice was obtained that the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) would accept payment of the arrival tax. After checking with the ATO, advice obtained from it said that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs would be happy to accommodate me. Unfortunately, that Department did not want to know and in turn advised me that the airline carrier collected the tax-never mind that it did not and that that was the reason for the inquiry in the first place.

Ever hopeful, I rang Thai Airlines, which said that the post office collected the tax. Never one to give up easily, my secretary phoned the office of the State Manager of Australia Post and was told that the $5 fee was not really an arrival tax, but an immigration clearance fee. I understand that one could go to any post office and as well as purchasing a $20 departure tax stamp, if that was appropriate, one could also buy a $5 immigration clearance fee stamp. Naturally overseas visitors would be excluded from this procedure for fairly obvious reasons. If those reasons are not apparent to honourable members, what overseas visitor with a difficulty with this language, but even without a difficulty with our language, would know, without advice from anyone at Sydney Airport or any other arrival centre, where he or she should go to pay the $5 tax?

The gentleman from Australia Post said that, if someone had entered Australia without paying the immigration clearance fee, he could-only if he wished; he did not have to-go to a post office and purchase a $5 stamp. The difficulties being experienced by the Government in collecting the $5 arrival tax-or is it really an immigration clearance fee, or are they different taxes?-in no way match the problems that conscience-stricken individuals like me encounter in trying to pay the blessed thing.

Honourable members know what trouble members in this House get into for not observing their obligations under the tax laws. We have seen people on either side of the chamber criticised. I made a genuine effort. Before I found out from Australia Post I went to the trouble of writing to the Department of Administrative Services and enclosing a cheque. A member of its staff phoned to say that the Department did not know what to do with the cheque. I have on my desk a letter which arrived last week, just before I left to attend the Parliament, returning the cheque. I do know now that I had to go to Australia Post. I will be one of the few people, if I ever get the opportunity to pay the rotten tax, to have paid it.

We have on our books a tax which is not collected, not collectable, and no-one is seriously trying to collect it. Why not repeal the stupid law immediately before we get into any more trouble? The question arises: is this just another unintended consequence of the Government's failure to think through yet another tax, or is it a natural consequence of the example of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) flouting the laws which he administers and which he breached by failing to lodge his personal income tax returns without attracting prescribed penalties? Is that the natural way of things under this Administration? I would like to pose the following question amongst my colleagues and members of this place: how many have been unable to pay this tax?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to pay tribute to a very close friend of mine and staunch supporter of the Labor movement in Wollongong, Michael Lynch, who unfortunately passed away two or three weeks ago. Michael was born in Ashbury in 1931 and was educated at Marist Brothers, Darlinghurst and St Joseph's College, Hunters Hill. He joined the Department of the Navy as a civilian in his early twenties and ended up as Chief of Personnel Removals-an interesting position by its title alone. His love affair with the English and Greek languages was born at an early age from his father who was then a classics master at Canterbury Boys High before going to the Bar after World War II. He was never lost for a word, nor the meaning of a word. In fact, Michael had a very clever, brilliant analytical mind. After his father's death in 1961 he decided to follow in his father's and brother's footsteps and study law. He was admitted to the Bar in December 1965. He practised in Sydney between 1965 and 1973 and came to the Wollongong Bar in 1973 where he developed a large criminal practice. He was appointed Crown Prosecutor in September 1980. Many of his colleagues and, I am sure, many of those people who appeared not necessarily in the witness box but certainly within the courts generally could testify to the fact that his forte was indeed cross-examination in that position of Crown Prosecutor. Michael was a man of many parts and interests. His other passions were archaeology, reading, astronomy, electronics, jazz and, indeed, songs of the twenties and thirties.

SPEECH.PARA: Michael joined the Australian Labor Party in 1954 when he was 23. Indeed, his other great love came to the surface then. He was a member of the Croydon Park, Campsie and Mosman branches at various times. When he came to Wollongong he joined the Keiraville-Gwynneville branch where he served terms as president, secretary-treasurer and delegate to Cunningham Federal Electorate Council (FEC) and Corrimal State Electorate Council (SEC). Between 1977 and 1984 he was a Corrimal SEC delegate to State Conference on six occasions and also delegate to State Council for six years. He transferred to Balgownie branch, my own branch, in December 1979 and served terms as president, vice-president, secretary and branch campaign director for many Federal, State and municipal elections and branch returning officer for seven years. He was an FEC and SEC delegate for the last several years. In fact, he held the last three positions when, unfortunately, he died.

Michael was a very close and personal friend of mine, and, indeed, of my wife and family. He and his wife, Eleanor, and my wife, Carol, and I spent many pleasant hours together. I have indicated that he had a brilliant analytical mind. In fact, Michael was the sort of person one would rather have on one's side playing Trivial Pursuit than against one. He will be sadly missed as a friend. He will certainly be sadly missed as somebody who has contributed greatly to the community within Wollongong, through his chosen profession as a lawyer, and to the Labor Party to which he was prepared to contribute greatly. He will also be missed by what I call his other family, as well as his lovely wife Eleanor. I am referring, of course, to his two black labrador dogs aptly named Ben Chifley and Jill Wran. I think that that has some significance for the Labor Party.

Michael was content to be a man who contributed to the Labor movement without necessarily seeking office himself. He was prepared to contribute in a great fashion. As I have indicated, Michael Lynch was the sort of person I was proud to call a friend. He was the sort of person who contributed greatly to the Labor movement. Indeed, he was the sort of person who will be sadly missed by all his friends in Wollongong, Sydney, different parts of Australia and Papua New Guinea. To his wife Eleanor I can only say that I hope that I can still continue to be as close a friend to her as I was to both her and Michael when Michael was alive. I certainly hope to look after her interests in the way which she would wish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The winning of the tender by Channel 9 to telecast the Commonwealth Games to be held in Auckland in 1990 no doubt will spell a rating win for that network as more and more people tune in to it over that period. There is no doubt that the telecast of the Winter Olympics in Calgary proved a bonanza for the Channel 9 network and allowed it to win the ratings period by a significant margin. However, the letting of the contract to Channel 9 will spell disaster for a great many country people who obviously cannot receive the Channel 9 signal, nor those of any of its affiliate country stations.
—You can watch them at the International Motel.

—The honourable member for Ballarat makes a number of facetious and quite irrelevant interjections. If he were really concerned about a number of his constituents who are unable to receive Channel 9, either directly or by relay, he would be able to make a more constructive contribution. The point is that country people are fed up with not being able to view on television many of the major sporting events that are held either in this country or internationally. They did not get to see on television the last Olympic Games held in Los Angeles because they were broadcast by the Channel 10 network. They will not see television broadcasts of the Olympic Games to be held in Seoul because they are to be broadcast on the Channel 10 network. They do not get to see the Victorian Football League's grand final or the running of the Melbourne Cup because those events are also broadcast by commercial networks. A number of country people may well view some or other of these great sporting events, depending on whether the local commercial television station subscribes to the network broadcasting them or to the specific program.

SPEECH.PARA: Far too many Australians receive only the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's (ABC) broadcasts. It is a disgrace that the ABC does not bid properly for the televising of these great events. I do not mean to convey that the ABC should bid to telecast every grand final of every minuscule sport around the place. It is far easier for the commercial networks to stick up 12 television cameras around a dirt track and televise the motor rally or the motor cars running around that track. But there is no reason why the ABC should be continually outbid for the right to televise these indisputably great events that are of tremendously wide appeal. If the ABC diverted some of the funds that are spent on the self-indulgent garbage which with such propensity it perpetrates upon its unsuspecting viewers, it might actually win a few of the tenders. The question must be asked: why does it lose every time to the disadvantage of hundreds of thousands of Australians? The ABC cannot compete--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the record of the National Party?

—The honourable member for Eden Monaro is joining the honourable member for Ballarat in making specious interjections. Does not the honourable member care about some of the people in the south-western area of his electorate or those on the South Coast who are totally unable to receive any television broadcasts other than the ABC? The ABC has yet to offer a convincing explanation as to why it is the unsuccessful bidder--
—It does not have the money.

—The honourable member for La Trobe says that it does not have the money. It certainly has the money to pursue a number of unrepresentative programs that are of minuscule appeal to the larger community. I call upon the ABC to at long last offer a convincing reason, other than mismanagement on its part, as to why hundreds of thousands of Australians are being left out in the cold yet again and why there seems to be two classes of television viewers in this country, the first being those who are within range to pick up the broadcasts of the commercial television stations and the other being those who are in the outback, which includes a number of areas of the East Gippsland region. This is a terribly serious matter. I hope that the ABC can offer some proper reasons as to why it is always the loser, it seems, not just in bidding for great sporting functions, but in anything it turns its hand to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a great fear throughout the world that nuclear war could break out at any time. Regrettably, in four of the six inhabited continents of the world thousands of people are dying or are injured as a result of wars, revolutions or rebellions of one kind or another. Some of these conflicts cause great fear because they could so easily lead to a nuclear war. In the case of many conflicts there is a fear that the two superpowers may become embroiled, which could lead to an escalation of conflict, eventually involving nuclear weapons. For this reason there was a great sigh of relief when the treaty eliminating intermediate and short range nuclear weapons was signed by the Soviet Union and the United States of America on 8 December 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: Another great step forward has been the creation of nuclear free zones in the South Pacific, Antarctica, South America, the Balkans and northern Europe. The nuclear free zones in the South Pacific were preceded by those in the many local municipal council areas all over Australia. Local councils led the way by declaring nuclear free zones in their municipalities. Our Government is to be commended for its initiative in sponsoring the South Pacific nuclear free zone.

Other nuclear free zones are also proposed. The Soviet Union has proposed a nuclear free zone in the Arctic, but unfortunately the Canadian Government has, so far, not supported that proposal. That is surprising because it is supporting the nuclear free zone in the Antarctic. Another nuclear free zone which has been proposed is the 100-kilometre corridor between the two German republics. The Social Democratic Party of the Federal Republic of Germany and the Socialist Unity Party of the German Democratic Republic have agreed to the proposed nuclear free corridor between the two countries. But again, unfortunately, the Government of the Federal Republic is not prepared to consider the proposal.

The German Democratic Republic has appealed to the people of the world to support disarmament, and nuclear disarmament in particular. I should like to quote part of that appeal because, in my view, the German Democratic Republic is endeavouring to ensure, by its appeal for the creation of additional nuclear free zones and its organisation of an international forum to discuss nuclear weapons free zones, the natural outcome of a world free of nuclear weapons:

The people of the world want to see further steps along the road of nuclear disarmament, as the danger of a nuclear inferno has not yet been banished. Every path leading to a peaceful world, free of nuclear weapons, must be explored. This includes the creation of regions, zones and corridors free of nuclear weapons. Nuclear-weapon-free zones have already proved their worth in Latin America and in the South Pacific. The idea of nuclear-weapon-free zones is gaining ground in North and South, East and West. The German Democratic Republic, which is known for its deep commitment to a nuclear-weapon-free corridor in Central Europe and for the elimination of all nuclear weapons from not only Europe, but the whole world, believes that it is high time that a discussion took place about the whole question of nuclear-weapon-free zones. This should be an international forum for leading representatives of states, governments and parliaments, political parties, trade unions, youth movements, sporting associations, women's organizations, peace movements, associations of scientists and of artists, churches and religious communities and other interested groups and individuals. To this end a preparatory committee has been constituted in the GDR capital, Berlin, today of an International Meeting for Nuclear-Weapon-Free Zones to be held in Berlin from 20-22 June 1988.
The day on which the committee was constituted was 18 February 1988. The appeal goes on:

We appeal to people of all political persuasions and religious beliefs, whatever their occupation or age, and wherever they live, to support the preparation for this international gathering, that it may turn out to be an objective and open dialogue serving peace and disarmament.

I hope that all Australians will support this conference. I believe it is very important to create more nuclear weapons free zones throughout the world. Hopefully, that will eventually lead to a nuclear free world, a place in which people no longer fear for what might be the outcome of local conflicts, or indeed fear that a nuclear war could envelope the whole world as a result of a conflict between, say, Iraq and Iran, or perhaps in the Middle East. The conference has my full support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to talk at great length about the speech we have just heard, but the speech by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) was profoundly depressing and rather strange to hear in the Australian Parliament. We have a member of the Australian Parliament falling for one of the oldest and simplest forms of propaganda, coming from one of the world's most totalitarian and oppressive nations which has never given a fig for human rights. The honourable member for La Trobe is a member of this House who I know is very sincere in campaigning for human rights, but fancy his falling for that old two-card trick.

SPEECH.PARA: Talking of human rights, I want to say something tonight about my concern about nursing homes in South Australia and the Government's current proposal-which it now says it will review, reconsider and put up more proposals in a few days time-to reduce the hours of nursing home care in South Australian nursing homes from an average of around 21 hours to 17 hours. This is an extraordinary proposal. When one asks oneself what is the logic for the Government taking this step, the explanation is that the Government wants to level down South Australia to the standards of other States. I would have thought that honourable members from other States-although there is practically no one in the House tonight who is not from South Australia-would be standing in this House and appealing to the Government to raise the standards of nursing home care in their States to the level of those in South Australia. But no, the Government, myopic as ever, wants to go in the other direction and create hardship and difficulties for the elderly and infirm in South Australia. That is a simple and sincere statement as to precisely what will happen. What sort of Government do we have if its ambition is to lower standards? I know that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), claims to have great concern for issues of this sort. I know that she, having heard my speech, will go straight to the relevant Minister and say, `Please, why lower standards of nursing home care? Why harm the elderly, the disadvantaged, the frail in South Australia just to get some statistical average?'.

This proposal is having a very real impact in my electorate alone. There is a proposal, which we in my electorate have fought for for many years, to establish a new nursing home in the town of McLaren Vale. McLaren Vale is in the southern vales, sometimes known as the wine coast of South Australia, and a large number of elderly people live in that area who in the past have had to move into the metropolitan area if they have wanted to go or have had to go into nursing homes. They are not metropolitan dwellers; they do not want to go and live in a city. Their families, relatives and friends live in the southern vales area, and that is an environment many have known all their lives. However, because there is no nursing home accommodation there, they have had to move out. At long last, after a great sustained battle, we finally managed to get approval for the building of a 30-bed nursing home at McLaren Vale to be built and managed by Aged Cottage Homes. But as a consequence of the uncertainty about the Government's changed policy which I have already described, the fact is that that nursing home has now been put in mothballs. Aged Cottage Homes has said that it will not proceed any longer with plans to build the nursing home until the Government's policy is clear.

If the Government goes ahead, as it proposes and reduces the number of hours of nursing home care, the McLaren Vale nursing home will not proceed in the form planned, and may not proceed at all. In the town of Goolwa a new 30-bed nursing home was opened recently and is now filling up, but the Government has also reneged on financial commitments to Aged Cottage Homes at Goolwa and it now has a bill of $40,000 a year to meet. That charitable organisation has to meet a bill of $40,000 a year to make up for the Government reneging on former financial commitments. This Government, which claims to be compassionate particularly now that it has found that lower income people have abandoned it in droves, is turning its back on the aged and frail in South Australia. That is a very serious problem. It is a matter of deep concern to me that people in my electorate are being harmed. I call on the Government to wake up and look after the elderly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last few weeks we have witnessed heavy flood rains in many parts of Australia. While I sympathise with and recognise the damage that has resulted, there will be massive benefits to rural regions, particularly those areas which have suffered drought conditions. Unfortunately, while some areas in my electorate received much needed rain, the Burnett region is still in need of more rain for run-off to replenish dams and creeks. This region is experiencing more than five years of severe drought.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently, the Leader of the Federal National Party of Australia, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), correctly stated during a visit to my electorate that the Burnett region has experienced drought for more than five years. The Isis region also has suffered severely from drought. The sugar crop in Isis this year, which would normally be in excess of 600,000 tonnes, is devastatingly poor, and the crushing may well go for only seven weeks.

Several meetings have been held in the Burnett region at which concern has been expressed about the effects of the drought. At a National Party meeting held in Eidsvold a watchdog committee was formed. Sadly, though, politics seem to be more important to that committee than farmers' hardship. Most members of this committee are leading lights in the local National Party branches. The organiser of the meeting, the National Party President in Eidsvold, stated that there is a need to change guidelines for household support so that families need not split up. Under the rural adjustment scheme, part C, household support gives income equivalent to unemployment benefit so that farmers can provide essential needs for their families. For the first 12 months farmers need not lease or try to sell their farms so that they are able to consider their options. Mr Fred Henke, the Chairman of the Hinkler division of the National Party, has on more than one occasion made cynical statements to the media, which have confused and disadvantaged farmers who are eligible for household support. I am pleased to say that, on my invitation, officers from the Department of Social Security will be visiting the region. Four representatives from the Department-Mr Ken Carr, the manager, Mr Jeff Watson, Shirley Saokowski and Janet Pownell-will be visiting the Eidsvold and Monto region on 28 and 29 April to correctly inform farmers of their entitlements.

I would also like to express my concern for those farmers who are in severe financial hardship and are having trouble restructuring their incomes. I stress, however, that grants of over $100m that are being asked for are not the answer. The Burnett region, along with the Wimmera, Eyre Peninsula, north Tasmania, south-west Western Australia and south-east New South Wales, including the Cooma region, are all suffering from drought. An amount of about $1 billion would be needed if grants were established for all of those regions at a time when all groups are expressing the need for financial restraint. However, contrary to what the State Minister for Primary Industries implies, Federal assistance is available.

The natural disaster relief arrangements are, and have been, in place. The relevant point I make is that a drought has existed for more than five years, and even the Federal Leader of the National Party acknowledges this. Yet the region was declared drought stricken only a few months ago by the Queensland Government. The State Government is required to declare specific areas as drought affected, and then inform the Federal Government. The natural disaster relief arrangements then come into operation. The State pays the first $14m. It then matches payments from $14m to $24.5m on a dollar for dollar basis. Over $24.5m, the Federal Government allocates $3 for every $1 that the State contributes. It is totally untrue to state that the Federal Government is unresponsive. The irony of all this is that Mr Neville Harper, the State Minister for Primary Industries, who is the local State member, obviously did not know that a five-year drought existed in his own electorate. Why did it take him five years to declare it a drought disaster? Surely the drought was just as bad last year as it is this year.

Farmers have also expressed their concerns in respect of interest payments. Under this scheme the Federal Government provides funds to the Queensland Government at no interest and the Queensland Government lends this money at the rate of 4 per cent. With the stroke of a pen, the State Government can take up this matter and absorb its own costs. In other words, it can lend this money at next to nothing. Obviously, Mr Harper is unable to handle this task. It seems that he is totally out of touch with his own electorate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 11 p.m.
